DIVISION 2. - CITY ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-81. - Establishment of position. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Minn. Stats. § 412.111, applicable to the city operating under Optional Plan A as defined in state law, the city administrator shall be appointed by the council for an indefinite term. The city administrator shall be hired by four-fifths vote of the city council, and be subject to a written employment agreement. The city administrator shall be subject to termination, which shall be preceded by 30 days' written notice of the intent of the city council to vote on the issue of termination and upon a four-fifths vote of the council authorizing the termination, which shall require an additional 60 days' notice for the termination to be final. 
(Code 1989, § 205.01; Ord. No. 214, § 300.02(1), 5-16-1994) 
Sec. 2-82. - General duties. 
    The city administrator shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)	Act as the chief administrative official of the city; 
(2)	Be responsible for the proper administration and coordination of all of the affairs of the city and for the fair and impartial provision of city services, consistent with city council policy and discretion; 
(3)	Supervise and direct the various city departments, including the city clerk and director of public works, and otherwise be responsible for the implementation of council directives and policies; 
(4)	Responsibility for overseeing and managing financial and accounting matters; 
(5)	Prepare and submit an annual budget for review and approval by the city council; 
(6)	Keep the council informed of the financial condition of the city and recommend action as appropriate; 
(7)	Manage and invest city funds in accordance with council guidelines and sound financial practices; 
(8)	Oversee all city purchases with council approval; 
(9)	Coordinate all city risk management, including insurance; and 
(10)	Assume responsibility for other duties as prescribed by the council by resolution or job description approved by the city council. 
(Code 1989, § 205.02; Ord. No. 214, § 300.02(2), 5-16-1994) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 10. 
State Law reference- The Liquor Act, Minn. Stats. § 340A.901; authority to impose further restrictions and regulations on the sale and possession of alcoholic beverages, Minn. Stats. § 340A.509. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any person making an application for a license under this chapter. 
    Application means a written, verified form to be completed by the applicant at his request for a license, furnished by the city clerk and uniformly required as a prerequisite to the consideration of the issuance of a license for a business. 
State Law reference- Verified, written application required by proposed retail licensee, Minn. Rules § 7515.0400. 
    Club means an incorporated organization organized under the laws of the state for civic, fraternal, social or business purposes, for intellectual improvement, or for the promotion of sports, or a congressionally chartered veterans' organization, which: 
(1)	Has more than 50 members; 
(2)	Has owned or rented a building or space in a building for more than one year that is suitable and adequate for the accommodation of its members; and 
(3)	Is directed by a board of directors, executive committee, or other similar body chosen by the members at a meeting held for that purpose. 
No member, officer, agent or employee shall receive any profit from the distribution or sale of beverages to the members of the club, or their guests, beyond a reasonable salary or wages fixed and voted each year by the governing body. 
State Law reference- Definition of "club," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 7. 
    Distilled spirits means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, spirits of wine, whiskey, rum, brandy, gin, and other distilled spirits, including all dilutions and mixtures, for nonindustrial use. 
State Law reference- Definition of "distilled spirits," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 9. 
    Guest means a person not a member of the club licensee but present on this club licensed premises in the company of a host member. 
    Host member means a member who is entertaining a guest who is in the member's company at all times such guest is on the licensed premises. 
    Hotel means an establishment where food and lodging are regularly furnished to transients and which has: 
(1)	A dining room serving the general public at tables and having facilities for seating at least 30 guests at one time; 
(2)	No less than 40 guest rooms. 
State Law reference- Definition of "hotel," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 13. 
    Intoxicating liquor means ethyl alcohol, distilled, fermented, spirituous, vinous and malt beverages containing in excess of 3.2 percent of alcohol by weight. 
State Law reference- Definition of "intoxicating liquor," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 14. 
    License means a document issued by the city to an applicant permitting him to carry on and transact the business stated in the license. 
    License fee means the money paid to the city pursuant to an application and prior to issuance of a license to transact and carry on the business stated in the license. 
    Licensee means a person who, pursuant to his approved application, holds a valid, current, unexpired license, which has neither been revoked nor suspended, from the city for carrying on the business stated in the license. 
    Manufacturer means every person who, by process of manufacture, fermenting, brewing, distilling, refining, rectifying, blending or by the combination of different materials, prepares or produces intoxicating liquors, wine or malt liquor for sale. 
State Law reference- Definition of "manufacturer," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 17. 
    Member means any person in good standing according to rules and regulations of the licensed club, wherever located, and having evidence of current membership upon his person. 
    Off-sale means the retail sale of alcoholic beverages in original packages for consumption off or away from the premises where sold. 
State Law reference- Definition of "off-sale," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 20. 
    On-sale means the retail sale of alcoholic beverages by the glass or by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold only. 
State Law reference- Definition of "on-sale," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 21. 
    Package and original package mean any container or receptacle holding alcoholic beverages, which container or receptacle is corked, capped or sealed by a manufacturer or wholesaler. 
State Law reference- Definition of "package," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 22. 
    Restaurant means any establishment, other than a hotel, which: 
(1)	Is under the control of a single proprietor or manager; 
(2)	Has appropriate facilities for the preparation of food on the premises; 
(3)	In consideration of payment, meals are regularly served at tables to the general public; 
(4)	Employs an adequate staff to provide the usual and suitable service to its guests, and the serving of foods; and 
(5)	Shall have seating facilities for seating not less than 30 guests at one time. 
State Law reference- Definition of "restaurant," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 25. 
    Sale, sell and sold mean all barters and all manners or means of furnishing beer, wine, or liquor to persons, including such furnishing in violation or evasion of law. 
    3.2 percent malt liquor means malt liquor containing not less than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume nor more than 3.2 percent alcohol by weight. 
State Law reference- Definition of "3.2 percent malt liquor," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 19. 
    Wholesaler means a person who sells alcoholic beverages to persons to whom sale is permitted under Minn. Stats. § 340A.310, from a stock maintained in a warehouse in the state. 
State Law reference- Definition of "wholesaler," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 28. 
    Wine means the product made from the normal alcoholic fermentation of grapes, including still wine, sparkling and carbonated wine, wine made from condensed grape must, wine made from other agricultural products than sound, ripe grapes, imitation wine, compounds sold as wine, vermouth, cider, perry and sake, in each instance containing not less than one-half of one percent nor more than 24 percent alcohol by volume for nonindustrial use. Wine does not include distilled spirits. 
State Law reference- Definition of "wine," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 29. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.02(9); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.00, 9-6-1994) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-2. - Violation a misdemeanor. 
    Every person violates a section, subdivision, paragraph or provision of this chapter when he performs an act prohibited or declared unlawful or fails to act when such failure is prohibited or declared unlawful, and upon conviction shall be punished as for a misdemeanor, in accordance with section 1-13, except as otherwise stated in specific provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.05(3); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.62, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Where no other penalty is specified a violation of any provision of this chapter is a misdemeanor, Minn. Stats. § 340A.703. 
Secs. 4-3-4-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- License or permit required to sell, barter, keep for sale, charge for possession, or otherwise dispose of alcoholic beverages as part of a commercial transaction, Minn. Stats. § 340A.401. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 4-31-4-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - APPLICATION PROCEDURE 

Sec. 4-51. - Application. 
    All applications shall be made at the office of the city clerk upon forms prescribed by the state commissioner of public safety and furnished by the city, along with such additional information as the council may desire. Information required may vary with the type of business organization making application. All questions asked or information required by the application forms shall be answered fully and completely by the applicant. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.04(1); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02(1), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Application forms for licenses required by Minn. Stats. ch. 340A shall be furnished by the state commissioner of public safety, Minn. Rules § 7515.0200; application procedures, Minn. Rules §§ 7515.0430, subp. 1 (on-sale), 7515.0440, subp. 2 (off-sale and certain on-sale). 
Sec. 4-52. - False statements. 
    It is unlawful for any applicant to intentionally make a false statement or omission upon any application form. Any false statement in such application or any willful omission to state any information called for on such application form shall, upon discovery of such falsehood, work an automatic refusal of license or, if already issued, shall render any license issued pursuant to such falsehood void and of no effect to protect the applicant from prosecution for violation of this chapter or any part of this chapter. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.05(7); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02(2), 9-6-1994) 
Sec. 4-53. - Application and investigation fees. 
(a)	At the time of the initial application, applicants, except applicants for temporary licenses, shall pay a fee, to cover the costs of the city in processing the application and ensuing investigation. The fees are established according to Minn. Stats. § 340A.408 and incorporated in the schedule of fees, amended from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(b)	Upon rejection of any application for a license or upon withdrawal of an application before approval of the issuance by the council, the license fee shall be refunded to the applicant. 
(c)	For licenses issued and which are to become effective other than on the first day of the license year, the fee to be paid with the application shall be a prorated share of the annual license fee. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.07(1); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02(3), (4)(a), (b), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- License restrictions, recommendation and review of applicants, Minn. Stats. § 340A.410, subd. 2; authority to investigate applicant for on-sale liquor license, Minn. Stats. § 340A.412. 
Sec. 4-54. - Fixing license and investigation fees. 
(a)	All license and investigation fees provided for in this chapter, including but not by way of limitation fees for on-sale and off-sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor, temporary on-sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor, on-sale and temporary off-sale of intoxicating liquor, and on-sale of wine, shall be fixed and determined by the council, adopted by resolution, and uniformly enforced. Such fees may, from time to time, be amended by the council by resolution. A copy of the resolution shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and open to inspection during regular business hours. 
(b)	No fees for alcoholic beverage licenses shall be increased except after notice and hearing on the proposed increase. Notice of the proposed increase shall be mailed to all affected licensees at least 30 days before the date set for the hearing. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08(3); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.24, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to set license fees, Minn. Stats. § 340A.408, subds. 1-3; requirement of notice and hearing on proposed fee increases by authority issuing intoxicating liquor and 3.2 percent malt liquor licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.408, subd. 3a. 
Sec. 4-55. - Refunds in certain cases. 
    If during the license year the licensed premises shall be destroyed or so damaged by fire or other catastrophe that the licensee shall cease to carry on the licensed business, or in case the business of the licensee shall cease by reason of illness or death, or if it shall become unlawful for the licensee to carry on the licensed business for a reason other than a license revocation, the city shall, upon the happening of any such event, refund to the licensee or to his estate such pro rata portion of the license fee paid as corresponds to the time such license had yet to run. 
(Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02(4)(c), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Circumstances under which a pro rata share of an annual license fee may be refunded to the licensee or his estate, Minn. Stats. § 340A.408, subd. 5. 
Sec. 4-56. - Action. 
(a)	Granting. All applications, including proposed license periods, must be consistent with Minn. Stats. ch. 340A, Minn. Rules ch. 7515, and this article. The council may approve any application for a period of the remainder of the then current license year or for the entire ensuing license year. 
(b)	Issuing. If an application is approved, and upon payment of the license fee, the city clerk shall forthwith issue a license in the form prescribed by the city or the state department of public safety, as the case may be. 
(c)	Refusal. The council may, in its sole discretion and for any reasonable cause, refuse to grant any application. 
(1)	No retail license may be issued to a person: 
a.	Under 21 years of age; 
b.	Who has had an intoxicating liquor or 3.2 percent malt liquor license revoked within five years of the license application, or to any person who at the time of the violation owns any interest, whether as a holder of more than five percent of the capital stock of a corporation licensee, as a partner or otherwise, in the premises or in the business conducted on the premises, or to a corporation, partnership, association, enterprise, business or firm in which any such person is in any manner interested; 
c.	Not of good moral character and repute or of questionable business reputation; or 
d.	Who has a direct or indirect interest in a manufacturer, brewer, or wholesaler. 
(2)	In addition, no new retail license may be issued to, and the city clerk may refuse to renew the license of, a person who, within five years of the license application, has been convicted of a felony or a willful violation of a federal or state law or local ordinance governing the manufacture, sale, distribution or possession for sale or distribution of an alcoholic beverage. 
(3)	No person shall be granted liquor or wine licenses at more than one location within the city. For the purpose of this section, any person owning any interest in or having an immediate family member who owns any interest in another commercial establishment holding a liquor or wine license shall not be granted another liquor or wine license. 
(d)	Corporate applicants. Applications by corporate applicants must be accompanied by verifiable documentation of the identity and respective interests of all shareholders. Applicants must be prepared to produce, for the examination by the city council, minute books and business records to the extent necessary to ascertain the identity and respective interests of all shareholders or parties holding an interest in the proposed corporate licensee. 
(Code 1989, § 1000; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Persons eligible for retail licensing, Minn. Stats. § 340A.402; license certificate, Minn. Rules § 7515.0430, subp. 6. 
Sec. 4-57. - Delinquent taxes and charges. 
    No license under this article shall be granted for operation on any premises upon which taxes, assessments or installments or other financial claims of the city are owed by the applicant and are delinquent and unpaid. For the purpose of this section, the term "applicant" includes persons and related persons, owning, directly or indirectly, at least a 50 percent beneficial interest in the proposed license or in the entity making the application, and at least an undivided half interest in the premises proposed to be licensed or at least a 50 percent beneficial interest in the entity owning such premises. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08(8); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.06, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt and incorporate by reference any statute, pertinent administrative rule, or code of Minnesota, Minn. Stats. § 471.62. 
Sec. 4-58. - Manager or agent. 
    Before a license is issued under this article to an individual who is a nonresident of the city, or more than one individual, whether or not they are residents of the city, or to a corporation, partnership or association, the applicant shall, by the terms of his written consent, take full responsibility for the conduct of the licensed premises, and serve as agent for service of notices and other process relating to the license. Such manager or agent must be a person who, by reason of age, character, reputation and other attributes, could qualify individually as a licensee. If such manager or agent ceases to act in such capacity for the licensee without appointment of a successor, the license issued pursuant to such appointment shall be subject to revocation or suspension. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08(1); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02, 9-6-1994) 
Secs. 4-59-4-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATION OF EXISTING LICENSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 4-81. - Duplicate licenses. 
    Duplicates of all original licenses under this article may be issued by the city clerk without action by the council upon licensee's affidavit that the original has been lost and upon payment of a fee set from time to time by the council for issuance of the duplicate. All duplicate licenses shall be clearly marked DUPLICATE. 
(Code 1989, § 1000; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02, 9-6-1994) 
Sec. 4-82. - Renewal of licenses. 
    Applications for renewal of all licenses under this article shall be made at least 60 days prior to the date of expiration of the license and shall contain such information as is required by the city clerk. This time requirement may be waived by the council for good and sufficient cause. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.05(4); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.04, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Items forwarded to commissioner of public safety at renewal of off-sale and certain on-sale applications, Minn. Rules § 7515.0440, subp. 4. 
Sec. 4-83. - Termination. 
    Licenses shall terminate only by expiration or revocation. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.06(4); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02, 9-6-1994) 
Sec. 4-84. - Revocation, suspension or fine. 
(a)	Upon a finding that the licensee of any license granted pursuant to this division has failed to comply with any applicable statute, regulation or ordinance relating to alcoholic beverages, the council shall either suspend the license for a period not to exceed 60 days, revoke the license or impose a civil fine on the licensee not to exceed $2,000.00 for each violation, or impose any combination of these sanctions. 
(b)	No suspension, fine or revocation shall take effect until the licensee or permit holder has been afforded an opportunity for a hearing before the council, a committee of the council, or a hearing examiner, as may be determined by the council in action calling the hearing. Such hearing, to be conducted in accordance with Minn. Stats. §§ 14.57-14.62 and Minn. Rules §§ 1400.5100-1400.8400, shall be called by the council upon written notice to the licensee served in person or by certified mail not less than 30 days prior to the hearing date, stating the time, place, and purpose of the hearing. The council may, in its discretion, contract with the state for a hearing examiner to hold such hearing. 
(c)	The council shall remove the license upon conviction of any licensee or agent or employee of a licensee for violating any law relating to the sale or possession of beer, wine or liquor upon the premises of the licensee or if such revocation is mandatory by statute. If it shall be made to appear at the hearing that such violation was not willful, the council may order suspension or a fine not to exceed $2,000.00. Revocation shall be ordered upon the third such violation or offense. Grounds for suspension, fine, revocation or some combination include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)	Permitting illegal acts upon the licensed premises unrelated to the sale of beer, wine or liquor; 
(2)	Having knowledge of such illegal acts upon the licensed premises, but failing to report such acts to police; 
(3)	Failing or refusing to cooperate fully with police in investigating such alleged illegal acts upon licensed premises; 
(4)	Failing to maintain financial responsibility required by this article; or 
(5)	Failing to pay any portion of a fee when due. 
(Code 1989, §§ 1000.06, 1000.07, 1000.11; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02(4)(a), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- License revocation or suspension, civil penalty, Minn. Stats. § 340A.415; notice of a contested administrative hearing must be served not less than 30 days prior to the hearing, Minn. Rules § 1400.5600, subp. 3. 
Secs. 4-85-4-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PROOF OF FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY 

Sec. 4-101. - Proof. 
    Except as provided by Minn. Stats. § 340A.409, subd. 4, no beer, wine or liquor license shall be issued, maintained or renewed unless and until the applicant has provided proof of financial responsibility imposed by Minn. Stats. § 340A.409, by filing with the city: 
(1)	A certificate that there is in effect for the license period an insurance policy or pool providing minimum coverages of $100,000.00 because of bodily injury to any one person in any one occurrence, and $300,000.00 because of bodily injury to two or more persons in any one occurrence, and in the amount of $100,000.00 because of injury to or destruction of property of others in any one occurrence, and $100,000.00 for loss of means of support of any one person in any one occurrence, and, subject to the limit of one person, $300,000.00 for loss of means of support of two or more persons in any one occurrence; an annual aggregate policy limit for dram shop liability of not less than $300,000.00 per policy may be included in the policy provision; 
(2)	A bond of a surety company with minimum coverages as provided in subsection (1) of this section; or, 
(3)	A certificate of the state treasurer that the licensee has deposited with him $100,000.00 in cash or securities which may legally be purchased by savings banks or for trust funds having a market value of $100,000.00. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.04; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.26, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Minimum requirement for proof of financial responsibility by certificate of insurance policy, Minn. Stats. § 340A.409, subd. 1; minimum requirement for proof of financial responsibility by bond of a surety company, Minn. Stats. § 340A.409, subd. 1; minimum requirement for proof of financial responsibility by a certificate of the state treasurer, Minn. Stats. § 340A.409, subd. 1; no retail license may be issued, maintained, or renewed unless the applicant demonstrates proof of financial responsibility to meet liability imposed by Minn. Stats. § 340A.801. 
Sec. 4-102. - Exception. 
(a)	This division does not apply to on-sale 3.2 percent malt liquor licensees with sales of less than $25,000.00 for the preceding year, nor to off-sale 3.2 percent malt liquor licensees with sales of 3.2 percent malt liquor of less than $50,000.00 for the preceding year, nor to holders of on-sale wine licenses with sales of wine of less than $25,000.00 for the preceding year. An affidavit of the licensee shall be required to establish the exemption under this section. 
(b)	A liability insurance policy required by this section must provide that it may not be canceled for: 
(1)	Any cause, except for nonpayment of premium, by either the insured or the insurer unless the canceling party has first given 30 days' notice in writing to the issuing authority of intent to cancel the policy; and 
(2)	Nonpayment of premium unless the canceling party has first given ten days' notice in writing to the issuing authority of intent to cancel the policy. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.04; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.26, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Exceptions to insurance requirement, Minn. Stats. § 340A.409, subd. 4; requisite insurance cancellation provisions, Minn. Stats. § 340A.409, subd. 1. 
Sec. 4-103. - Documents submitted to commissioner. 
    All proofs of financial responsibility and exemption affidavits filed with the city under this section shall be submitted by the city to the state commissioner of public safety. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.04; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.26, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Requirement that issuing authority submit applicant's proof of financial responsibility to state commissioner of public safety, Minn. Stats. § 340A.409, subd. 1. 
Secs. 4-104-4-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 4-121. - Generally. 
(a)	Gambling. No gambling or gambling devices shall be permitted on any licensed premises except as provided by Minn. Stats. § 340A.410, subd. 5. 
(b)	Conformance. Every license shall be granted subject to the provisions of this article, all other applicable provisions of this chapter, and other claims relating to the operation of the licensee's business. 
(c)	Number issued. The council may issue the number of licenses authorized by statute or restrict such number from time to time as it may, in its discretion, deem proper. 
(d)	Duration. All licenses shall expire on December 31 each year unless otherwise specified. 
(e)	Location and premises. Unless a change in location has been approved by the city council or the commissioner of public safety, licenses shall be valid only at one location and on the premises described in an approved license application. 
(f)	Extension upon death of licensee. In the event of death of the licensee, his personal representative is authorized to continue operation of the business for not more than 90 days after the death of such licensee. 
(g)	Transfer. No license shall be transferable between persons or locations without the approval of the council. A license issued to a location at a racetrack licensed under Minn. Stats. ch. 240 may not be transferred. Where a license is held by a corporation, a change in ownership of ten percent or more of the stock of the corporation must be reported in writing to the authority who issued the license within ten days of the transfer. 
(h)	Corporate licensees. A corporate applicant, at the time of application, shall furnish the city with a list of all persons that have an interest in such corporation and the extent of such interest. The list shall name all shareholders holding more than five percent of all issued and outstanding stock of the corporation and show the number of shares held by each, either individually or beneficially for others. It is the duty of each corporate licensee to notify the city clerk of any change in legal ownership or beneficial interest in such corporation or in such shares. Any changes in the ownership or beneficial interest in the shares entitled to be voted at a meeting of the shareholders of a corporate licensee, which results in a change in ownership of ten percent or more of the stock or the change of voting control of the corporation by the persons owning the shares shall be deemed equivalent to a transfer of the license issued to the corporation; and any such license shall be revoked 30 days after any such change in ownership or beneficial interest of shares unless the council has been notified of the change in writing within ten days of the transfer and has approved it by appropriate action. The council or an officer of the city designated by it may at any reasonable time examine the stock transfer records and minute books of the corporate licensee in order to verify and identify the shareholders, and the council or its designated officer may examine the business records of any other licensee to the extent necessary to disclose the interest which persons other than the licensee have in the licensed business. The council may revoke any license issued upon its determination that a change of ownership of shares in a corporate licensee, or any change of ownership of any interest in the business, or any other licensee, has actually resulted in the change of control of the licensed business so as to materially affect the integrity and character of its management and its operation; but no such action shall be taken until after a hearing by the council on notice to the licensee conducted in accordance with Minn. Stats. §§ 14.57-14.62 and Minn. Rules §§ 1400.5100-1400.8400. 
(Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Within ten days of a change in ownership of ten percent or more of the corporate stock, corporate licensees must submit a written report of the transfer to the issuing authority, Minn. Stats. § 340A.412, subd. 9. 
Sec. 4-122. - Posting. 
    All licensees shall conspicuously post their licenses in their places of business. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.02, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- A retail alcoholic beverages license must be posted in a conspicuous place in the premises for which it is used, Minn. Stats. § 340A.410, subd. 4. 
Sec. 4-123. - Copy of summons. 
    Every application for the issuance or renewal of a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages must include a copy of each summons received by the applicant under Minn. Stats. § 340A.802, during the preceding year. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.04; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.26, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Requirement that all summons received by applicant under Minn. Stats. § 340A.802 during the preceding year accompany application for issuance or renewal of licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.410, subd. 8. 
Sec. 4-124. - Principal part of business. 
    A licensed restaurant shall be conducted in such a manner that the principal part of the business for a license year is the serving of foods. A hotel shall be conducted in such a manner that, of that part of the total business attributable to or derived from the serving of foods and intoxicating liquors, the principal part of the business for a license year is the serving of foods. "Principal part" shall mean 50 percent or more of the gross receipts. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.20, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to impose further restrictions and regulations on the sale and possession of alcoholic beverages within its limits, Minn. Stats. § 340A.509. 
Sec. 4-125. - Clubs; unlawful acts. 
    The following are in addition to all other unlawful acts set forth in this chapter relating to sales and purchases of 3.2 percent malt liquor or intoxicating liquor as the case may be: 
(1)	Club licenses shall be issued only to incorporated clubs or to congressionally chartered veterans organizations, either of which has been in existence for at least three years. 
(2)	It is unlawful for any club licensee to serve 3.2 percent malt liquor or liquor to any nonmember of the licensed club unless such nonmember is a guest. 
(3)	It is unlawful for any club licensee to hinder or prevent a police officer from determining compliance with this section and all other laws. It is unlawful for any person to refuse, upon request of a licensee or police officer, to provide information as to whether he or she is a member, guest, or host member or to give false, fraudulent or misleading information in response to such request. 
(Code 1989, § 1015.04; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.60, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Definition of "club," Minn. Stats. § 340A.101, subd. 7; requirement of at least three years of existence of a club seeking temporary on-sale licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.404, subd. 10. 
Sec. 4-126. - Council authority. 
    The council may, upon a finding of necessity, place such special conditions and restrictions, in addition to those stated in this article, upon any license as it, in its discretion, may deem reasonable and justified. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.10, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to impose further restrictions and regulations on the sale and possession of alcoholic beverages within its limits, Minn. Stats. § 340A.509. 
Secs. 4-127-4-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - 3.2 PERCENT MALT LIQUOR 

Sec. 4-151. - Malt liquor and 3.2 percent malt liquor license required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell or keep or offer for sale malt liquor and 3.2 percent malt liquor without a license from the city. This section shall not apply to sales by manufacturers to wholesalers or to sales by wholesalers to persons licensed by the city to sell on-sale or off-sale malt liquor and 3.2 percent malt liquor or intoxicating liquors, nor shall this section apply to sales to the public by persons licensed by the city to sell on-sale or off-sale intoxicating liquors. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.03; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.28, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to issue off-sale and on-sale licenses for sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor, Minn. Stats. § 340A.403, subd. 1; authority to license manufacturers and wholesalers of intoxicating liquor or 3.2 percent malt liquor is vested in the state commissioner of public safety, Minn. Stats. § 340A.301; persons possessing an on-sale or off-sale license to sell intoxicating liquor are exempt from the requirement of obtaining 3.2 percent malt liquor licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.403, subd. 3. 
Sec. 4-152. - Eligible establishments. 
    On-sale 3.2 percent malt liquor licenses shall be granted only to bona fide clubs, exclusive liquor stores, restaurants and motels or hotels. 
(Code 1989, §§ 1015-1020; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.32(5), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to issue 3.2 percent malt liquor licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.403, subd. 1. 
Sec. 4-153. - Temporary 3.2 percent malt liquor license. 
(a)	Applicant. A club or charitable, religious or nonprofit organization duly incorporated as a nonprofit or religious corporation under the laws of the state and having its registered office and principal place of activity within the city shall qualify for a temporary on-sale 3.2 percent malt liquor license for serving 3.2 percent malt liquor on and off school grounds and in and out of school buildings. 
(b)	Conditions. 
(1)	An application for a temporary license shall state the exact dates and place of proposed temporary sale. 
(2)	No applicant shall qualify for a temporary license for more than a total of seven days in any calendar year. 
(3)	The council may grant a temporary 3.2 percent malt liquor license on premises owned or controlled by the city, but at no time shall the council be under any obligation whatsoever to do so. Any such license may be conditioned, qualified or restricted as the council sees fit. If the premises to be licensed are owned or under the control of the city, the applicant shall file with the city, prior to issuance of the license, a certificate of liability insurance coverage in at least the sum of $100,000.00 for injury to any one person and $100,000.00 for injury to more than one person, naming the city as an insured during the license period. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.30, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to issue and set terms of temporary 3.2 percent malt liquor on-sale licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.403, subd. 2(a), (c); temporary 3.2 percent malt liquor on-sale licenses may authorize the sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor in any school or school building, Minn. Stats. § 340A.403, subd. 2(b). 
Secs. 4-154-4-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - INTOXICATING LIQUOR 

Sec. 4-171. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)	It is unlawful for any person to sell or keep or offer for sale any intoxicating liquor without a license from the city. 
(b)	This division shall not apply to: 
(1)	Possession or handling for sale or otherwise of sacramental wine or to any representative of any religious order or for use in connection with a legitimate religious ceremony; 
(2)	Such potable liquors as are prescribed by licensed physicians and dentists for therapeutic purposes; 
(3)	Industrial alcohol and its compounds not prepared or used for beverage purposes; 
(4)	Wine in the possession of a person duly licensed under this article as an on-sale wine licensee; or 
(5)	Sales by manufacturers to wholesalers duly licensed as such by the state and to sales by wholesalers to persons holding on-sale or off-sale licenses from the city. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.03; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.38, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Intoxicating liquor on-sale licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.404. 
Sec. 4-172. - Sunday license. 
    An establishment serving intoxicating liquor on Sundays must obtain a Sunday license. 
(Code 1989, §§ 1000.03(3), 1000.04(3), 1000.06(6), 1000.07(2), 1000.08(14), 1000.09(2), (3); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.44, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Establishment serving intoxicating liquor on Sundays must obtain a one-year license, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504, subd. 3(c). 
Sec. 4-173. - Sports or convention facilities. 
    The council may authorize any holder of a retail on-sale intoxicating liquor license issued by the city or by an adjacent municipality to sell intoxicating liquor at any convention, banquet, conference, meeting or social affair conducted on the premises of a sports or convention facility owned by the city or an instrumentality of the city having independent policy-making and appropriating authority and located within the city. The licensee must be engaged to sell intoxicating liquor at such an event by the person or organization permitted to use the premises and may sell intoxicating liquor only to persons attending the event. The licensee shall not sell intoxicating liquor to any person attending or participating in any amateur athletic event. Such sales may be limited to designated areas of the facility. All such sales shall be subject to all related laws. 
(Code 1989, ch. X; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.48, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Power to authorize a retail on-sale intoxicating liquor license to dispense intoxicating liquor at any event conducted on the premises of a sports, convention or cultural facility, Minn. Stats. § 340A.404, subd. 4(a). 
Sec. 4-174. - Nonprofit organization temporary license. 
    The council may issue to a club or charitable, religious or other nonprofit organization in existence for at least three years, a temporary license for the on-sale of intoxicating liquor in connection with a social event held within the city and sponsored by the licensee. The license may authorize the on-sale of intoxicating liquor for not more than three consecutive days and may authorize on-sale on premises other than premises the licensee owns or permanently occupies. The license may provide that the licensee may contract for intoxicating liquor catering services with the holder of a full-year on-sale intoxicating liquor license issued by the city. Temporary licenses are subject to all laws and ordinances governing the sale of intoxicating liquor except those relating to insurance required by state law and/or city ordinance (but not those requiring the furnishing of a bond as provided by law), except those are not valid unless first approved by the state commissioner of public safety. 
(Code 1989, § 1015; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.50, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Temporary on-sale licenses, Minn. Stats. § 340A.404, subd. 10. 
Sec. 4-175. - Restrictions. 
    On-sale intoxicating liquor licenses shall be granted only to the following kinds of establishments: 
(1)	Hotels; 
(2)	Restaurants; 
(3)	Bowling centers; 
(4)	Clubs or congressionally chartered veterans organizations with the approval of the state commissioner of public safety provided the organization has been in existence for at least three years and liquor sales will only be to members and bona fide guests; 
(5)	Sports facilities located on land owned by the metropolitan sports commission; and 
(6)	Exclusive liquor stores. 
(Code 1989, §§ 1015-1020; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.40(9), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Kinds of establishments to which an on-sale intoxicating liquor license may be issued, Minn. Stats. § 340A.404, subd. 1. 
Secs. 4-176-4-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - WINE 

Sec. 4-201. - Required; exceptions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell or keep or offer for sale any wine without a license from the city. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)	Possession or handling for sale or otherwise of sacramental wine or to any representative of any religious order or for use in connection with a legitimate religious ceremony; 
(2)	Sales by manufacturers to wholesalers duly licensed as such by the state; 
(3)	Sales by wholesalers to persons holding on-sale or off-sale liquor licenses from the city; or 
(4)	Sales by wholesalers by persons holding on-sale wine licenses from the city. 
(Code 1989, § 1020.03; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.52, 9-6-1994) 
Sec. 4-202. - Sales of food. 
    The holder of an on-sale wine license who is also licensed to sell 3.2 percent malt liquor at on-sale pursuant to section 4-151 and whose gross receipts are at least 60 percent attributable to the sale of food may sell intoxicating malt liquors at on-sale without an additional license. 
(Code 1989, § 1020.03; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.52, 9-6-1994) 
Sec. 4-203. - Restrictions. 
(a)	Restaurants applying for an on-sale wine license must have facilities for seating at least 25 guests at one time. 
(b)	On-sale wine licenses shall be granted only to restaurants. 
(c)	On-sale wine licensees shall sell wine only for consumption with the sale of food. 
(Code 1989, § 1020.06; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.58(13), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- A wine license permits the sale of wine of up to 14 percent alcohol by volume for consumption with the sale of food, Minn. Stats. § 340A.404, subd. 5(a). 
Secs. 4-204-4-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALES REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-231. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)	Consumption. It is unlawful for any person to consume or any licensee to permit consumption of 3.2 percent malt liquor, wine or intoxicating liquor on licensed premises more than 20 minutes after the hour when a sale can be legally made. 
(b)	Consumption in public places. No person shall consume intoxicating liquor or 3.2 percent malt liquor on a public highway or public place. 
(c)	Removal of containers. It is unlawful for any on-sale licensee to permit any glass, bottle or other container containing 3.2 percent malt liquor, wine or intoxicating liquor in any quantity to remain upon any table, bar, stool or other place where customers are served more than 20 minutes after the hour when a sale can legally be made. 
(d)	Closing. It is unlawful for any person other than an on-sale licensee's bona fide employee actually engaged in the performance of his duties to be on the premises licensed under this chapter more than 30 minutes after the legal time for making licensed sales; however, this subsection shall not apply to licensees, employees of licensees, and patrons on licensed premises for the sole purpose of preparing, serving or consuming food or beverages other than 3.2 percent malt liquor, wine or intoxicating liquor. 
(e)	Lewd or indecent conduct prohibited. No lewd or indecent conduct shall be allowed or permitted on the licensed premises. For the purposes of this subsection, lewd or indecent conduct shall include nudity and sexual conduct as those terms are defined in Minn. Stats. § 617.292. Any licensee providing live entertainment or dancing must conduct that activity entirely with the licensed premises. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.14, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Hours and days of sale, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504; authority to further limit the hours of sale of alcoholic beverages, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504; authority to retain and punish persons guilty of lewd conduct, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 26. 
Sec. 4-232. - Conduct on licensed premises. 
    Except as otherwise provided, every licensee under this article shall be responsible for the conduct of his place of business and shall maintain conditions of sobriety and order in the place of business. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08(1); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.16, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Responsibility of licensee for conduct in the licensed establishment, Minn. Stats. § 340A.501. 
Sec. 4-233. - Sale by employee. 
    Any sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor, wine or intoxicating liquor in or from any premises licensed under this chapter by any employee authorized to make such sale in or from such place is the act of the employer as well as the person actually making the sale; and every such employer is liable to all of the penalties provided by law for such sale, equally with the person actually making the sale. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.18, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Responsibility of licensee for any sale of alcoholic beverages by an employee, Minn. Stats. § 340A.501. 
Sec. 4-234. - Inspection. 
(a)	All premises licensed under this chapter shall at all times be open to inspection by any police officer to determine whether or not this chapter and all other laws are being observed. All persons, as a condition to being issued such license, consent to such inspection by such officers and without a warrant for searches or seizures. 
(b)	It is unlawful for any licensee or agent or employee of a licensee to hinder or prevent a police officer from making such inspection. 
(Code 1989, § 1020.09; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.22, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to inspect the premises and examine the books, papers, and records of a retailer to ascertain compliance with Minn. Stats. ch. 340A, Minn. Stats. § 340A.907. 
Sec. 4-235. - Application for, possession of federal stamp prohibited. 
    No retail licensee or municipal liquor store shall apply for or have in possession a federal wholesale liquor dealer's tax stamp. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08(6); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.32(2), 9-6-1994) 
Sec. 4-236. - Employment of underage persons. 
    No person under 18 years of age shall be employed to sell or serve alcoholic beverages in any licensed establishment. 
(Code 1989, §§ 1000.08(3), 1020.04(4); Ord. No. 216, §§ 1000.32(4), 1000.40(5), 1000.54(5), 9-6-1994) 
Sec. 4-237. - Use of refilled bottles prohibited. 
    No licensee shall sell, offer for sale or keep for sale alcoholic beverages in a package or bottle which has been refilled or partly refilled. 
(Code 1989, ch. X; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.40(6), 9-6-1994) 
Sec. 4-238. - Sales to intoxicated persons prohibited. 
    No person may sell, give, furnish or in any way procure for another alcoholic beverages for the use of an obviously intoxicated person. 
(Code 1989, §§ 1010.02, 1015.04(1), 1020.06; Ord. No. 216, §§ 1000.46(9), 1000.58(8), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Sales to obviously intoxicated persons prohibited, Minn. Stats. § 340A.502. 
Sec. 4-239. - Hours and days of sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any: 
(1)	Licensee to sell alcoholic beverages on any day or during any hour when such sales are prohibited by this article or any other law. 
(2)	Person to purchase any alcoholic beverages on any day or during any hour when such sales are not permitted by law. 
(Code 1989, §§ 1000.09, 1020.06; Ord. No. 216, §§ 1000.36(13), 1000.46(7), 1000.58(7), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Hours and days of sale, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504. 
Sec. 4-240. - Underage persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any: 
(1)	Person, other than a parent or legal guardian, to procure alcoholic beverages for any person under 21 years of age. 
(2)	Person to induce a person under the age of 21 years to purchase or procure any alcoholic beverage. 
(3)	Person to lend or knowingly permit the use of the person's driver's license, permit, state identification card, or other form of identification by a person under the age of 21 years for the purpose of purchasing or attempting to purchase an alcoholic beverage. 
(4)	Person to sell, barter, furnish or give alcoholic beverages to a person under 21 years of age. 
(5)	Person under 21 years of age to misrepresent his age by claiming to be 21 years of age or older for the purpose of purchasing alcoholic beverages. 
(6)	Person under age 21 to consume any alcoholic beverage unless in the household of his parent or guardian and with the consent of the parent or guardian. 
(7)	Person under the age of 21 years to possess any alcoholic beverage with the intent to consume it at a place other than the household of his parent or guardian. Possession at a place other than the household of the parent or guardian creates a rebuttable presumption of intent to consume it at a place other than the household of the parent or guardian. 
(8)	Retail alcoholic beverages licensee to permit any person under the age of 21 years to drink alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises. 
(9)	Retail alcoholic beverages licensee to permit any person under 21 years of age to be upon a licensed premises except a restaurant, hotel or motel, and then only if accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(10)	Retail alcoholic beverages licensee to fail, where doubt could exist, to require adequate proof of age of a person upon licensed premises. Proof of age for purchasing or consuming alcoholic beverages may be established only by one of the following: 
a.	A valid driver's license or identification card issued by this or another state, or a province of Canada, and including the photograph and date of birth of the licensed person; 
b.	A valid military identification card issued by the United States Department of Defense; or 
c.	In the case of a foreign national, from a nation other than Canada, by a valid passport. 
(11)	Person under the age of 21 years to purchase or attempt to purchase any alcoholic beverage unless under the supervision of a responsible person over the age of 21 for training, education or research purposes. 
(12)	Person under the age of 21 years to enter an establishment licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages for the purpose of purchasing or having served or delivered any alcoholic beverage. 
(Code 1989, §§ 1000.08(3), 1020.06; Ord. No. 216, §§ 1000.46(4), 1000.58(4), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Unlawful possession of alcoholic beverages by persons under 21, Minn. Stats. § 340A.503, subd. 3; persons under 21, illegal acts of purchasing, Minn. Stats. § 340A.503, subd. 2(2), (3); inducement of a person under 21 to purchase or procure any alcoholic beverage is unlawful, Minn. Stats. § 340A.503, subd. 2(3). 
Secs. 4-241-4-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - 3.2 PERCENT MALT LIQUOR 

Sec. 4-261. - Hours and days of sale. 
(a)	No sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor may be made between 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on the days of Monday through Saturday nor 1:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sunday. 
(b)	An establishment located on land owned by the metropolitan sports commission, or a sports arena for which one or more licenses have been issued under Minn. Stats. § 340A.404, subd. 2, par. (c), may sell 3.2 percent malt liquor between 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon on a Sunday on which a sports or other event is scheduled to begin at that location on or before 1:00 p.m. of that day. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.09; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.34, 9-6-1994; Ord. No. 95-9-1, § 2, 9-5-1995) 
State Law reference- Hours and days of sale of 3.2 percent malt liquor, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504, subd. 1. 
Sec. 4-262. - Prohibited consumption. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to allow consumption of 3.2 percent malt liquor on licensed premises on any day or during any hour when sales of 3.2 percent malt liquor are prohibited. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.08(2); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.36(12), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to impose further restrictions and regulations on the sale and possession of alcoholic beverages, Minn. Stats. § 340A.509. 
Secs. 4-263-4-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INTOXICATING LIQUOR 

Sec. 4-281. - Hours and days of sale. 
(a)	Except as provided in section 4-172 no sale of intoxicating liquor for consumption on the licensed premises may be made: 
(1)	Between 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on the days of Monday through Saturday; or 
(2)	After 1:00 a.m. on Sundays, except as provided by Minn. Stats. § 340A.504, subd. 3. 
(b)	No on-sale liquor establishment shall display any intoxicating liquor when open to the public during hours when the sale of such liquor is prohibited by law. 
(c)	Additionally, no sale of intoxicating liquor may be made by an off-sale licensee: 
(1)	On Sundays; 
(2)	Before 8:00 a.m. on Monday through Saturday; 
(3)	After 8:00 p.m. on Monday through Thursday and after 10:00 p.m. on Friday and Saturday, provided that an establishment may sell intoxicating liquor until 10:00 p.m. on December 31, and July 3 and on the day preceding Thanksgiving Day, unless it is on a Sunday; 
(4)	On Thanksgiving Day; 
(5)	On Christmas Day, December 25; or 
(6)	After 8:00 p.m. on Christmas Eve, December 24. 
(Code 1989, § 1000.09; Ord. No. 95-9-1, § 2, 9-5-1995) 
State Law reference- Hours and days of sale for on-sale intoxicating liquor, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504, subds. 2, 4. 
Sec. 4-282. - Sunday sales. 
    Upon one public hearing, the council may, by ordinance, permit sales of intoxicating liquor for consumption, in conjunction with the sale of food, on the premises by hotels, motels, restaurants, bowling centers, or clubs which have on-sale licenses and which also have facilities for serving not less than 30 guests at one time, between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on Sundays and 1:00 a.m. on Mondays provided the licensee is in conformance with the Minnesota Clean Air Act. 
(Code 1989, §§ 1000.03(3), 1000.04(3), 1000.06(6), 1000.07(2), 1000.08(14), 1000.09(2), (3); Ord. No. 216, § 1000.44, 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Intoxicating liquor Sunday sales on-sale, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504, subd. 3(b), (c). 
Secs. 4-283-4-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - WINE 

Sec. 4-301. - Hours and days of sales of wine by on-sale wine licensees. 
(a)	The hours and days of sales of wine by on-sale wine licensees shall be in conformance with section 4-281, except that a special Sunday license is not required for sales by wine licensees. 
(b)	No on-sale liquor establishment shall display any intoxicating liquor when open to the public during hours when the sale of such liquor is prohibited by law. 
(Code 1989, § 1020.05; Ord. No. 216, § 1000.54(6), 9-6-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to further limit hours of sale of alcoholic beverages, Minn. Stats. § 340A.504, subd. 6; display of intoxicating liquor is forbidden during hours when sale of intoxicating liquor is prohibited, Minn. Rules § 7515.0560, subp. 3. 
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Environment, ch. 16. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, Minn. Stats. ch. 347; authority to regulate the keeping, running at large, impounding, sale or summary destruction of animals, to establish pounds, and to license and regulate riding academies, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 21. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dog means an animal of canine species, regardless of sex, owned, kept or harbored within the city. 
    Dog, female, means any dog of the female gender on which no alterative surgery of the genital organs has been performed. 
    Dog, male, means any dog of masculine gender, either castrated or not castrated. 
    Dog, spayed female, means any female dog on which an ovarectomy or ovarohisterectomy has been performed by a licensed veterinarian and accompanied by a certificate asserting that the operation has been performed. 
    Owner means any person, excepting the operator of a commercial kennel or dog hospital, who owns, keeps or harbors a dog within the city. 
    Stray means any dog without license found attached or loose anywhere within the city limits. 
(Code 1989, § 600.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 6-32-6-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license dogs, Minn. Stats. §§ 347.08, subd. 1, 347.21. 

Sec. 6-51. - Required. 
    No dog over the age of six months of age shall be owned, kept or harbored within the city unless a current license for the dog has been obtained. Licenses shall be issued every two years. A $2.00 late payment charge shall be assessed for failure to purchase a license as required in this section within the time provided. The payment of such penalty for a late purchase shall be in addition to any other penalties provided by law. 
(Code 1989, § 600.02) 
State Law reference- An owner who permits a dog to be uncontrolled off the owner's premises shall have the dog identified, Minn. Stats. § 346.50; implied authority to regulate dangerous dogs, Minn. Stats. § 347.51, subd. 8; authority to regulate potentially dangerous dogs, Minn. Stats. § 347.53. 
Sec. 6-52. - License fees. 
    The fees for a license required in this division shall be set from time to time by the council. Application for such license must be accompanied by a certificate of inoculation for rabies which is not more than two years old. Upon receipt of the license fee and the certificate of inoculation, the clerk shall execute a receipt in duplicate, the original of which shall be given to the person who pays the fees; the duplicate shall be retained in the records of the city. This receipt shall describe the dog as to color, breed, age and sex. Any owner shall produce for inspection the permit receipt upon the request of the police department or community service officer. A summary of dog licenses issued shall be given to the police department. 
(Code 1989, § 600.02(1)) 
Sec. 6-53. - Collar and tag. 
    The owner shall also place upon the neck of every dog a collar made of durable material having attached the metal or plastic license tag to be furnished by the city clerk upon payment of the license fee. The number of such tag shall correspond with the number of the license issued to the owner. The collar with the tag attached shall be kept on each dog at all times. 
(Code 1989, § 600.02(2)) 
State Law reference- The licensee shall securely attach the tag to a collar, which shall at all times be kept on the dog for which the license is issued, Minn. Stats. § 347.11, subd. 2. 
Sec. 6-54. - Puppies. 
    All puppies shall have the required rabies vaccinations before becoming six months of age. 
(Code 1989, § 600.02(3)) 
Sec. 6-55. - Prorating license fees. 
    The owner of any dog brought into the city after January 1 of any year shall immediately procure a license for such animal as provided in this division. When licenses are issued for less than a full year, annual license fees shall be prorated accordingly. 
(Code 1989, § 600.03) 
Sec. 6-56. - License tag. 
    A metal or plastic license tag will be furnished by the city clerk upon receipt of the required fee. A duplicate license tag to replace lost or stolen tags shall be issued by the city clerk upon payment of the fee which shall be set by the council from time to time. 
(Code 1989, § 600.04) 
Secs. 6-57-6-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 6-81. - Impoundment. 
(a)	Adequate provision shall be made by the city to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)	Each stray dog picked up, if healthy, shall be impounded for not less than five days, not including the day of pickup. After such period, if not claimed by the owner, the dog may be destroyed or otherwise disposed of. No dog claimed by its owner shall be released until the board and pound charges are paid. Pound and board fees shall be fixed from time to time by the city council. 
(c)	Any person, not an officer of the city, may seize or pick up any dog running at large on his premises or the premises occupied by him but shall not keep the dog any longer than six hours without notifying the ploice department or surrendering it to the owner. If not surrendered to the owner, the dog so seized shall be impounded and handled in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)	Whenever a dog is picked up by the police department or community service officer and such dog has an identification tag or license, the owner shall be notified immediately. Any dog not claimed by the registered owner within five days may be disposed of in accordance with Minn. Stats. § 35.71. Before any dog is released, the owner shall pay in addition to any other penalties and the kennel charges the following: 
(1)	First offense in one-year period ..... $25.00 
(2)	Second offense in one-year period ..... 35.00 
(3)	Third offense in one-year period ..... 50.00 
(Code 1989, § 600.05(4); Ord. No. 600, § 1, 4-6-1999) 
State Law reference- No person shall abandon an animal, either permanently or temporarily, Minn. Stats. § 343.21, subds. 5, 6. 
Sec. 6-82. - Reports by poundkeeper. 
    The poundkeeper shall account for and pay over to the city each month all moneys received pursuant to this division. The poundkeeper shall also give an accurate written report for each month to the city showing all fees collected, all sales made, all dogs impounded and the duration of the impoundment, or otherwise disposed of under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1989, § 600.14) 
Secs. 6-83-6-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - LEASHING 

Sec. 6-101. - Parks, custodial duties. 
(a)	The provisions of this division shall not apply to guide or service dogs accompanying blind or disabled persons; or to a dog when used in police or rescue activities. 
(b)	A dog is restrained if the dog is: 
(1)	In a secure vehicle; 
(2)	Within a secure fence or building; 
(3)	Picketed by means of a chain or cable to a secure, fixed object, thereby confining the dog to a specified area; 
(4)	Involved in a scheduled dog show or obedience demonstration or trial; or 
(5)	Legally involved in tracking, or hunting and retrieving game animals. 
(c)	No person having custody or control of any dog shall permit: 
(1)	The dog to be on any unfenced area or lot abutting a street, public park, schoolground, public place or upon any private land in the city without being restrained so that it does not enter beyond such area or lot; 
(2)	The dog at any time to be on any street, public park, schoolground or public place in the city without being restrained or secured by a chain or leash not exceeding six feet in length; 
(3)	The dog to be in any public park area not marked with city "Pet Area" signs; 
(4)	The dog to be in any public park area marked with city "Pet Area" signs without being either restrained or secured by a chain or leash not exceeding six feet in length; or 
(5)	Any dog declared to be a nuisance to be in any public park area marked with city "Pet Area" signs, whether restrained or not. 
(d)	Any person having custody or control of any dog shall remove the feces of the dog over which he has custody or control, deposited upon any street, public park (including designated pet areas), schoolground or public place in the city and shall dispose of the feces in city waste receptacles or shall otherwise properly dispose of the feces in accord with city solid waste regulations. 
(e)	Any person having control or custody over a dog while the dog is off the owner's or custodian's private property shall have in their possession suitable equipment for pickup, removal and sanitary disposal of feces. 
(Code 1989, § 600.06; Ord. No. 600, § 1, 4-6-1999) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Authority of cities to prohibit, license or regulate the running at large of dogs within their respective limits, Minn. Stats. § 347.21. 
Secs. 6-102-6-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - NUISANCE DOG[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Public nuisances, § 16-31 et seq. 

Sec. 6-121. - Abatement required. 
(a)	The owner or keeper of any dog found within the city that shall be a nuisance shall, upon notification by any individual authorized by this city, abate such nuisance; and if such owner or keeper fails to abate such nuisance, the authorized individual may impound the dog and destroy it. Any owner or keeper of a dog after having been given notice of such nuisance who fails to abate the nuisance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)	The council declares to be a nuisance any dog that: 
(1)	Continually barks, howls or otherwise creates a disturbance and annoys any neighborhood. 
(2)	Has bitten or attacked a person off the premises of the owner or keeper. 
(3)	Has destroyed property or other animals or habitually trespasses in a damaging manner on the property of a person other than the owner or keeper. 
(4)	Is vicious, shows vicious propensities, molests pedestrians, or interferes with vehicular traffic on the public walks, highways or streets within the city. 
(5)	Travels beyond the boundaries of public park pet areas two or more times. 
(Code 1989, § 600.07(1)(c), (1)(d); Ord. No. 600, § 1, 4-6-1999) 
Sec. 6-122. - Statutes adopted by reference. 
    The provisions of Minn. Stats. §§ 35.67, 35.68 and 35.69 are adopted by reference and are incorporated in and made a part of this division as completely as if they were set down here in full. 
(Code 1989, § 600.15) 
State Law reference- Animal health, Minn. Stats. ch. 35. 
Sec. 6-123. - Dogs which have bitten and are suspected of having rabies. 
    Dogs which have bitten persons or other animals and which are suspected of having rabies shall be kept in a suitable authorized place under veterinary supervision for not less than 14 days and released only on authority of the veterinarian. 
(Code 1989, § 600.08) 
Sec. 6-124. - Dogs known to have been bitten or exposed to rabid animal. 
    Dogs known to have been bitten or exposed to a rabid animal must be destroyed or detained in a suitable quarantine for a period of not less than six months, unless proof of immunization is shown and booster injections are given by a licensed veterinarian at the dog owner's expense. 
(Code 1989, § 600.09) 
Sec. 6-125. - Rabid animals shall be reported to proper authorities. 
    Rabies in animals is declared a portable disease and upon recognition shall be reported to the health officer of the city, who in turn shall report the facts to the state department of health. 
(Code 1989, § 600.10) 
Sec. 6-126. - Transient dog. 
    A transient dog need not be licensed if it is in the city less than 45 days, confined in a suitable enclosure or maintained on a leash and accompanied by a health and rabies vaccination certificate. 
(Code 1989, § 600.11) 
Secs. 6-127-6-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - KENNELS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- No person shall establish, maintain, conduct or operate a kennel without obtaining a license from the board of animal health, Minn. Stats. § 347.32. 

Sec. 6-151. - Permits. 
(a)	No person shall operate a commercial kennel in this city without first obtaining a permit. Application for such permit shall be made to the city clerk and shall be accompanied by the permit fee. The clerk shall refer the application to the council who may grant or deny the permit. 
(b)	Permits shall be issued on an annual basis, expiring on December 31 following the first effective day of the kennel permit. The animal kennel permit fee per year or any fraction of a year shall be set by the council from time to time. 
(c)	Kennels shall be kept in a clean and healthful condition at all times and shall be open for inspection by the city authorities at any time. A kennel permit may be revoked by the council by reason of the violation of this section or any health or nuisance order, laws or regulations. 
(d)	Special permits for the keeping of more than two dogs over six months of age may be issued by the council under circumstances not amounting to the operation of a kennel when the council deems that the issuance of such special permit is justified and that such issuance shall not defeat the spirit and intent of this section. This section does not apply to the premises of a duly licensed veterinarian. 
(Code 1989, § 600.12) 
Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:
