State Law reference- Authority to regulate the construction of buildings, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 28. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 8-1-8-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- The Minnesota State Building Code applies statewide and supersedes the building code of any municipality, Minn. Stats. § 16B.62, subd. 1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-31. - Adopted. 
    The state building code, established pursuant to Minn. Stats. §§ 16B.59-16B.75, is adopted as the building code for the city. The code is incorporated in this article as if fully set out in this section. 
(Code 1989, § 400.01(1); Ord. No. 400.01, § 4, 6-20-1995; Ord. No. 400.02, § 4, 7-20-1999) 
Sec. 8-32. - Inclusion of state provisions. 
(a)	Chapters of the Minnesota Rules relevant to the state building code include the following: 
(1)	Administration of the state building code: 
a.	1300 Building code administration. 
b.	1301 Building official certification. 
c.	1302 Construction approvals. 
d.	1305 Amendments to the current edition of the Uniform Building Code. 
1.	Appendices required, Minn. Rules § 1305.0020, subp. 1: 
i.	Chapter 3, division I; 
ii.	Chapter 12, division II; 
iii.	Chapter 15; 
iv.	Chapter 16, division I; 
v.	Chapter 29; and 
vi.	Chapter 31, division II. 
2.	Optional appendices, Minn. Rules § 1305.0020, subp. 2: 
i.	Chapter 3, division III; and 
ii.	Chapter 33. 
e.	1307 Elevators and related devices. 
(2)	The state building code: 
a.	1315 Electrical code. 
b.	1325 Energy. 
c.	1330 Fallout shelters. 
d.	1335 Floodproofing. 
e.	1341 Accessibility for buildings and facilities. 
f.	1346 Uniform mechanical code. 
g.	1350 Manufactured homes. 
h.	1360 Prefabricated buildings. 
i.	1361 Industrialized/modular buildings. 
j.	1370 Storm shelters (manufactured home parks). 
k.	7670 State energy code. 
(b)	The city may adopt by reference any or all of the following optional appendix chapters of the current edition of the Uniform Building Code as authorized by Minn. Rules § 1305.0020 subp. 2: 3, Use or Occupancy, division III, Requirements for Group R, Division 3 Occupancies and 33, Excavation and Grading. The following optional appendix chapters of the current edition of the Uniform Building Code are adopted and incorporated as part of the building code for the city. 
(1)	Use or Occupancy, division III, Requirements for Group R, Division 3 Occupancies. 
(2)	33, Excavation and Grading. 
(c)	The city may adopt by reference any or all of the following optional chapters of Minn. Rules: 1306, Special Fire Protection Systems, option 8, Sprinkler System Requirements (Group M (Mercantile), S (Storage), or F (Factory) occupancies with 2,000 or more gross square feet of floor area or three or more stories in height) or 8a, Sprinkler System Requirements (Group M (Mercantile), S (Storage), or F (Factory) occupancies with 5,000 or more gross square feet); and 1335, Floodproofing Regulations §§ 1335.0600-1335.1200. 
(d)	The following optional chapters of Minn. Rules are adopted and incorporated as part of the building code for this city: 
(1)	1306, Option 8, Group M, S or F occupancies with 2,000 or more gross square feet. 
(2)	1335, Floodproofing Regulations §§ 1335.0600-1335.1200. 
(Code 1989, § 400.01(1b); Ord. No. 400.01, § 4, 6-20-1995; Ord. No. 400.02, § 4, 7-20-1999) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt and enforce the state building code, Minn. Stats. § 16B.62, subd. 1; authority to adopt appendix chapters 3, division III, and 33 and to adopt a revised fee schedule and bond requirements with appendix chapter 33, Minn. Rules § 1305.0020, subp. 2; optional administration, Minn. Rules § 1300.2900. 
Secs. 8-33-8-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 8-51. - Application, administration and enforcement. 
(a)	The application, administration and enforcement of the Long Lake Building Code (CODE) shall be in accordance with the Minnesota State Building Code (MSBC), Minn. Rules § 1300.2100 et seq. and Minn. Rules ch. 1305. The code shall be enforced within the extraterritorial limits permitted by Minn. Stats. § 16B.62, subd. 1, when so established by this article. 
(b)	The code enforcement agency of the city is called the building official, certified by the state commissioner of administration and appointed by the city council, Minn. Stats. § 16B.65. 
(Code 1989, § 400.01(2); Ord. No. 400.01, § 1, 6-20-1995; Ord. No. 400.02, § 1, 7-20-1999) 
State Law reference- Exemptions from applicability of the Minnesota Building Code, Minn. Stats. §§ 16B.72, 16B.73. 
Sec. 8-52. - Permits and fees. 
(a)	The issuance of permits and the collection of fees shall be as authorized in Minn. Stats. § 16B.62, subd. 1, and as provided for in sections 106 and 107 of the current edition of the Uniform Building Code and Minn. Rules §§ 1305.0106, 1305.0107. 
(b)	Permit fees shall be assessed for work governed by this article in accordance with table no. 1-A. In addition, a surcharge fee shall be collected on all permits issued for work governed by this article in accordance with Minn. Stats. § 16B.70 and Minn. Rules § 1300.2700. 
(Code 1989, § 400.01(2a); Ord. No. 400.01, § 2, 6-20-1995; Ord. No. 400.02, § 2, 7-20-1999) 
Sec. 8-53. - Violations and penalties. 
    A violation of this article is a misdemeanor (Minn. Stats. § 16B.69). 
(Code 1989, § 400.01(2b); Ord. No. 400.01, § 3, 6-20-1995; Ord. No. 400.02, § 3, 7-20-1999) 
Secs. 8-54-8-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY 

Sec. 8-71. - Required. 
(a)	A certificate of occupancy must be obtained before: 
(1)	Any vacant land is occupied or used; 
(2)	Any building erected or altered in such manner as to require a building permit is occupied or used; or 
(3)	The use of any building or existing building is altered. 
(b)	Issuance of a certificate of occupancy shall not be construed as an approval of a violation of the provisions of this article or of other ordinances of the city. Certificates presuming to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this article or other ordinances of the city shall not be valid. 
(Code 1989, § 400.02(1)) 
Sec. 8-72. - Application and issuance. 
(a)	Application for a certificate of occupancy for a new building or for an existing building which has been structurally altered shall be made to the building official as part of the application for a building permit for such new building or alteration of existing building. The certificate shall be issued by the building official within ten days after the erection or alteration of such building or a part of the building has been completed in conformity with the provisions of the state building code and this article. Proof of completion in conformity with the state building code and this article shall be submitted to the building official prior to issuance of the certificate. Such proof shall be in written form, shall be subscribed by the city building official and all state building inspectors, whose inspection is required, and shall state: 
(1)	The building permit number. 
(2)	The address of the building. 
(3)	The name and address of the owner. 
(4)	A description of that portion of the building for which the certificate is issued. 
(5)	A statement that the described portion of the building has been inspected for compliance with the requirements of this article for the group and division of occupancy and the use for which the proposed occupancy is classified. 
(6)	The name of the building official. 
(b)	Pending the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, if the building official finds that no substantial hazard will result from occupancy of any building or portion before it is completed, a temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued, for a period not to exceed six months, for the use of a portion of a building or structure prior to the completion of the entire building or structure. Application for a temporary certificate of occupancy must be submitted to the building official. The temporary certificate shall not be construed as altering the respective rights, duties or obligations of the owner or the city relating to the use or occupancy of the premises, or any other matter, except under such restrictions and provisions as will adequately ensure the safety of the occupants. 
(c)	The certificate of occupancy shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises and shall not be removed except by the building official. 
(Code 1989, § 400.02(2)) 
Sec. 8-73. - Vacant land. 
    Written application for a certificate of occupancy for the use of vacant land or for a change in the character of the use of land as provided in this division shall be made before any such land shall be so occupied and used. Such a certificate of occupancy shall be issued within three days after the application has been made if the use is in conformity with the provisions of this section. Proof of completion in conformity with the state building code and this section shall be submitted to the city administrator prior to issuance of the certificate. Such proof shall be in written form, shall be subscribed by the city building official and all state building inspectors, whose inspection is required, and shall state: 
(1)	The building permit number. 
(2)	The address of the building. 
(3)	The name and address of the owner. 
(4)	A description of that portion of the building for which the certificate is issued. 
(5)	A statement that the described portion of the building has been inspected for compliance with the requirements of this article for the group and division of occupancy and the use for which the proposed occupancy is classified. 
(6)	The name of the building official. 
(Code 1989, § 400.02(3)) 
Sec. 8-74. - Content, record and fee. 
(a)	Every certificate of occupancy shall state that the building or proposed use of a building or land complies with all provisions of law and this division. A record of all certificates of occupancy shall be kept on file in the office of the city administrator, and copies shall be furnished on request to any person having a proprietary or tenancy interest in the building or the land affected. No fee shall be charged for a certificate of occupancy. 
(b)	No building permit for the erection or alteration of a building shall be issued before an application has been made for a certificate of occupancy. 
(Code 1989, § 400.02(4)) 
Sec. 8-75. - Building code certificates. 
    When a certificate is required under the state building code, it shall serve also as the certificate required under this division; and the application and certificate forms may be altered accordingly. 
(Code 1989, § 400.02(5)) 
Sec. 8-76. - Revocation. 
    The building official may, in writing, suspend or revoke a certificate of occupancy issued under the provisions of this article whenever the certificate is issued in error, or on the basis of incorrect information supplied, or when it is determined that the building or structure or portion is in violation of any ordinance or regulation or any of the provisions of this article. 
Sec. 8-77. - Enforcement, penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this division is guilty of a misdemeanor; and any condition created by such violation is subject to abatement and removal by such equitable and/or legal proceedings, including proceedings for injunctive relief and money damages as the city shall undertake. 
(Code 1989, § 400.03) 
Secs. 8-78-8-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NUMBERING OF HOUSES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to number or renumber lots and blocks or any part thereof, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 18. 

Sec. 8-111. - Duty of owner or occupant. 
    The owner or occupant of every house or other building (except barns, garages and other buildings which are part of the same property with a numbered house or building) shall place on such building (or on a mailbox or a signpost clearly identified with such building or at the front door) the proper street number for such building by affixing such number so that the number shall be clearly visible from the sidewalk or street. The fire department recommends five-inch letters on contrasting background for residential or commercial buildings and three-inch letters on mailboxes or posts. For industrial buildings, 12-inch letters are recommended. 
(Code 1989, § 440.01) 
Sec. 8-112. - Adoption of plan. 
    The plan and system for numbering of houses and buildings on file in the city offices is incorporated by reference. The basis for the plan is as follows: 
(1)	Numbers of east-west streets. Numbers on east-west streets shall start at the Wayzata-Orono line on North Ferndale Road (and its extension) and increase from 0 going west, with 800 numbers to a mile. 
(2)	Numbers on north-south streets. Numbers on north-south streets shall start at the south line of T118N and increase from 0 going north or south, with 800 numbers to a mile. 
(Code 1989, § 440.02) 
Sec. 8-113. - Assignment of numbers. 
    The city administrator shall assign numbers in accordance with the numbering plan, to every house or other building in the city, and shall make a report of the numbers assigned. A copy of the report and the council resolution adopting it, properly certified, shall be attached to the plat of the city in the office of the register of deeds of the county and to the plat of the city in the office of the city; and the numbers assigned may be entered upon the appropriate blocks and lots indicated on the plats. 
(Code 1989, § 440.03) 
Sec. 8-114. - Annual report of new numbers. 
    Whenever any house or other building is to be erected, a number shall be assigned at the time the building permit is granted. On or before January 31 of each year, the city administrator shall prepare certificates stating the new numbers assigned during the preceding calendar year, and send one to the register of deeds of the county for attaching to the plat of the city and shall attach another to the plat in the office of the city administrator. Such numbers shall be appropriately entered upon the plats. 
(Code 1989, § 440.04) 
Secs. 8-115-8-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HAZARDOUS REAL PROPERTY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 16. 
State Law reference- Authority to enact and enforce ordinances addressing hazardous and substandard buildings or hazardous condition of real estate, Minn. Stats. § 463.26. 

Sec. 8-151. - Deteriorated structures. 
    In any area, the existence of any structure or part of any structure which because of fire, wind or other natural disaster, or physical deterioration is no longer habitable as a dwelling, nor useful for any other purpose for which it may have been intended shall not be allowed. 
(Code 1989, § 505.01) 
State Law reference- Definition of hazardous building or hazardous property, Minn. Stats. § 463.15, subd. 3. 
Sec. 8-152. - Vacant buildings. 
    In any area, the existence of any vacant or portion of any vacant building, garage or other outbuilding, unless such buildings are kept securely locked, windows kept glazed or neatly boarded up, and otherwise protected to prevent entrance to vandals, shall not be allowed. 
(Code 1989, § 505.02) 
State Law reference- Authority to order securing of vacant buildings, Minn. Stats. § 463.251. 
Sec. 8-153. - Enforcement. 
    The owner, owner's agent in charge of the building or property, and the occupying tenant of any property upon which any of the causes of blight or blighted factors set forth in sections 8-151 and 8-152 is found to exist shall be notified in writing by the building inspector or fire chief to remove or eliminate such causes of blight or blighting factors from such property within ten days after service of the notice upon him. Such notice may be served personally or by registered mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the owner and, if the premises are occupied, to the premises. Additional time may be granted by the enforcement officer where bona fide efforts to remove or eliminate such causes of blight or blighting factors are in progress. If the owner fails to answer the order, the city may move the district court of the county in which the hazardous building or property is located for summary enforcement of the order. If an answer is filed contesting the order, further proceedings in the action shall be governed by the rules of civil procedure for the district courts. 
(Code 1989, § 505.03(1)) 
State Law reference- Required content, service, and filing of order to remove, raze, or correct hazardous building or condition of real estate, Minn. Stats. § 463.17; required notice and order to secure any vacant or unoccupied building, Minn. Stats. § 463.251; default cases, Minn. Stats. § 463.19; procedure in contested cases, Minn. Stats. § 463.20. 
Sec. 8-154. - Exercise of eminent domain authorized. 
    In case of failure to raze, remove, or correct any blight within the time prescribed by district court judgment, the city may acquire, by eminent domain, the building, if any, and real estate on which the building or hazardous condition exists, or the police department may order to be repaired, razed, removed or corrected the hazardous buildings or conditions of property and shall certify the cost to the city administrator. The city administrator shall certify such cost to the county auditor as a special assessment against the property involved for collection in the same manner as other special assessments. As an additional or alternative remedy, the owners of any interest in the land and the occupancy shall be jointly and severally liable for such costs; and the costs shall be recoverable in any action against any of them in the name of the city to impose a lien against the real estate on which the hazardous building or condition exists or obtain a judgment against the owner of the real estate on which the hazardous building or condition exists. 
(Code 1989, § 505.03(2)) 
State Law reference- Authority to remove, raze or correct any hazardous building or property, Minn. Stats. § 463.15 et seq. 
Sec. 8-155. - Violation; penalty. 
    Failure to comply with a notice under this article within the time allowed shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable in accordance with section 1-13. 
(Code 1989, § 505.03(3)) 
Secs. 8-156-8-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SIGN REGULATIONS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to provide signs for public streets, buildings and parks, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 34; Minnesota Outdoor Advertising Control Act, Minn. Stats. § 173.01 et seq., Minn. Rules §§ 8810.0200-8810.1400. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-191. - Purpose. 
    Regulations governing signs are established to allow effective signage appropriate to the planned character of each district, to promote an attractive environment, to minimize adverse effects on nearby property, and protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1989, § 435.01; Ord. No. 435, § 31(1), 11-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Declaration of policy regarding advertising devices on property adjacent to roads and highways, Minn. Stats. § 173.01, Minn. Rules § 8810.0300; purpose and intent of regulating outdoor advertising and outdoor signs in the capitol area, Minn. Rules § 2400.0850. 
Sec. 8-192. - Scope of regulations. 
    The sign regulations set forth in this article shall apply to all structures and all land uses. This article describes the signage standards for permitted and conditional uses in the residential and industrial zoning districts and within the central business and highway commercial special sign districts that overlay the commercial zoning districts and a part of the industrial district. Specific additional regulations are established for signs which are unique in purpose and not easily addressed by district regulations. No person shall place, erect or maintain a sign, nor shall a lessee or owner permit property under his control to be used for such sign, which does not conform to the requirements of this article and all other applicable regulations. 
(Code 1989, § 435.01; Ord. No. 435, § 31(2), 11-4-1998) 
Secs. 8-193-8-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 8-211. - Sign permit required. 
(a)	Any placement or installation of a new sign, temporary or permanent, or, if any modification of an existing sign that changes the location, size, height, method or intensity of lighting, or bulk of the sign, or, any maintenance that involves removal, temporary or permanent, or replacement of any part of the sign cabinet, and/or the sign's supports, attachment or structure shall require a sign permit. Temporary removal of the sign face for installation of a new sign face shall require a sign permit but will not require the sign to be brought into conformance with the regulations of this article. 
(b)	A sign permit will be issued by the city after application for such permit on a form provided by the city along with any plans, certifications or other attachments requested by the city, and the finding by city officials the application is in conformance with the regulations of this section. 
(Code 1989, §§ 435.03, 435.04; Ord. No. 435, § 31(3), 11-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Permits for road advertising permits, Minn. Stats. §§ 173.06, 173.07; permits for outdoor advertising permits in scenic areas and along and adjacent to interstate and primary systems of highways, Minn. Rules § 8810.1300; sign permits for capitol area, Minn. Rules § 2400.0900. 
Sec. 8-212. - Exempt signs. 
    The following signs shall be exempt from the regulations of this article: 
(1)	Official public notices or warning signs required by local, state or federal law, including but not limited to traffic control and other regulatory purpose signs. 
(2)	Any sign located inside a building that is not legible from more than three feet beyond the property line of the parcel or lot the sign is located on. 
(3)	Religious symbols or works of art that do not contain a commercial message. 
(4)	Any temporary for sale or for rent sign that advertises the sale or rental of the premises upon which the sign is located as long as the sign is not illuminated and does not exceed 24 square feet in area or four feet in height, or the height permitted for an auxiliary sign in that sign district, if greater. 
(5)	Any sign display or device allowed under this article that contains, in lieu of other copy, any otherwise lawful noncommercial message that does not direct attention to a business operated for profit, or to a commodity or service for sale, and that complies with the size, height and lighting requirements of this article. 
(6)	Any political campaign sign in compliance with Minn. Stats. § 211B.045. 
(7)	Home security signs not exceeding two square feet in area. 
(Code 1989, § 435.07; Ord. No. 435, § 31(4), 11-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Excluded road advertising devices in scenic areas, Minn. Stats. § 173.08; exclusions and exemptions of advertising devices visible to operators and occupants of motor vehicles on the primary or interstate system of highways, Minn. Rules § 8810.0400; exempt signs, Minn. Rules § 2400.0910; all noncommercial signs of any size may be posted from August 1 in a state general election year until ten days following the state general election, Minn. Stats. § 211B.045. 
Secs. 8-213-8-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 8-231. - Prohibited signs. 
    The following signs shall be prohibited in all zoning districts: 
(1)	Signs with moving or swinging parts. 
(2)	Flashing signs, except in the central business or highway commercial districts when used to provide primarily time and temperature or other public service information and not to exceed 25 percent of the area of the sign face. 
(3)	Roof signs. 
(4)	Off-premises, billboard or advertising signs, or any sign that directs attention to a business, service, product or event not related to or on the premises where the sign is located. 
(5)	Any sign not constructed, wired, assembled, attached or supported in conformance with applicable building or other codes and regulations. 
(6)	Any sign not specifically permitted in this article. 
(Code 1989, § 435.06; Ord. No. 435, § 31(5), 11-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Required conditions of outdoor signs in the capitol area, Minn. Rules § 2400.0860; prohibited advertising devices on trunk highways, Minn. Stats. § 173.15, Minn. Rules § 8810.0500. 
Sec. 8-232. - Regulation by sign district. 
    For the purpose of regulation of signs, the following sign districts are adopted: 
(1)	Residential district, which includes all properties located in the R-1, R-1A, R-2, R-3 and R-4 zoning districts occupied for residential use. 
(2)	Multifamily residential district, which includes all properties located in the R-5 and R-6 zoning districts and any nonresidential use located in a residential zoning district. 
(3)	Central business district, which shall be an overlay district and shall include all commercially zoned properties located within the central business sign overlay district on the zoning map. 
(4)	Highway commercial district, which shall be an overlay district and shall include all commercially or industrially zoned properties located within the highway commercial sign overlay district on the zoning map. 
(5)	Industrial district, which includes all industrially zoned properties not located in the highway commercial sign overlay district. 
(Code 1989, § 435.08; Ord. No. 435, § 31(6), 11-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Chart of permitted signs, by use district, in the capitol area, Minn. Rules § 2400.0870; signs in business areas, Minn. Rules § 8810.0900; unzoned commercial or industrial areas, Minn. Rules § 8810.1000; prohibited advertising areas, Minn. Rules § 8810.1200. 
Sec. 8-233. - Permitted sign type, area, height and illumination by sign district. 
(a)	Conformity. All signs, unless specifically regulated in section 8-234, shall conform to the applicable standards in the following Table One:
