(a) The area of all signs shall be area of the smallest rectangle, circle or triangle that contains the sign copy. Permitted sign area is in square feet. 
(b) The maximum height of all signs in feet shall be measured from grade at the base of the sign or the elevation of the nearest edge of the nearest roadway, whichever is greater. 
(c) E = external, I = internal, B = backlit, see subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
(d) Projecting signs are only permitted when projecting over a public right-of-way; maximum projection is four feet. 
(e) See special design requirement in section 8-235 for freestanding signs in the highway commercial districts. 
State Law reference- Chart of permitted signs, by use district, in the capitol area, Minn. Rules § 2400.0870. 
(b)	Definition of permitted sign types and lighting. 
(1)	Sign types. 
a.	Wall sign means a sign mounted parallel to the building facade. Wall signs may not extend more than 18 inches from the wall they are attached to. 
State Law reference- Definition of wall sign, Minn. Rules § 2400.0010, subp. 60(U). 
b.	Projecting sign means a sign, other than a wall sign, that is attached to and projects from the building facade. Projecting signs are only permitted when projecting over a public right-of-way. Projecting signs may extend not more than four feet into any right-of-way, and an encroachment permit must be acquired. In no case may a projecting sign extend beyond the top of the wall to which it is attached. 
State Law reference- Definition of projecting sign, Minn. Rules § 2400.0010, subp. 60(N). 
c.	Roof sign means a sign mounted on the roof of a building or on a parapet wall. Roof signs are not permitted. 
State Law reference- Definition of roof sign, Minn. Rules § 2400.0010, subp. (R). 
d.	Freestanding sign means a self-supporting sign on poles, standards or any other base anchored to the ground. No more than one freestanding sign is permitted on any site. See the special design requirements for freestanding signs in the highway commercial sign overlay districts in section 8-235. 
Freestanding signs must be located to provide at least a five-foot setback from any property line. If the bottom edge of the sign copy is not located more than ten feet above the ground with supports that do not encroach on the clear vision of approaching traffic from any exit from the site, the sign must be located to preserve the following clear vision area. 
The clear vision area shall be an area within a triangle created beginning at the intersection of the midpoint of the driveway and the curb or edge of pavement line of the street, and extending 35 feet in the direction of approaching traffic and 25 feet toward the interior of the property, and then a line connecting these two points. 
State Law reference- Definition of pylon sign, Minn. Rules § 2400.0010, subp. 60(O); chart of permitted signs, Minn. Rules § 2400.0870(3); prohibition of freestanding signs in visual corridors, Minn. Rules § 2400.1220. 
e.	Auxiliary sign means a sign solely providing direction for internal circulation, parking or entry; restrictions on parking; or security warnings. Only nonilluminated auxiliary signs are permitted, and no part of the sign may display a product or logo message. 
State Law reference- Definition of directional signs, Minn. Stats. § 173.02, subd. 6(d), Minn. Rules § 2400.0010, subp. 60(F); standards for directional signs, Minn. Stats. § 173.081. 
(2)	Sign lighting. 
a.	Not permitted. A sign is not permitted if it is neither lighted internally nor has a specific source of light directed at it. It depends on the general illumination in the area for its lighting. 
b.	External. A sign is illuminated externally if it is illuminated by means of external light fixtures directed at the sign. 
c.	Internal. A sign is internally lighted if it is illuminated by a light source located inside of the sign and only the letters other symbols are illuminated within an opaque background. This includes neon and/or channel letter signs. 
d.	Backlit. A sign is backlit if the message is applied to a translucent panel, through which light is directed from a source behind the sign face, illuminating the copy and background of the sign. 
(Code 1989, § 435.09(2); Ord. No. 435, § 31(7), 11-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Lighting requirements of advertising devices located in business areas adjacent to interstate or primary highways, Minn. Stats. § 173.16, subd. 3. 
Sec. 8-234. - Allocation of permitted sign type and sign area in multitenant developments and sites. 
(a)	In multitenant buildings or sites, the permitted sign area and sign types, except for permitted freestanding signs, may be installed by each individual business establishment that has exclusive use of some portion of the street or otherwise primary level of the building, and unless located in a center with a common mall or atrium must have direct access to the outside. The management and ownership of any business establishment proposing to install signage must be separate and distinct from the management and ownership of any other establishment in the same building or on the same building lot. Each establishment must be separated from all other establishments by party walls having no openings or passages. Signage for establishments occupying a multitenant building or site but not located on the street or primary level of the building must be provided from the allocation of sign area and type to the occupants of the street or primary level of the building. 
(b)	Only one freestanding sign is permitted for each development or parcel whether occupied by a single or by multiple tenants. In the case of multiple-tenant sites, the permitted freestanding sign area in table one, section 8-233, for the single permitted freestanding sign must be allocated by the owner of the site among its tenants. 
(Code 1989, § 435.05(7); Ord. No. 435, § 31(8), 11-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Chart of permitted signs, Minn. Rules § 2400.0870; size limitations of advertising devices on trunk highways inside and outside corporate limits, Minn. Stats. § 173.16, subd. 2; spacing of advertising devices on trunk highways, Minn. Stats. § 173.16, subd. 4; measuring sign area, Minn. Rules § 8810.0600; back-to-back, side-to-side, and V-type signs, Minn. Rules § 8810.0700; allowable on-premises signs within a scenic area, Minn. Rules § 8810.0800; spacing and location required for advertising devices for business areas of highways or roads, Minn. Rules § 8810.1100. 
Sec. 8-235. - Special sign types. 
(a)	Service area canopy signs. Each edge of a service area canopy facing a street is permitted 25 square feet of sign area in addition to all other sign area permitted on the site. Such signage may be illuminated externally, internally or backlit; but no other part of the face of the canopy shall be illuminated. 
(b)	Awning or sun canopy. No part of an awning or sun canopy may be less than eight feet or greater than 12 feet above grade. Any sign area on the awning, if illuminated, will be deducted from the permitted wall sign area. The fabric or material used for the awning or canopy must be opaque, and no internal illumination is permitted. 
(c)	Design of freestanding signs in the highway commercial sign districts. Freestanding signs in the highway commercial sign districts may not be supported by poles or columns. They must be monument-type ground signs with the copy resting on and supported by a solid base of brick or rock faced block in a color similar to or complementary to the main structure on the site. The material of the base must extend at least halfway up the sides of the sign copy. 
(Code 1989, §§ 435.02(6), 435.08(3); Ord. No. 435, § 31(9), 11-4-1998) 
Sec. 8-236. - Temporary signs. 
    Temporary signs, including streamers and pennants, are permitted for a total of 30 days per calendar year. The area of the temporary signs may not exceed 50 percent of the maximum sign area permitted at the site per table one, section 8-233. 
(Code 1989, §§ 435.02(22), 435.07(1), (3), (6), (7), (9); Ord. No. 435, § 31(10), 11-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Definition of temporary sign, Minn. Rules § 2400.0010, subp. 60(S); chart of permitted signs, temporary, Minn. Rules § 2400.0870(2)(h). 
Sec. 8-237. - Sign adjustments. 
    Adjustment to the height, area or location of a sign may be approved by the city council if the following criteria are met: 
(1)	There are site conditions which require a sign adjustment to allow the sign to be reasonably visible from a street immediately adjacent to the street; or 
(2)	The sign adjustment will allow a sign of exceptional design or a style that will enhance the area or that is more consistent with the architecture and design of the site; and 
(3)	The sign adjustment will not result in a sign that is inconsistent with the purpose of the zoning district in which the property is located. 
(Code 1989, § 435.12; Ord. No. 435, § 31(11), 11-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, sign variances, Minn. Rules § 2400.0930. 

Proposed Sign Districts 
Secs. 8-238-8-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MOVING OF STRUCTURES 

Sec. 8-271. - Purpose. 
    The process of preparing structures and transporting them from one site to another via public streets, and related necessary site activity, can adversely affect the health, safety, and welfare of the city. The intent of regulating the moving of buildings within the city is to minimize the adverse effects of such activity, consistent with Minn. Stats. § 221.81. 
(Ord. of 4-3-2001, § VI.1) 
Sec. 8-272. - Enforcement. 
(a)	This article will be enforced by the building official, public works director, the chief of police, and other authorized agents. 
(b)	The property owner is responsible to maintain the property to current city standards. Failure to maintain the property will result in the city causing the work to be completed and all charges will be assessed to the property owner. 
(Ord. of 4-3-2001, § VI.8) 
Sec. 8-273. - Appeals of decisions. 
    Appeals of a decision made by the building official, public works director, or zoning administrator shall be made in accordance with section 26, pertaining to appeals of decision of the building official and zoning administrator, in the city zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. of 4-3-2001, § VI.9) 
Sec. 8-274. - Building and zoning code requirements. 
    Buildings or structures, including manufactured homes, that have been previously used or occupied for any purpose and that are moved into or within the city must comply with the provisions of the city building code and zoning ordinance for new buildings or structures. 
(Ord. of 4-3-2001, § VI.2) 
Sec. 8-275. - Permit required. 
    A person must not move or cause to be moved a building or structure, including manufactured homes, that have been previously used or occupied for any purpose, into, within, or out of the city without first obtaining all necessary permits to do so. 
(Ord. of 4-3-2001, § VI.3) 
Sec. 8-276. - Moving permit application. 
(a)	An application for a moving permit must be completed and filed with the city clerk. 
(b)	The moving permit application shall include, among other inclusions, the following: 
(1)	The legal description of the premises from which and to which the building is to be moved as prepared by a registered land surveyor. 
(2)	A certificate of survey from a registered land surveyor showing the location of the building on the destination lot and related lot improvements. 
(3)	A rendering showing for the destination lot the proposed: 
a.	Grade and elevation as it relates to adjacent lots; 
b.	Elevation of the first floor; 
c.	Drainage and fill requirements; and 
d.	Location of all utilities. 
(4)	Photos and/or drawings for the destination lot showing: 
a.	All sides of the building or structure; and 
b.	The proposed building locations. 
(5)	The highways, streets, and other property over which the building is proposed to be moved. 
(6)	The proposed moving date and hours. 
(7)	Evidence that the building and lot from which it is to be removed are free from mortgages, liens or other encumbrances, and that all taxes, utility bills, and other charges against the lots from which, and to which, the building is to be moved are currently paid. 
(8)	Evidence, such as a bill of sale, showing that the applicant is entitled to move the building. 
(9)	The permit fee specified in the city's fee schedule adopted by the city council and amended from time to time. 
(10)	As part of the permit fee, a limited letter of credit, bond, or certified check from the property owner for a minimum of $5,000.00 payable to the city to ensure that the streets are not damaged and that the structure is properly removed from the former property, located on the proposed property and attached to the foundation and utilities in compliance with the permit, building code, and this article. 
(11)	The name, address, proof of state license issued by the state under Minn. Stats. § 221.81, and proof of insurance of the proposed building mover. 
(12)	The name, address, proof of state license, and proof of insurance of the proposed contractors that are connecting and/or disconnecting utility services on the origin and destination lots. 
(13)	Any additional information requested by the city planner, building official, or public works director. 
(Ord. of 4-3-2001, § VI.4) 
Sec. 8-277. - Permit issuance. 
(a)	The issued permit must specify the following: 
(1)	The permitted days, hours, route, movement, parking, speed limit, and vegetation removal for the proposed move. 
(2)	Written notice from the building official that the building or structure meets the requirements of the city building code and zoning ordinance. 
(3)	Any additional conditions imposed by the building official, public works director, city planner, chief of police, or school district principal. 
(b)	The issuance of a city permit does not relieve the obligation to obtain required permits from other governmental agencies and does not permit the use of private property except when written consent of the landowner has been received by the public works director. 
(c)	The building official may refuse to issue the moving permit if it finds that: 
(1)	The permit application is incomplete as required in section 8-276. 
(2)	A permit requirement in section 8-276 has not been met. 
(3)	The building is too large to move or that no routes are available to be used without endangering persons or property or seriously inconveniencing traffic in the city. Limited vegetation trimming or removal may be allowed in the permit. 
(4)	The proposed route includes use of private property, and no written consent from the owner has been obtained. 
(5)	People or property in the city would be endangered by moving the building. 
(6)	The building is structurally unsafe or unfit for the purpose for which it is moved, if the proposed location is within the city. 
(7)	The proposed building mover's equipment is unsafe, and persons and property may be endangered by its use. 
(8)	The proposed building mover has been shown to be unreliable and irresponsible in complying with city requirements. 
(9)	The building to be moved is not worth at least 50 percent of the cost of a similar new building. 
(10)	The building in the proposed location in the city would fail to comply with any provision of the zoning ordinance, and proper assurances of future compliance have not been given. 
(11)	The building in the proposed location in the city would not conform to the general bulk, density, and/or character of, and the types of architecture in, the surrounding neighborhood. 
(12)	The necessary permits from other governmental agencies have not been obtained. 
(Ord. of 4-3-2001, § VI.5) 
Sec. 8-278. - Supplemental information. 
(a)	At least ten city business days before the actual move is to take place, the applicant must submit to the building official and public works director all of the following supplemental information: 
(1)	The proposed moving date and hours. 
(2)	A copy of the proposed building mover's state license and an insurance certificate showing that the mover has current insurance coverage required by state law. 
(3)	The identity of the motor vehicle and trailer to be used, including the make, model, model year, license number, and vehicle identification number, and evidence that the motor vehicle, trailers, and other equipment is in compliance with state and federal requirements for use on public highways. 
(4)	A signed statement from the applicant or a contractor agreeing to fence or secure the foundation at the original building location, to install a silt fence, to fill the foundation cavity with an approved fill, to landscape the surface with perennial grass, and to keep the area safe and clean, in accordance with section 8-279, if that location is within the city. 
(5)	A signed statement from the applicant or a contractor agreeing to properly abandon any wells, fill any septic tanks and/or properly disconnect all utilities in accordance with section 8-279, if the original building location is within the city. 
(6)	A signed statement from the applicant or a contractor agreeing to connect the building to its new foundation in accordance with section 8-279. 
(7)	Existing water and sewer service must be terminated and all outstanding bills paid prior to the issuance of a permit. 
(b)	A permit for a building move is void if the additional information required in subsection (a) of this section is not provided in a timely manner as determined by the building official or public works director. 
(c)	In consultation with the chief of police, principal of the school district, and building official, the public works director may deny the proposed moving date and hours if the move at that time would unreasonably interfere with the public's use of a street or highway or would otherwise adversely affect the public interest. The public works director may also deny use of the proposed building mover if its equipment is not in compliance with federal and state requirements, it does not have a current license or insurance as required by state law, or it has previously been unreliable or irresponsible in complying with city requirements. The director must notify the applicant in writing of a denial at least five city business days before the proposed moving date, giving the reasons for denial. The applicant may file a written appeal of this decision with the city clerk, to be heard by the city council at its next available meeting, unless the applicant selects a later date in writing. 
(Ord. of 4-3-2001, § VI.6) 
Sec. 8-279. - Building moving conditions. 
(a)	A licensed building mover must comply with the following when moving buildings into, within, or out of the city. The building mover must: 
(1)	Move a building only in compliance with the permit conditions and only over the streets and other property designated for that use in the permit. 
(2)	Obtain prior permission from the chief of police for any changes in the approved route or times for the move. 
(3)	Notify the police department and school district at least four hours in advance of the proposed move. 
(4)	Notify the public works director of all damage done to any property during the move within 24 hours after the damage has occurred. 
(5)	Be responsible for all damage caused by the move and pay the cost to correct the damage or the value of the property lost because of the damage. 
(6)	Remove all debris located on the origin and destination lots, and along the public and/or private land along the route within 48 hours of the completion of the move, in accordance with section 20-1. 
(7)	Comply with state and county requirements for over-sized vehicles and loads. 
(8)	Use only the motor vehicles and trailers identified in the supplemental information or obtain police department approval of any substitution before the move and provide written verification of this approval to the public works director before the structure is moved. 
(9)	When necessary, erect and maintain barricades across the streets and other necessary traffic control devices during the entire time period of the move to protect the public from damage or injury because of the move. 
(10)	Complete the move within 48 hours after either: 
a.	The building crosses into the city, if moved from a location outside the city; or 
b.	The building is raised from its original foundation, if moved from a location within the city. 
(11)	Pay the expense of employees or other individuals who are required and retained by the city to accompany or monitor the movement of the building for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the moving permit or protecting the public health, safety or welfare. 
(12)	Comply with all applicable state laws and local ordinances. 
(b)	A move is complete when the structure has been moved to the precise location shown on the approved certificate of survey and the equipment used to move the building has been removed. 
(c)	A building mover cannot transfer its obligations under subsection (a) of this section to the building owner or any other party, except where the responsibility for damage is insured by a contract for liability insurance. 
(d)	Within 120 days after the date of the permit issuance, the building must be moved, the building code requirements met as they apply to the structure at its new location, and a certificate of occupancy for the building received if all requirements are met. 
(e)	A person must not cause or permit a structure that has been raised from a foundation and placed on supports to: 
(1)	Remain at a location or locations in the city, other than the new permanent location, for longer than 48 hours; or 
(2)	Remain on any property without the written consent of the property owner. 
(f)	The applicant, the landowner and the contractor hired to be responsible for the work must not leave rubbish or other materials at the site from which the building is moved or otherwise allow that site to remain in an unsafe, unsanitary or unsightly condition. 
(g)	The applicant, the landowner and the contractor hired to be responsible for a building foundation must not allow an open and unattended foundation to remain unsecured for more than a two-hour period immediately after a building has been raised from the foundation. Foundations must be fenced or secured in some other manner to prevent uninvited access, particularly by children, to the open foundation. 
(h)	The applicant, the landowner and the contractor hired to be responsible for a building foundation must not allow a foundation from which a building has been removed to remain open longer than seven days after the building was removed. Foundations must be removed and the cavity filled with previously approved earth materials to the original contours, covered to a depth of four inches, with the approved topsoil seeded with perennial grass. Previously used foundations and related materials may be used in the construction of a new building if approved by the building official. 
(i)	No later than the time required by subsection (a) of this section for filling the foundation, the applicant, the landowner, or a contractor hired to be responsible must properly abandon any wells and fill any septic tanks remaining on the original site of the building, if these will no longer be used. On parcels within the city, a state-licensed plumber must be retained to properly disconnect existing water and sewer services. Utility services will be required to be disconnected at the main lines unless otherwise approved by the building official. Any disturbances to the street or any improvement within the public right-of-way must be repaired to a standard at least comparable to the previously existing condition within 48 hours of disconnect. 
(j)	The building must be connected to the foundation at its new location in accordance with the city building code within ten days after the move has been completed. 
(k)	Variances from the provisions of this article may be granted by the public works director upon documentation of good cause. 
(l)	A failure to comply with a permit provision, building code requirement, or condition in this article will result in a forfeiture of the letter of credit, bond or cash deposit. The city may use the financial proceeds to complete unfinished work required by the permit, the building code, or this article, or to pay for any damage caused by the move. 
(m)	No work will be permitted that violates applicable noise ordinance and regulations. 
(Ord. of 4-3-2001, § VI.7) 
Chapter 10 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 4; emergency management, ch. 14; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 24; business and contribution solicitation practices, § 24-31 et seq.; utilities, ch. 36. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AMUSEMENT DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to prevent or license and regulate amusements and amusement devices, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 25. 

Sec. 10-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement device means any table or machine which may be used for any game or contest or amusement, and for the use, operation or playing of which money or any other consideration is charged, either by insertion of a coin into such table or machine, or in any other manner, including such devices as pinball machines, novelty machines, skill machines, pool or billiard machines, foosball machines, bowling machine, or any other machine or device commonly known as and used as a game of skill, amusement or play and for the use, operation or playing of which a consideration is charged; however, nothing in this section shall be construed to include within the definition of amusement device a coin-operated music box or what is commonly known as a jukebox. 
    Operator means a person who keeps or allows to be kept amusement devices on premises owned by him or under his control where they may be played by members of the public legally upon such premises upon payment of the charge or consideration required to play such amusement devices. 
(Code 1989, § 930.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-32. - License required. 
    No person shall become an operator of any amusement device, nor shall any person own, operate, maintain or keep for public use and play within the city any amusement device without first having applied for and received an operator's license; except no such license shall be required for an amusement device kept in a private residence and not available for public play. No such license shall be issued for any device or machine which constitutes a roulette wheel, slot machine or any other device or machine commonly known to be and used for gambling purposes. Nor shall any person, having obtained an operator's license, own, operate, maintain or keep for public use and play within the city any amusement device without first having such amusement device inspected and tagged (and the appropriate fee paid to the city). 
(Code 1989, § 930.02) 
State Law reference- Definition of gambling device, Minn. Stats. § 609.76, subd. 4; with certain exceptions, manufacturing, selling, offering for sale, providing or setting up for the purpose of gambling a gambling device constitutes a gross misdemeanor, Minn. Stats. § 609.76, subd. 1(4) and (5). 
Sec. 10-33. - License application fees, inspection and display. 
(a)	Application for an operator's license shall be made at the office of the city clerk upon forms to be provided by the city. The application shall be accompanied by payment of a fee, to be set from time to time by the city council, per amusement device to be owned, operated, maintained or kept for public use on the applicant's premises. The application shall specify the number, types and distinguishing characteristics of the amusement devices for which the applicant seeks an operator's license and shall clearly identify the premises upon which such amusement devices shall be kept. Upon an operator's license being granted, each amusement device shall be inspected by such city employees or agents as the council may authorize and designate from time to time. Such inspector shall then attach a prenumbered or prelettered tag, which the city shall supply, to each amusement device found to comply with the provisions of this article in such a way that it can be readily seen and which tags shall remain so attached during the term of the license. Such inspector shall thereafter spot check the licensee's devices and premises on a quarterly basis. The operator's license, upon being granted, shall be issued to the operator upon a form or certificate supplied by the city, and shall be plainly displayed in the operator's place of business. All license fees shall be paid into the general fund of the city. All operator's licenses shall commence on September 1 of each year and terminate on August 31 of the subsequent year. License fees shall be paid in advance. 
(b)	No operator's license shall be transferable as to person or premises, nor shall any tags be transferrable between or among amusement devices. However, the holder of a valid operator's license may automatically receive additional license tags for replacement or newly acquired amusement devices on condition that the annual license fee is first paid and the replacement or newly acquired amusement devices have been inspected. 
(Code 1989, § 930.03) 
Sec. 10-34. - Granting, suspension and/or revocation of license. 
    The council shall grant or deny any application as provided in this article; and, if granted, the council may suspend or revoke such license for good cause shown upon notice and hearing. 
(Code 1989, § 930.04) 
Sec. 10-35. - Prohibited practices. 
    No person shall permit the operation of an amusement device for the purposes of making side bets or gambling in any form. 
(Code 1989, § 930.05) 
State Law reference- Making a bet constitutes a misdemeanor, Minn. Stats. § 609.755, subd. 1. 
Secs. 10-36-10-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CIGARETTES AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license and regulate the retail sale of tobacco as defined in Minn. Stats. § 609.685, subd. 1, Minn. Stats. § 461.12, subd. 1; Minn. Stats. §§ 461.12-461.18 do not preempt a local ordinance that provides for more restrictive regulation of tobacco sales, Minn. Stats. § 461.19. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-71. - Purpose. 
    Because the city recognizes that many persons under the age of 18 years purchase or otherwise obtain, possess and use tobacco, tobacco products and tobacco-related devices, and such sales, possession and use are violations of both state and federal laws; and because studies, which the city hereby accepts, adopts and are on file at city hall, have shown that most smokers begin smoking before they have reached the age of 18 years and that those persons who reach the age of 18 years without having started smoking are significantly less likely to begin smoking; and because smoking has been shown to be the cause of several serious health problems which subsequently place a financial burden on all levels of government; this article shall be intended to regulate the sale, possession and use of tobacco, tobacco products and tobacco-related devices for the purpose of enforcing and furthering existing laws, to protect minors against the serious effects associated with the illegal use of tobacco, tobacco products and tobacco-related devices, and to further the official public policy of the state in regard to preventing young people from starting to smoke as stated in Minn. Stats. § 144.391. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 100, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-72. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cigarette means any roll for smoking made wholly or in part of tobacco, the wrapper or cover of which is made of paper or another substance or material except tobacco. 
State Law reference- Definition of cigarette, Minn. Stats. § 297F.01, subd. 3. 
    Compliance checks means the system the city or other units of government use to investigate and ensure that those authorized to sell tobacco, tobacco products and tobacco-related devices are following and complying with the requirements of this article. Compliance checks shall involve the use of minors over the age of 15 years but under the age of 18 years as authorized by this article. Compliance checks shall also mean the use of minors over the age of 15 years but under the age of 18 years who attempt to purchase tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices for educational, research and training purposes as authorized by state and federal laws. 
State Law reference- Compliance checks, Minn. Stats. § 461.12, subd. 5. 
    Loosies means the common term used to refer to a single or individually packaged cigarette. 
    Minor means any natural person who has not yet reached the age of 18 years. 
State Law reference- Definition of minor, Minn. Stats. § 645.451, subd. 2. 
    Moveable place of business refers to any form of business operated out of a truck, van, automobile or other type of vehicle or transportable shelter and not a fixed address store front or other permanent type of structure authorized for sales transactions. 
State Law reference- Definitions of retailer and retail outlet, Minn. Stats. § 297F.01, subds. 14 and 15. 
    Package means the individual packet, box or other container used to contain and convey cigarettes to the consumer. Packages include but are not limited to single cigarette packs, single bags or cans of loose tobacco in any form, and single cans or other packaging of snuff or chewing tobacco. 
State Law reference- Definition of package, Minn. Stats. § 297F.01, subd. 11. 
    Retail establishment means any place of business where tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices are available for sale to the general public. Retail establishments include but are not limited to grocery stores, convenience stores and restaurants. 
    Sale means a transfer, exchange or barter, in any manner or by any means, for consideration, and includes all sales made by any person. It also includes gifts or samples provided for advertising or promotional purposes, made by a person engaged in the selling of cigarettes or tobacco products. 
State Law reference- Definition of sale, Minn. Stats. § 297F.01, subd. 16. 
    Self-service merchandising means open displays of tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices in any manner where any person shall have access to the tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices, without the actual physical assistance or intervention of the licensee or the licensee's employee in exchanging the tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device between the customer and the licensee or employee. 
    Tobacco products means cigars; little cigars; cheroots; stogies; periques; granulated, plug cut, crimp cut, ready rubbed, and other smoking tobacco; snuff; snuff flour; cavendish; plug and twist tobacco; fine cut and other chewing tobacco; shorts; refuse scraps, clippings, cuttings and sweepings of tobacco, and other kinds and forms of tobacco, prepared in such manner as to be suitable for chewing or smoking in a pipe or otherwise, or both for chewing and smoking; but does not include cigarettes. 
    Tobacco-related devices means a pipe, rolling papers, or other device intentionally designed or intended to be used in a manner which enables the chewing, sniffing, or smoking of tobacco or tobacco products. 
State Law reference- Definition of tobacco, Minn. Stats. § 609.685, subd. 1(a); definition of tobacco products, Minn. Stats. § 297F.01, subd. 19; definition of tobacco-related devices, Minn. Stats. § 609.685, subd. 1(b). 
    Vending machine means any mechanical, electronic or other type of device which dispenses tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices upon the insertion of money, tokens or other form of payment directly into the machine by any person. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 200, 11-3-1997) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 10-73-10-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 10-91. - Required. 
    No person shall sell or offer to sell any tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices without first having obtained a license to do so from the city. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 300(intro. ¶), 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-92. - Application. 
    An application for a license to sell tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices shall be made on a form provided by the city. The application shall contain the full name of the applicant, the applicant's residential and business addresses and telephone numbers, the name of the business for which the license is sought, and any additional information the city deems necessary. Upon receipt of a completed application, the city clerk shall forward the application to the council for action at its next regularly scheduled council meeting. If the city clerk shall determine that an application is incomplete, he shall return the application to the applicant with notice of the information necessary to make the application complete. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 300(1), 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-93. - Action. 
    The council may either approve or deny a license under this division, or it may delay action for such reasonable period of time as necessary to complete any investigation of the application or the applicant it deems necessary. If the council shall approve the license, the city clerk shall issue the license to the applicant. If the council denies the license, notice of the denial shall be given to the applicant, along with notice of the applicant's right to appeal the council's decision. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 300(2), 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-94. - Term. 
    All licenses issued under this division shall be valid for one calendar year from the date of issue. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 300(3), 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-95. - Revocation or suspension. 
    Any license issued under this division may be revoked or suspended as provided in section 10-101. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 300(4), 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-96. - Transfers. 
    All licenses issued under this division shall be valid only on the premises for which the license was issued and only for the person to whom the license was issued. No transfer of any license to another location or person shall be valid without the prior approval of the council. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 300(5), 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-97. - Movable place of business. 
    No license shall be issued to a moveable place of business. Only fixed location businesses shall be eligible to be licensed under this division. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 300(6), 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-98. - Display. 
    All licenses shall be posted and displayed in plain view of the general public on the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 300(7), 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-99. - Renewals. 
(a)	The renewal of a license issued under this division shall be handled in the same manner as the original application. The request for a renewal shall be made at least 30 days but no more than 60 days before the expiration of the current license. 
(b)	The issuance of a license under this division shall be considered a privilege and not an absolute right of the applicant and shall not entitle the holder to an automatic renewal of the license. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 300(8), 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- Authority to license and regulate the retail sale of tobacco, Minn. Stats. § 461.12, subd. 1. 
Sec. 10-100. - Fees. 
    No license shall be issued under this division until the appropriate license fee shall be paid in full. The fee for a license under this division shall be determined from time to time by the city and published in a fee schedule adopted by the city council at a regularly scheduled council meeting. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 400, 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish a license fee for sales to recover administrative costs, Minn. Stats. § 461.12, subd. 1. 
Sec. 10-101. - Basis for denial of license. 
    The following shall be grounds for denying the issuance or renewal of a license under this division; however, except as may otherwise be provided by law, the existence of any particular ground for denial does not mean that the city must deny the license. If a license is mistakenly issued or renewed to a person, it shall be revoked upon the discovery that the person was ineligible for the license under this division because: 
(1)	The applicant is under the age of 18 years. 
(2)	The applicant has been convicted within the past five years of any violation of a federal, state or local law, ordinance provision, or other regulation relating to tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices. 
(3)	The applicant has had a license to sell tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices revoked or suspended on two or more occasions within the preceding 12 months of the date of application. 
(4)	The applicant fails to provide any information required on the application or provides false or misleading information. 
(5)	The applicant is prohibited by federal, state or other local law, ordinance or other regulation from holding such a license. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 500, 11-3-1997) 
Secs. 10-102-10-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SALES 

Sec. 10-121. - Prohibited sales. 
    It shall be a violation of this article for any person to sell or offer to sell any tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device: 
(1)	To any person under the age of 18 years. 
(2)	By means of any type of vending machine, except as may otherwise be provided in this article. 
(3)	By means of self-service methods whereby the customer does not need to make a verbal or written request to an employee of the licensed premises in order to receive the tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device and whereby there is not a physical exchange of the tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device between the licensee or the licensee's employee, and the customer. 
(4)	By means of loosies as defined in section 10-72. 
(5)	Containing ammonia or any compound of ammonia, arsenic, cadmium, formaldehyde, lead, opium, morphine, jimson weed, belladonna, strychnos, cocaine, marijuana or other deleterious, hallucinogenic, toxic or controlled substances except nicotine and other substances found naturally in tobacco or added as part of an otherwise lawful manufacturing process. 
(6)	By any other means, to any other person, or in any other manner or form prohibited by federal, state or other local law, ordinance provision or other regulation. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 600, 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- Selling tobacco to a person under the age of 18 is unlawful, Minn. Stats. § 609.685, subd. 1a. 
Sec. 10-122. - Vending machines. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed under this article to allow the sale of tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices by the means of a vending machine. Any retailer selling tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices on November 3, 1997, shall comply with this section within 45 days. This section does not apply to facilities that cannot be entered at any time by persons younger than 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 700, 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- Vending machine sales prohibited except in facilities from which persons under 18 years of age are excluded, Minn. Stats. § 461.18, subd. 2. 
Sec. 10-123. - Self-service sales. 
    It shall be unlawful for a licensee under this article to allow the sale of tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices by any means whereby the customer may have access to such items, including but not limited to individually packaged or multipack units of tobacco or tobacco products, without having to request the item from the licensee or the licensee's employee and whereby there is not a physical exchange of the tobacco, tobacco product or the tobacco-related device between the licensee or his clerk and the customer. All tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices shall either be stored behind a counter or other area not freely accessible to customers, or in a case or other storage unit not left open and accessible to the general public. Any retailer selling tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices on November 3, 1997, shall comply with this section within 45 days. This section does not apply to retail stores which derive at least 90 percent of their revenue from tobacco and tobacco-related products and which cannot be entered at any time by persons younger than 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 800, 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- Self-service sales of single packages of cigarettes or smokeless tobacco are prohibited, except in adult-only facilities, Minn. Stats. § 461.18, subd. 1. 
Sec. 10-124. - Responsibility. 
    All licensees under this article shall be responsible for the actions of their employees in regard to the sale of tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices on the licensed premises; and the sale of such an item by an employee shall be considered a sale by the license holder. Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the city from also subjecting the clerk to whatever penalties are appropriate under this article, state or federal law, or other applicable law or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 900, 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- Administrative penalties apply to employees of licensees as well as to licensees, Minn. Stats. § 461.12, subd. 2. 
Sec. 10-125. - Compliance checks and inspections. 
    All licensed premises shall be open to inspection by the city police or other authorized city official during regular business hours. From time to time, but at least once per year, the city shall conduct compliance checks by engaging, with the written consent of their parents or guardians, minors over the age of 15 years but less than 18 years to enter the licensed premises to attempt to purchase tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices. Minors used for the purpose of compliance checks shall be supervised by city designated law enforcement officers or other designated city personnel. Minors used for compliance checks shall not be guilty of unlawful possession of tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices when such items are obtained as a part of the compliance check. No minor used in compliance checks shall attempt to use a false identification misrepresenting the minor's age; and all minors lawfully engaged in a compliance check shall answer all questions about the minor's age asked by the licensee or his employee and shall produce any identification, if any exists, for which he is asked. Nothing in this section shall prohibit compliance checks authorized by state or federal laws for educational, research or training purposes, or required for the enforcement of a particular state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 1000, 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- Compliance checks, Minn. Stats. § 461.12, subd. 5. 
Sec. 10-126. - Billboards. 
    Billboards advertising any tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device shall be governed by section 8-191 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 1100, 11-3-1997) 
Secs. 10-127-10-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ILLEGAL ACTS 

Sec. 10-151. - Specified. 
    Unless otherwise provided, the following acts shall be a violation of this article: 
(1)	Illegal sales. It shall be a violation of this article for any person to sell or otherwise provide any tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device to any minor. 
(2)	Illegal possession. It shall be a violation of this article for any minor to have in his possession any tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device. This subsection shall not apply to minors lawfully involved in a compliance check. 
State Law reference- Selling tobacco to a minor is unlawful, Minn. Stats. § 609.685, subd. 1a; furnishing tobacco or tobacco-related devices to a minor is unlawful, Minn. Stats. § 609.685, subd. 2. 
(3)	Illegal use. It shall be a violation of this article for any minor to smoke, chew, sniff or otherwise use any tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device. 
State Law reference- Unlawful for a minor to possess, smoke, chew or otherwise ingest, purchase or attempt to purchase tobacco or tobacco-related devices, Minn. Stats. § 609.685, subd. 3. 
(4)	Illegal procurement. It shall be a violation of this article for any minor to purchase or attempt to purchase or otherwise obtain any tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device; and it shall be a violation of this article for any person to purchase or otherwise obtain such items on behalf of a minor. It shall further be a violation for any person to coerce or attempt to coerce a minor to illegally purchase or otherwise obtain or use any tobacco, tobacco product or tobacco-related device. This subsection shall not apply to minors lawfully involved in a compliance check. 
(5)	Use of false identification. It shall be a violation of this article for any minor to attempt to disguise his true age by the use of a false form of identification, whether the identification is that of another person or one on which the age of the person has been modified or tampered with to represent an age older than the actual age of the person. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 1200, 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- It is an affirmative defense to the charge of selling tobacco to a person under age 18 that the licensee or individual making the sale relied in good faith upon proof of age, Minn. Stats. § 461.12, subd. 6. 
Secs. 10-152-10-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 10-171. - Violations. 
(a)	Notice. Upon discovery of a suspected violation of this article, the alleged violator shall be issued, either personally or by mail, a citation that sets forth the alleged violation and which shall inform the alleged violator of his right to be heard on the accusation. 
(b)	Hearings. If a person accused of violating this article so requests, a hearing shall be scheduled, the time and place of which shall be published and provided to the accused violator. 
(c)	Hearing officer. The city council shall serve as the hearing officer. 
(d)	Decision. If the hearing officer determines that a violation of this article did occur, that decision, along with the hearing officer's reasons for finding a violation and the penalty to be imposed under section 10-172, shall be recorded in writing, a copy of which shall be provided to the accused violator. Likewise, if the hearing officer finds that no violation occurred or finds grounds for not imposing any penalty, such findings shall be recorded and a copy provided to the acquitted accused violator. 
(e)	Appeals. Appeals of any decision made by the hearing officer shall be filed in the district court for the city. 
(f)	Prosecution. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city from seeking prosecution, in addition to imposing administrative penalties, for any alleged violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 1300, 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- Judicial review constitutes appeal from administrative hearing on illegal sale of tobacco, Minn. Stats. § 461.12, subd. 7. 
Sec. 10-172. - Penalties. 
(a)	Licensees. Any licensee found to have violated this article, or whose employee shall have violated this article, shall be charged an administrative fine pursuant to a penalty schedule determined from time to time by the city and published in a penalty schedule adopted by the city council at a regularly scheduled council meeting. In addition, after the second offense, the license shall be suspended for not less than three days. After the third offense, the license shall be suspended for not less than seven days. 
(b)	Other individuals. Individuals other than minors found to be in violation of this article shall be charged an administrative fine pursuant to a penalty schedule determined from time to time by the city and published in a penalty schedule adopted by the city council at a regularly scheduled council meeting. 
(c)	Prosecution. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city from seeking prosecution as a misdemeanor for any violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 1400, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 10-173. - Exceptions and defenses. 
    Nothing in this article shall prevent the providing of tobacco, tobacco products or tobacco-related devices to a minor as part of a lawfully recognized religious, spiritual or cultural ceremony. It shall be an affirmative defense to the violation of this article for a person to have reasonably relied on proof of age as described by state law. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 1500, 11-3-1997) 
State Law reference- Administrative penalties, Minn. Stats. § 461.12, subds. 2, 3. 
Secs. 10-174-10-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GAMBLING[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt more stringent regulation of lawful gambling, including prohibition of lawful gambling, Minn. Stats. § 349.213. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-201. - Policy. 
(a)	Statement of purpose. It is the stated policy of the city that to the extent lawful, regulated gambling is permitted within the city and the net profits and proceeds of gambling shall directly benefit the citizens of the city. 
(b)	Gambling a privilege. The city council finds that lawful gambling is a nuisance-prone activity and as such is subject to restrictive regulations. The city council further finds and declares that the ability to conduct lawful gambling and participate in lawful gambling is a privilege, rather than a right. 
(Ord. No. 915, § 2, 1-4-2000) 
Sec. 10-202. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Charitable means aid given to those in need, a gift for public benevolent purposes. 
    Gambling control division means the state agency that licenses and regulates gambling. 
    Lawful gambling means the operation, conduct or sale of bingo, raffles, paddlewheels, tip boards, and pull tabs. 
State Law reference- Lawful gambling, Minn. Stats. ch. 349. 
    Lawful purpose means any expenditure by or contribution to a 501K(3) organization, provided that the organization and expenditure or contribution are in conformity with standards prescribed by the gambling control board under Minn. Stats. § 349.154. 
    Net profit means gross profit less reasonable sums actually expended for allowable expenses. 
    Organization means a religious, fraternal, veterans or other nonprofit entity which has been in existence for at least three years, has at least 15 active members, and is not in existence solely for the purpose of conducting gambling. 
State Law reference- Definition of organization, Minn. Stats. § 349.11, subd. 28. 
    Premises permit means a permit caused by the state gambling control board for each premises where lawful gambling is to be conducted. 
    Trade area means the city limits and the contiguous City of Orono. 
(Ord. No. 915, § 2, 1-4-2000) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-203. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished in accordance with section 1-13. 
(Ord. No. 915, § 2, 1-4-2000) 
Secs. 10-204-10-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- License forms, Minn. Stats. § 349.155, subd. 1. 

Sec. 10-221. - Investigation fee. 
    Any person or organization applying for a state license, or a renewal of such license to conduct lawful gambling within the city shall submit to a background investigation conducted by the city. At the time it files its application for or renewal of a license with the gambling control board, the person or organization must: 
(1)	Complete an investigation form provided by the city. 
(2)	Furnish any additional information required by the city. 
(3)	Pay an investigation fee of $50.00 (renewal) or $100.00 (new license). This fee will be refundable if the application is withdrawn and no investigation has been started before the city's receipt of this information. 
No person or organization exempt from state license requirements is required to comply with these investigation requirements. 
(Ord. No. 915, § 2, 1-4-2000) 
State Law reference- Authority to assess an investigation fee on organizations or bingo halls applying for or renewing a premises permit or a bingo hall license, Minn. Stats. § 349.16, subd. 8. 
Sec. 10-222. - License restrictions. 
(a)	The city may disapprove premises permits based on the following requirements: The city reserves the right to disapprove a premises permit application for individual bingo occasions, raffle games and pull tab operations for any of the following reasons: 
(1)	Violation by the applicant of any statute, rule, regulation or ordinance relating to gambling. 
(2)	Failure to make reports required by any applicable ordinance, rule, regulation or statute. 
(3)	Any reason which would justify the state gambling control board in denying an application for a license. 
State Law reference- Premises permits, Minn. Stats. § 349.165. 
(b)	No premises permit or renewal will be approved unless: 
(1)	The organization is conducting the lawful gambling on the premises of a church or a fraternal, veterans or other nonprofit organization, or on the premises of an on-sale liquor licensee of the city. 
(2)	All of the following requirements are met: 
a.	The physical site for the organization's headquarters or the registered business office of the organization is located within the city or a city contiguous to the city for at least two years immediately preceding the application for a license; or 
b.	The organization has at least 15 members that are residents of the city trade area. 
This requirement may be waived for an existing licensed organization which does not comply with this subsection and if approved by the city council at the time of the premises permit renewal. 
(Ord. No. 915, § 4, 1-4-2000) 
State Law reference- Qualifications for organization licenses, Minn. Stats. § 349.16, subd. 2, Minn. Rules § 7861.0020, subp. 2. 
Sec. 10-223. - Distribution of proceeds. 
(a)	During any year that an eligible organization is licensed to conduct lawful gambling, no less than 75 percent of its lawful purpose expenditures shall be for lawful purposes conducted or located within the city trade area. The city trade area is defined as the city limits and the contiguous City of Orono. 
(b)	During any year that an eligible organization is licensed to conduct lawful gambling, such organization shall contribute ten percent of the net profit derived from lawful gambling within the city to a fund administered and regulated by the city, without cost to such fund, for disbursement by the city of the receipts for lawful purposes. These ten percent contributions shall be made to the city at the same time of filing the monthly state gambling report, and at no time shall the ten percent contribution be a negative number (i.e. if the licensed operation loses money on operation in a given month, the ten percent contribution shall be $0.00). 
(Ord. No. 915, § 6, 1-4-2000) 
State Law reference- Expenditure restrictions on use of gross profits from lawful gambling, Minn. Stats. § 349.15, subd. 1. 
Sec. 10-224. - Reporting requirements. 
(a)	Every organization licensed to conduct gambling in the city shall file with the city clerk copies of the monthly state gambling report and schedule C required to be filed with the state lawful gambling control board pursuant to Minn. Stats. ch. 349. The records and reports shall be due at the same time they are due to the gambling control board. The city shall file all state or federal reports necessary. 
(b)	Every organization licensed to conduct gambling in the city shall file with the city clerk an annual summary report of lawful purpose expenditures of gambling profits no later than January 30 of each year. 
(c)	Organizations conducting gambling activities in other communities as well as the city shall segregate the gross receipts, expenses, profits and expenditures of profits from the city operation. 
(d)	A semiannual report of the expenditures for lawful purpose gambling within the trade area shall be provided to the city clerk on or before July 2 and February 2 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 915, § 7, 1-4-2000) 
Secs. 10-225-10-360. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - JUNK[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate more strictly and control the erection or maintenance of junkyards, Minn. Stats. §§ 161.242, subd. 7, 471.927; Junkyard Act, Minn. Stats. § 161.242 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-361. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Junk means old or scrap hazard signs, copper, brass, rope, rags, batteries, paper, synthetic or organic, trash, rubber debris, waste, or junked, dismantled or wrecked automobiles or farm or construction machinery or their parts, iron, steel, and other old or scrap ferrous or nonferrous material. 
State Law reference- Definition of junk, Minn. Stats. § 161.242, subd. 2(d). 
    Junk business means the keeping, conducting or maintaining of any building, structure, yard or place for keeping, storing or piling in commercial quantities, whether temporarily, irregularly or continually, or the buying and selling at retail or wholesale or dealing in any junk. 
    Junk dealer means and includes any person engaged in the junk business. 
State Law reference- Definition of junk dealer, Minn. Stats. §§ 161.242, subd. 2(c), 471.925. 
    Junkyard means an establishment, place of business, or place of storage or deposit, which is maintained, operated or used for storing, keeping, buying or selling junk, or for the maintenance or operation of an automobile graveyard, and shall include garbage dumps and sanitary fills not regulated by the state pollution control agency, any of which are wholly or partly within one-half mile of any right-of-way of any state trunk highway, including the interstate highways, whether maintained in connection with another business or not, where the waste, body or discarded material stored is equal in bulk to five or more motor vehicles and which are to be resold for used parts or old iron, metal, glass or other discarded material. 
State Law reference- Definition of junkyard, Minn. Stats. § 161.242, subd. 2(b). 
    Public nuisance means: 
(1)	Maintaining or permitting a condition which unreasonably annoys, injures or endangers the safety, health, morals, comfort or repose of any considerable number of members of the public; 
(2)	Interfering with, obstructing or rendering dangerous for passage any public highway or right-of-way, or waters used by the public; or 
(3)	Engaging in any other act or omission declared by law to be a public nuisance and for which no sentence is specifically provided. 
State Law reference- Elements of public nuisance, Minn. Stats. § 609.74. 
    Screening means trees, shrubs or foliage, natural objects, fences or other appropriate means as determined by standards established by the commissioner of transportation. Plantings shall be used in connection with any fence or other nonnatural screening device. Plantings that will eventually achieve effective screening shall be effective. 
State Law reference- Requirements of screening of junkyards, Minn. Stats. § 161.242, subd. 3(a). 
(Code 1989, § 925.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 10-362-10-380. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 10-381. - Required. 
    No junk dealer shall engage in the junk business within the city without first obtaining a license pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1989, § 925.02) 
Sec. 10-382. - Application. 
    Every applicant for a license to engage in the junk business shall file with the city clerk a written application to be supplied by the city, signed by the applicant and accompanied by a license fee to be set from time to time by the city council. Such application shall state the: 
(1)	Names and residences of the applicant or its principal offices and their residences if the applicant is an association or corporation. 
(2)	Detailed nature of the business to be conducted, and the kind of materials to be collected, stored, bought, sold or otherwise handled. 
(3)	Premises where such business or activity is to be located or carried on. 
(Code 1989, § 925.03) 
Sec. 10-383. - Inspection. 
    The city clerk shall report such application to the fire chief and building inspector, who shall inspect or cause to be inspected such premises to determine whether they are appropriate for carrying on the junk business in terms of whether there is or will be compliance with all laws and ordinances and whether a fire, health or safety hazard would be created by such activity. The city officers shall report their findings to the council at its next regular meeting. 
(Code 1989, § 925.04) 
Sec. 10-384. - Term. 
    The council shall act upon all applications and in its discretion shall grant a license to conduct the junk business for a period not to exceed one year. After expiration of one year, the applicant must resubmit a new application pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1989, § 925.05) 
Sec. 10-385. - Revocation and suspension. 
    The council may suspend or revoke the license of any junk dealer after notice and hearing and upon showing that the junk dealer: 
(1)	Has been convicted of theft or receiving stolen goods or conspiracy to commit either; 
(2)	Has stolen goods in possession and refuses to permit a law enforcement officer to examine them during usual business hours; 
(3)	Purchases property from a person under lawful age, without written consent of the person's parent or guardian; 
(4)	Has failed to or is not competent to operate the licensed business in a manner consistent with public health, safety and welfare, and/or good morals; 
(5)	Failed to comply with the provisions of this article or any provision of law applicable to the premises, equipment or operation of the licensed business; 
(6)	Has obtained his license through any fraud, misrepresentation or misstatement of material fact; 
(7)	Has conducted business in such a manner as to maintain a nuisance; or 
(8)	Is no longer operating or carrying on business. 
(Code 1989, § 925.07) 
State Law reference- A junk or secondhand dealer is subject to penalties of a misdemeanor for possessing stolen goods and refusing inspection of them by a law enforcement officer or unlawfully purchasing property from a minor, Minn. Stats. § 609.815. 
Secs. 10-386-10-410. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 10-411. - Premises requirements. 
    The following general operating requirements shall apply to each junk dealer's license in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(intro. ¶)) 
Sec. 10-412. - Plainly displayed. 
    The license issued pursuant to division 4 of this chapter shall be plainly displayed on the business premises. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(1)) 
Sec. 10-413. - Premises in sanitary condition. 
    The premises on which the junk business is carried on shall at all times be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(2)) 
Sec. 10-414. - No unlicensed land or space. 
    No land or space not covered by the license shall be used in the licensed business. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(3)) 
Sec. 10-415. - Standing water. 
    No water shall be allowed to stand in any place on the premises in such a manner as to afford a breeding place for mosquitoes. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(4)) 
Sec. 10-416. - Vegetation. 
    Weeds and vegetation on the premises, other than trees and shrubs, shall be kept at a height of not more than eight inches. No garbage or waste liable to give off a foul odor or attract vermin shall be kept on the premises. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(5)) 
Sec. 10-417. - Location. 
    No junk shall be allowed to rest upon or protrude over any public street, sidewalk or curb or become scattered or blow off the business premises. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(6)) 
Sec. 10-418. - Buffer zone. 
(a)	There shall be maintained a buffer zone of not less than ten feet between any public street or right-of-way bordering such licensed premises and the area on such licensed premises wherein the licensee keeps, stores or piles the junk or articles for sale, within which buffer zone no junk shall be kept, stored or piled. The buffer zone shall be landscaped with the planting of appropriate grass and/or sod and trees and shrubbery which shall be maintained and kept by the licensee in a presentable appearance. 
(b)	Any junkyard located within one-half mile of any right-of-way of any trunk highway, including interstate highways, shall be screened to effectively conceal it from view of motorists. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(7)) 
State Law reference- Unauthorized junkyards prohibited, Minn. Stats. § 161.242, subd. 3. 
Sec. 10-419. - Storage. 
    Junk shall be stored in piles not exceeding six feet in height, and shall be arranged in a neat and tidy manner with accessways between rows sufficient to allow easy firefighting access to all areas of the premises wherein junk is kept, stored or piled. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(8)) 
Sec. 10-420. - Combustible materials. 
    No combustible material of any kind not necessary or beneficial to the licensed premises shall be kept on the premises, nor shall the premises be allowed to become a fire hazard. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(9)) 
Sec. 10-421. - Gasoline and oil. 
    All gasoline and oil shall be removed from any inoperative engines or motor vehicles on the premises. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(10)) 
Sec. 10-422. - No burning. 
    No junk or material shall be burned on the licensed premises. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(11)) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 18. 
Sec. 10-423. - Noise. 
    No noisy processing of junk or other noisy activity shall be carried on in connection with the licensed premises on Sunday, Christmas, Thanksgiving or at any time between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(12)) 
Cross reference- Noise, § 16-71 et seq. 
Sec. 10-424. - Enclosures, entrances and exits. 
    The area on the premises where junk is kept, stored or piled (other than indoors) shall be enclosed, except for entrances and exits, with a solid vertical wall or fence of a minimum height of six feet measured from ground level. There shall be not more than one entrance and exit of a width of not more than ten feet on any one side of the licensed premises. All entrances and exits shall have a closeable solid gate of a height not less than that of the fence itself. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(13)) 
Sec. 10-425. - Inspection. 
    The licensee shall permit inspection of the premises by any employee or agent of the city at any reasonable time. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(14)) 
Sec. 10-426. - Person under age of 18 years. 
    No junk dealer licensed under this division or his agent or employee shall purchase or receive any junk for use in the licensed business from any person under the age of 18 years without the written consent of a parent or guardian of such person. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(15)) 
Sec. 10-427. - No nuisance allowed. 
(a)	No licensee shall allow the licensed premises to become a nuisance; nor shall any junk business be operated in such a manner as to become injurious to the health, safety or welfare of the community or of any residents close by. 
(b)	Any junkyard not in compliance with the provisions of this article or the Junkyard Act is declared a public nuisance and illegal. 
(Code 1989, § 925.06(16)) 
Cross reference- Public nuisances, § 16-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Declaration of junkyards not in compliance with the Junkyard Act as public nuisances by the commissioner of transportation, Minn. Stats. § 161.242, subd. 3(b). 
Chapter 12 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes:
