State Law reference- Municipal elections, Minn. Stats. ch. 205; Minnesota Election Law, Minn. Stats. §§ 200.01-211C.09. 

Sec. 12-1. - Election date. 
    The regular city election shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each even-numbered year. 
(Code 1989, § 300.01) 
State Law reference- Date of elections, Minn. Stats. § 205.07. 
Sec. 12-2. - Terms of office. 
    The mayor shall serve a term of two years. The councilmembers shall serve terms of four years. 
(Code 1989, § 300.02) 
State Law reference- Officers' terms, Minn. Stats. §§ 412.02, 412.022. 
Chapter 14 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 10. 
State Law reference- Minnesota Emergency Management Act of 1996, Minn. Stats. §§ 12.01-12.46. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Policy and purpose. 
    Because of the existing possibility of the occurrence of disasters of unprecedented size and destruction resulting from fire, flood, tornado, blizzard, destructive winds or other natural causes, or from sabotage or hostile action, or from hazardous material mishaps of catastrophic measure or other major incidents, and in order to ensure that preparations of the city will be adequate to deal with such disasters and generally; to provide for the common defense; to protect the public peace, health and safety; and to preserve the lives and property of the people of this city, it is found and declared to be necessary to: 
(1)	Establish a city emergency management organization responsible for assisting a city in planning and preparation for emergency government operations in time of disasters. 
(2)	Provide for the exercise of necessary powers during emergencies and disasters. 
(3)	Provide for the rendering of mutual aid between the city and other political subdivisions with respect to the carrying out of emergency preparedness functions. 
(4)	Comply with the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 12, known as the Minnesota Emergency Management Act of 1996. 
(5)	To participate as a member of the Lake Minnetonka Regional Emergency Management Preparedness Planning and Review Committee and review and accept its emergency plan as the city's basic plan for responses to emergencies, disasters, major incidents, mutual aid and other projects consistent with ordinance and Minn. Stats. ch. 12. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 1, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 14-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Disaster means a situation which creates an immediate and serious impairment to the health and safety of any person, or a situation which has resulted in or is likely to result in major loss to property, and for which traditional sources of relief and assistance within the affected area are unable to repair or prevent the injury or loss. 
State Law reference- Definition of disaster, Minn. Stats. § 12.03, subd. 2. 
    Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances that calls for immediate action to respond or prevent a disaster from developing or occurring. 
State Law reference- Definition of emergency, Minn. Stats. § 12.03, subd. 3. 
    Emergency management means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters caused by fire, flood, tornado and other acts of nature, or from sabotage, hostile action, industrial hazardous material mishaps or other major incidents. These functions include without limitation firefighting services, police services, emergency medical services, engineering, warning services, communications, radiological, chemical, evacuation, congregate care, emergency transportation, existing or properly assigned functions of plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services and other functions related to civil protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental for carrying out these functions. Emergency management includes those activities sometimes referred to as civil defense or emergency preparedness functions. 
State Law reference- Definition of emergency management, Minn. Stats. § 12.03, subd. 4. 
    Emergency management forces means the total personnel resources engaged in city-level emergency management functions in accordance with the provision of this chapter or any rule or order under this chapter. This includes personnel from city departments, authorized volunteers, and private organizations and agencies. 
State Law reference- Definition of emergency response personnel, Minn. Stats. § 12.03, subd. 4b. 
    Emergency management mutual aid means any disaster or major incident which requires the dispatching of city personnel, equipment or other necessary resources within or without the city limits. 
State Law reference- Arrangements for mutual aid for emergency management, Minn. Stats. § 12.27. 
    Emergency management organization means the staff element responsible for coordinating city-level planning and preparation for disaster response. This organization provides city liaison and coordination with federal, state and local jurisdictions relative to disaster preparedness activities, major incidents, mutual aid, and other projects consistent with this chapter and assures implementation of federal, state, county and other program requirements. 
State Law reference- Definition of local organization for emergency management, Minn. Stats. § 12.03, subd. 6. 
    Lake Minnetonka Regional Emergency Management, Preparedness Planning and Review Committee means a committee made up of the Lake Minnetonka area emergency management directors, which develops, renews and establishes a basic emergency plan; identifies and coordinates training for member communities; and reviews local plans, exercises, major incidents and disaster responses which are consistent with this chapter. 
State Law reference- Regional disaster offices, Minn. Stats. § 12.24. 
    Major incident means any incident that exhausts local resources. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 2, 11-2-1999) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 14-3-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL ORGANIZATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Local emergency management organizations, Minn. Stats. § 12.25. 

Sec. 14-31. - Established. 
    The city designates the police department of the City of Orono and the fire department of Long Lake the director. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 3, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 14-32. - Powers and duties of the director. 
(a)	The director shall represent the city on any regional or state conference for emergency management. The director may develop additional mutual aid agreements with other political subdivisions of the state for reciprocal emergency management aid and assistance in an emergency too great to be dealt with unassisted and shall present such agreements to the city for its action. Such arrangements shall be consistent with the emergency plan. The director shall also be the city's representative on the Lake Minnetonka Regional Emergency Management, Preparedness Planning and Review Committee. 
(b)	The director shall work with the city to make assessments of personnel, businesses and industries, resources and facilities of the city as deemed necessary to determine their adequacy for emergency management and to plan for their most efficient use in time of an emergency, major incident or disaster. 
(c)	The director shall prepare a comprehensive emergency plan for the emergency preparedness of the city and shall present such plan to the city for its approval. When the council has approved the plan by motion, it shall be the duty of all city agencies and all emergency preparedness forces of the city to perform the duties and functions assigned by the plan as approved. The plan may be modified in like manner from time to time. The director shall coordinate the basic emergency management activities of the city to the end that they shall be consistent and fully integrated with the basic emergency plan of the Lake Minnetonka Regional Emergency Management, Preparedness Planning and Review Committee, and federal and state governments. 
(d)	In accordance with the emergency plan, the director shall institute such training programs, public information programs and conduct practice warning alerts and emergency exercises as may be necessary to assure prompt and effective operation of the emergency plan when a disaster, major incident or mutual aid occurs. 
(e)	The director, in communication with the mayor and administrator during an emergency, major incident or mutual aid, shall utilize the personnel, services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments and agencies of the city to the maximum extent practicable. The officers and personnel of all such departments and agencies shall be, to the maximum extent practicable, cooperative with and extend such services and facilities to the emergency management organization. The head of each department or agency in cooperation with the director shall be responsible for the planning and programming of such emergency activities as will involve the utilization of the facilities of the department or agency. 
(f)	The director shall, in cooperation with the existing departments and agencies affected, assist in the organizing, recruiting and training of such emergency management personnel that may be required on a volunteer basis to carry out the emergency plans. To the extent that such emergency personnel are recruited to augment a regular department or agency for emergencies, they shall be assigned to such departments or agencies and shall be under the administration and control of such department or agency. 
(g)	The director shall carry out all orders, rules and regulations issued by the city with reference to emergency management. 
(h)	The director shall prepare and submit such reports on emergency preparedness activities as may be requested by the city. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 4, 11-2-1999) 
State Law reference- Responsibilities of the director of a local organization for emergency management, Minn. Stats. § 12.25, subd. 1. 
Sec. 14-33. - Authorizing dispatch and use of city equipment and services by the director in emergency situations (mutual aid). 
(a)	The city finds it desirable and necessary to authorize the director to dispatch city equipment and personnel to local communities who request aid to combat their emergency, disaster, or major incident consistent with this chapter, and section 14-32. 
(b)	The director shall evaluate the internal needs of the city and dispatch appropriate available aid. The director shall immediately recall, order and terminate the use of any dispatched equipment and personnel when the need for their use no longer exists, or earlier, when it appears in the best interest of the city. Aid requested from outside the Lake Minnetonka Regional area, or extended local aid within the Lake Minnetonka Regional area, shall require mutual agreement between the director and the city manager/administrator or his designee. 
(c)	The director shall be fully authorized as an agent of the city; and all provisions for compensation of personnel, rental of equipment, liability insurance coverage, worker's compensation insurance and all other safeguards and matters pertaining to the city, its equipment and personnel, shall apply in each case as if specifically authorized and directed at such time, whether or not the governing body or authority of the place in which the disaster, major incident, mutual aid or other occurrence exists has previously requested and provided for assistance and the use of equipment and personnel under a mutual protection agreement or other type protection agreement within the city. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 9, 11-2-1999) 
State Law reference- Authority to delegate authority to dispatch equipment and personnel for the purpose of providing mutual aid to an emergency or disaster area outside of the political subdivision, Minn. Stats. § 12.27, subd. 3. 
Secs. 14-34-14-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCIES 

Sec. 14-61. - Local emergencies. 
(a)	A local emergency, including a disaster, major incident or mutual aid response, may be declared by the mayor or his legal successors. It shall not be continued for a period in excess of three days except by or with the consent of the governing body of the city. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing or terminating a local emergency shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly by the city administrator. 
State Law reference- Authority to declare a local emergency, Minn. Stats. § 12.29. 
(b)	A declaration of a local emergency shall invoke necessary portions of the response and recovery aspects of applicable plans, including fiscal expenditures that are consistent with this article, and that shall previously have been deemed necessary and approved by the city council. 
State Law reference- Effect of declaration of emergency, Minn. Stats. § 12.29, subd. 2. 
(c)	No interjurisdictional agency or official may declare a local emergency unless expressly authorized by the agreement under which the agency functions. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 5, 11-2-1999) 
State Law reference- Role of interjurisdictional agencies in declaration of local emergency, Minn. Stats. § 12.29, subd. 3. 
Sec. 14-62. - Emergency regulations. 
(a)	Whenever necessary to meet a declared emergency or to prepare for such an emergency for which adequate regulations have not been adopted by the governor or the city council, the council may by resolution promulgate regulations, consistent with the applicable federal or state law or regulation, respecting: 
(1)	The conduct of persons and the use of property during emergencies; 
(2)	The repair, maintenance and safeguarding of essential public services, emergency health, fire and safety regulation, drills or practice periods required for preliminary training; and 
(3)	All other matters which are required to protect public safety, health and welfare in declared emergencies. 
(b)	Every resolution of emergency regulations shall be in writing, shall be dated, shall refer to the particular emergency to which it pertains if so limited, and shall be filed in the office of the city administrator, which copy shall be kept posted and available for public inspection during business hours. Notice of the existence of such regulation and its availability for inspection at the administrator's office shall be conspicuously posted at the front of the city hall or other headquarters of the city or at such other places in the affected area as the council shall designate in the resolution. By like resolution, the council may modify or rescind any such regulation. 
(c)	The city council may rescind any such regulation by resolution at any time. If not sooner rescinded, every such regulation shall expire at the end of 30 days after its effective date or at the end of the emergency to which it relates, whichever comes first. Any resolution, rule or regulation inconsistent with an emergency regulation promulgated by the council shall be suspended during the period of time and to the extent such conflict exists. 
(d)	During a declared emergency, the director is, notwithstanding any statutory or charter provision on the contrary, empowered through its governing body acting within or without the corporate limits of the city, to enter into contracts and incur obligations necessary to combat such disaster by protecting the health and safety of persons and property and providing emergency assistance to the victims of such disaster. The director may exercise such powers in the light of the exigencies of the disaster without compliance with the time-consuming procedures and formalities prescribed by law pertaining to the performance of public work, entering rental equipment agreements, purchase of supplies and materials, limitations upon tax levies, and the appropriation and expenditure of public funds, including but not limited to publication of resolutions, publication of call for bids, provisions of personnel laws and rules, provisions relating to low bids and requirements for budgets. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 6, 11-2-1999) 
State Law reference- Authority to enter into contracts, incur obligations, and exercise the powers vested in local governments by the Minnesota Emergency Management Act of 1996, Minn. Stats. § 12.37. 
Sec. 14-63. - Emergency management a governmental function. 
    All functions and all activities relating to emergency management are declared to be governmental functions. The city and (except for willful misconduct) its officers, agents or employees, when engaged in emergency services activities, shall not be liable for damage to person or property. The provisions of this section shall not affect the right of any person to receive benefits to which he would otherwise be entitled under this chapter or under the worker's compensation law, or under any pension law, nor the right of any such person to receive any benefits or compensation under any act of Congress. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 7, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 14-64. - Participation in labor dispute or politics. 
    The emergency management organization shall not participate in any form of political activity, nor shall it be employed directly or indirectly for political purposes, nor shall it be employed in a labor dispute. The director may express professional opinions on legislative or other legal regulations consistent with the areas found in Minn. Stats. ch. 12. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 8, 11-2-1999) 
State Law reference- No emergency management organization shall participate in political activity or be employed for political purposes or in a legitimate labor dispute, Minn. Stats. § 12.44. 
Chapter 16 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) ---

ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC NUISANCES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisance dog, § 6-121 et seq.; no nuisance allowed, § 10-427; nuisances at waterways, § 40-61 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to define nuisances and provide for their prevention or abatement, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 23. 

Sec. 16-31. - Prohibition. 
    No person shall commit or maintain any public nuisance within the city. 
(Code 1989, § 550.01) 
Sec. 16-32. - Public nuisance defined. 
    An intentional act or failure to perform a legal duty resulting in any of the following constitutes a public nuisance: 
(1)	Maintaining or permitting a condition which unreasonably annoys, injures or endangers the safety, health, morals, comfort or repose of any considerable number of members of the public; 
(2)	Interfering with, obstructing, or rendering dangerous for passage any public highway or right-of-way, or waters used by the public; or 
(3)	Engaging in any other act or omission declared by law to be a public nuisance; 
whether or not such act or condition is listed in sections 16-33-16-35. 
(Code 1989, § 550.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Elements of public nuisance, Minn. Stats. § 609.74; acts constituting a public nuisance, Minn. Stats. § 617.81, subd. 2. 
Sec. 16-33. - Public nuisances endangering health. 
    The following are declared to be nuisances endangering public health: 
(1)	The effluence from any cesspool, septic tank, drainfield or sewage disposal system discharging upon the surface of the ground. 
(2)	Accumulation of manure, rubbish, tin cans or other debris. 
(3)	The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream or lake, canal or body of water by sewage, industrial waste or other substance. 
(4)	Outdoor toilets. 
(Code 1989, § 550.03) 
State Law reference- Authority to define the unsafe use, maintenance or abandonment of cesspools as a public nuisance and to abate them, Minn. Stats. § 471.92, subd. 1; unsealed wells are public nuisances which can be regulated by city ordinances, Minn. Stats. § 103I, subd. 6. 
Sec. 16-34. - Public nuisances endangering peace and safety. 
    The following are declared to be nuisances endangering public peace and safety: 
(1)	Trees, hedges, signs, billboards, fences or other obstructions which interfere with the maintenance of rights-of-way or which hinder persons using any right-of-way from seeing traffic. 
(2)	The piling, storing or keeping of old machinery, junk or debris. 
(3)	The unhoused storage of pipe, lumber, forms, machinery, old unlicensed wrecked or junked cars or car bodies, other than occupational material. 
(4)	The unlawful interference with, obstruction or tendency to obstruct or render dangerous for passage a lake, stream, lagoon, canal or basin, or a public park, square, street, alley or highway. 
(5)	Any act or condition which, in any way, renders the public insecure in life or in its use of property. 
(Code 1989, § 550.04) 
Sec. 16-35. - Buildings or structures as public nuisances. 
    Any building or structure is a public nuisance which is dangerous to public safety or health or to other property by reason of: 
(1)	Damage by fire; 
(2)	Defective chimneys or decay; 
(3)	Dilapidated condition or decay; 
(4)	Defective electric wiring; 
(5)	Defective gas installation; 
(6)	Defective heating apparatus; 
(7)	Defective sewage disposal system or plumbing; 
(8)	Any other defect endangering the public safety, health or other property; 
including those addressed in section 8-151 et seq. 
(Code 1989, § 550.05) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8. 
State Law reference- Authority to remove or raze any hazardous building or remove or correct any hazardous condition of real estate, Minn. Stats. § 463.15 et seq., Minn. Rules § 1305.0102. 
Sec. 16-36. - Enforcement. 
    Any public nuisance as described in sections 16-33 and 16-34 shall be abated in accordance with the procedures set out in Minn. Stats. §§ 463.15 et seq., 14.57 et seq., and Minn. Rules §§ 1400.5100-1400.8400. Orders shall be issued and hearings conducted by a city employee or other qualified person designated by the council. Any public nuisance as described in section 16-35 shall be abated in accordance with the building code of the city, section 8-31, Minn. Stats. § 463.151 et seq., and Minn. Rules § 1305.0102. The city inspector and/or city engineer may order other public nuisances abated. The order shall specify 48 hours or such longer time as is reasonably necessary for the abatement of the nuisance. The order shall be served upon the owner or lessee or occupant of the premises and shall be served by certified mail or by personal service. 
(Code 1989, § 550.06) 
State Law reference- Permitting a public nuisance constitutes a misdemeanor, Minn. Stats. § 609.745. 
Secs. 16-37-16-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Restrictions on noise for junk, § 10-423. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate and prevent noise, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 24; no local governing unit shall set standards describing the maximum levels of sound pressure which are more stringent than those set by the pollution control agency, Minn. Stats. § 116.07, subd. 2; the pollution control agency shall adopt standards describing maximum levels of noise, Minn. Stats. § 116.07, subds. 2-4. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Words or phrases defined in the rules of the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency Noise Section, chapter 7030, shall have the meanings given in those rules. 
    A-weighted means a specific weighting of the sound pressure level for the purpose of determining the human response to sound. The specific weighting characteristics and tolerances are those given in American National Standards Institute § 1.4-1983, section 5.1. 
    Cutout and bypass mean a mechanism which varies the exhaust system gas flow so as to discharge the exhaust gas and acoustic energy to the atmosphere without passing through the entire length of the system, including all exhaust system sound attenuation components. 
    dB(A) means a unit of sound level expressed in decibels (dB) and A-weighted. 
State Law reference- Definition of dB(A), MPCA Noise Rule § 7030.0020, subp. 4. 
    Exhaust system means a combination of components which provides an enclosed flow of exhaust gas from engine parts to the atmosphere. 
    Holiday means any day fixed by the United States or by state law for suspension of business in whole or in part. 
    L10 means the sound level, expressed in dB(A), which is exceeded ten percent of the time for a one-hour period, as measured by test procedures approved by the director of the MPCA. 
State Law reference- Definition of L10, MPCA Noise Rule § 7030.0020, subp. 7. 
    L50 means the sound level, expressed in dB(A), which is exceeded 50 percent of the time for a one-hour period, as measured by test procedures approved by the director of the MPCA. 
State Law reference- Definition of L50, MPCA Noise Rule § 7030.0020, subp. 8. 
    MPCA means the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency. 
    Noise means any sound not occurring in the natural environment, including but not limited to sounds emanating from airways, roadways, waterways, industrial, commercial and residential sources. 
State Law reference- Definition of noise, Minn. Stats. § 116.06, subd. 15. 
    Noise control officer (zoning administrator) means the zoning administrator or other person appointed by the city council. 
    Noise pollution means the presence of any noise or combination of noises in such quantity, at such levels, or of such nature and duration, or under such conditions as could potentially be injurious to human health, safety or welfare; or to animal life; or could interfere unreasonably with the enjoyment of life or property. 
State Law reference- Definition of noise pollution, Minn. Stats. § 116.06, subd. 16. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, trustee, association, the state and its agencies and subdivisions, or any body of persons whether incorporated or not, except the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency. With respect to acts prohibited or required in this article, the term shall include employees and licensees. 
(Code 1989, § 510.01; Ord. No. 3-21-95, § 1, 3-23-1995) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 16-72. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)	Enforcement. 
(1)	When the zoning administrator, after appropriate testing has been done, determines that a noise exceeds the maximum sound level permitted under this article, or otherwise constitutes a nuisance, the noise control officer shall give written notice of the violation to the owner or occupant of the premises where the noise originates, and order such person to correct or remove each specified violation within such reasonable time as is prescribed in the notice. 
(2)	In all other cases, the zoning administrator or the city's law enforcement officer may demand immediate termination of the excessive noise. Failure to adhere to such demand would subject the violator to appropriate criminal enforcement procedure. 
(b)	Penalties. Any person violating this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable in accordance with the provisions of section 1-13, and in addition shall be subject to injunctive relief which the city may exercise to pursue through a court of competent jurisdiction or state administrative agency as may be appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 3-21-95, § 7, 3-23-1995) 
Secs. 16-73-16-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STANDARDS 

Sec. 16-91. - General noise standards. 
(a)	Incorporation by reference. The MPCA Noise Rule §§ 7030.0010-7030.1060, as amended and supplemented are referred to, adopted, incorporated by reference, and made a part of this article. A current copy shall be available for public inspection through the city clerk's office. 
(b)	Maximum noise levels by receiving land use districts. No person shall operate or cause or permit to be operated any source of noise in such a manner as to create a noise level outdoors exceeding the decibel limit set in table 1 for the receiving land use district specified.

(Ord. No. 3-21-95, § 2, 3-23-1995) 
State Law reference- Noise standards, MPCA Noise Rule § 7030.0040, subp. 2. 
Secs. 16-92-16-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXEMPTIONS 

Sec. 16-111. - Nonapplicability. 
(a)	The levels prescribed in section 16-91 do not apply to noise originating on public streets and alleys but such noise shall be subject to ordinances enacted from time to time by the city. 
(b)	The levels prescribed in table 1 do not apply to farm machinery being operated by a person actively engaged in productive agricultural operations provided the machinery is not stationary. 
(c)	The levels prescribed in table 1 do not apply to the Church of St. George of Long Lake when it rings the church bells for the purpose of calling its congregation to church services, and to times of worship. 
(d)	The levels prescribed in table 1 do not apply to special citywide events approved by the city council, which shall be preceded by an application for the special citywide event to be exempt from the noise standards, and a finding of the city council that the proposed event will not adversely affect the citizens of the city, and is otherwise consistent with the public health, safety and welfare of the city. 
(e)	The levels prescribed in table 1 do not apply to trains operating on the existing train track through the city so long as the use complies with all other applicable county, state and federal standards and such use is not in any manner expanded in terms of scope or duration. 
(Ord. No. 3-21-95, § 2, 3-23-1995) 
Secs. 16-112-16-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PROHIBITIONS 

Sec. 16-131. - Noises prohibited. 
(a)	Home, audible and signaling devices, etc. No person shall sound any signaling device on any vehicle except as a warning of danger; and no horn or other warning device shall emit an unreasonably loud or harsh sound or a whistle, Minn. Stats. § 169.68. 
(b)	Engine exhausts. 
(1)	No person shall discharge the exhaust or permit the discharge of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motorboat, motor vehicle, motorcycle, all-terrain vehicle, snowmobile or any recreational device except through a muffler or other device that effectively prevents loud or explosive noises and complies with all applicable state laws and regulations and city ordinances. 
(2)	No exhaust system on any engine shall be modified, altered or repaired in any manner, including the use of a muffler cutout or bypass, that shall amplify or otherwise increase noise above that emitted by the device as originally equipped. 
(c)	Radios, phonographs, televisions, paging systems, etc. No person shall use or operate or permit the use or operation of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, television, paging system, machine or other device for production or reproduction of sound in a distinctly and loudly audible manner so as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of any person nearby. Operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or other device between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., in such a manner as to be plainly audible at the property line of the structure or building in which it is located, or at a distance of 50 feet if the source is located outside a structure or building, shall be prima facie evidence of violation of this section. 
(d)	Social gatherings. 
(1)	No person shall participate in any party or other gathering of people giving rise to noise which disturbs the peace, quiet or repose of the occupants of adjoining or other property. When a police officer determines that a gathering is creating such noise disturbance, the officer shall order all persons present, other than the owner or tenant of the premises where the disturbance is occurring, to disperse immediately. No person shall refuse to leave after being ordered by a police officer to do so. Every owner or tenant of such premises who has knowledge of the disturbance shall cooperate with police officers and shall make every reasonable effort to see that the disturbance is abated. 
(2)	A violation of this subsection shall be deemed to be the act of the owner of the residential dwelling unit wherein it occurs as well as the persons on the premises who violate this subsection, except that the owner of the dwelling unit occupied by others shall be liable only for those violations occurring after a written notice of the violation of this subsection shall have been received. 
(e)	Loudspeakers, amplifiers for advertising, etc. No person shall operate or permit the use or operation of any loudspeaker, sound amplifier, or other device for the production or reproduction of sound on a street or other public place for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public for any purpose whatsoever. 
(f)	Schools, churches, etc. No person shall create any excessive noise on a street, alley or public grounds adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or other place of worship. 
(g)	Human noise. No person shall engage in yelling, shouting, screaming, whistling or singing at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of any persons in any office, dwelling, hotel, motel, other place of residence, or in the vicinity of the source. 
(h)	Animal noises. 
(1)	It shall be unlawful for any owner to fail to exercise proper care and control over his animals to prevent them from engaging in excessive noise such as barking excessively, continuously or untimely. Failure on the part of the owner or custodian to prevent his animals from engaging in excessive noise shall subject the owner or custodian to the penalty provided in this article. 
(2)	The term "to bark excessively, continuously or untimely" includes but is not limited to the creation of any noise by any dog which can be heard by any person, including a law enforcement officer or animal control officer, from a location outside the building or premises where the dog is being kept and which noise occurs for repeatedly over at least a ten-minute period of time with one minute or less lapse of time between each animal noise during the ten-minute period. 
(Code 1989, § 510.01(4), (5); Ord. No. 3-21-95, § 3, 3-23-1995) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate and prevent noise or other disorder, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 24. 
Sec. 16-132. - Hourly restriction for certain operations. 
(a)	Domestic power equipment. No person shall operate a garden or lawn tractor, power lawn mower, power hedge clipper, chain saw, mulcher, garden tiller, edger, power device for bug eradication, drill, or other similar domestic power maintenance equipment except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. on any weekday or between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekends and holidays. Snow removal equipment is exempt from this subsection. 
(b)	Refuse hauling. No person shall collect or remove garbage or refuse in any residential district except during hours approved from time to time by the city council. 
(c)	Construction activities. No person shall engage in or permit construction activities involving the use of any electric, diesel or gas-powered machine or other power equipment except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. weekdays or between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. any weekends or holidays. 
(Ord. No. 3-21-95, § 4, 3-23-1995) 
Secs. 16-133-16-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - EXCEPTIONS 

Sec. 16-151. - Permit. 
    Any person desiring to use sound amplification equipment contrary to the provisions of this division or to create noise pollution may be permitted to do so by the council. Application to the council shall be made in advance of the proposed event and shall be granted only upon such reasonable conditions as the council may impose. The applicant shall be required to comply with all conditions placed upon the permit and shall sign the permit, which shall state the conditions upon which it is allowed. Any violation of the conditions of the permit shall constitute a violation of this division. The permit shall require that the permittee have present at all times an individual to monitor the sound levels to ensure that they remain within reasonable limits. The permit shall be specific as to time and area. 
(Code 1989, § 510.02) 
Sec. 16-152. - Exception for emergency work. 
    Noise created exclusively in the performance of emergency work to preserve the public health, safety or welfare, or in the performance of emergency work necessary to restore public service or eliminate a public hazard shall be exempt from the provisions of this article for a period not to exceed 48 hours after the work is commenced. Persons responsible for such work shall inform the noise control officer of the need to initiate such work or, if the work is commenced during nonbusiness hours of the city, at the beginning of business hours of the first day thereafter. Any person responsible for such emergency work shall take all reasonable actions to minimize the amount of noise and its duration. 
(Ord. No. 3-21-95, § 5, 3-23-1995) 
Secs. 16-153-16-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - ZONING ADMINISTRATOR[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq.; planning and development, ch. 26. 

Sec. 16-171. - Powers and duties. 
(a)	Administering officer. The noise control program established by this article shall be administered by the zoning administrator. 
(b)	Testing procedures. The zoning administrator shall adopt guidelines establishing the test procedures and instrumentation used in enforcing the provisions of this article. A copy of such guidelines shall be kept in the office of the city clerk and shall be available to the public for reference during business hours. 
(c)	Investigation and inspection. The zoning administrator, with the assistance of other professional agencies or persons as may be necessary, shall conduct all research monitoring and other studies related to sound as are necessary in order to enforce this article and shall make all investigations and inspections in accordance with law as required in applying the provisions of this article. 
(d)	Noise impact statements. The zoning administrator may require any person applying to the city for a change in zoning classification, permit, license for any structure, operation, process, installation, or alteration or project that may be considered a potential noise source to submit a noise impact statement on a form prescribed by the zoning administrator. Each such statement shall be reviewed to ascertain whether the granting of such change in zoning classification, permit or license would result in the violation of any provision of this article. Reviews of noise impact statements shall be made by the zoning committee, planning commission if appropriate, and recommendations shall be made to the city council. 
(e)	Other powers and duties. The zoning administrator shall exercise such other powers and perform such other duties as are reasonable and necessary to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3-21-95, § 6, 3-23-1995) 
State Law reference- Measurement methodology, MPCA Noise Rule § 7030.0060. 
Secs. 16-172-16-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TREES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 38. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-201. - Planting, maintenance and removal. 
(a)	Duties of forester. 
(1)	The forester, as appointed by the city administrator, for the purposes of this section shall identify diseased and hazardous trees that threaten the health and safety of the public and coordinate all activities of the city relating to the control and prevention of tree diseases. 
(2)	The forester shall identify and describe significant trees in any proposed subdivision or development project, and assist planners, developers, and architects in the development of a tree preservation plan for each construction development project. 
(3)	The forester shall maintain a list of desirable trees for planting on public lands with a definition of the size classes (small, medium, large) for each species. 
(4)	The forester shall promulgate and enforce, and all persons shall obey, rules, regulations and specifications concerning the trimming, spraying, removal, planting, pruning and protection of trees, shrubs, vines, hedges and other plants upon the right-of-way of any street, alley, park or other city-owned property. 
(5)	The forester shall promulgate and enforce a tree preservation policy approved by the city council to protect significant trees on public and private property. 
(b)	Placement and care of trees. 
(1)	Placement. Trees along streets and boulevards as well as trees located upon city-owned property shall be planted no closer together than: (i) 30 feet for small trees; (ii) 40 feet for medium trees; (iii) 50 feet for large trees, applying size definitions promulgated by the forester under subsection (a)(3) of this section. Plantings at less than the minimum spacing described in this section may be allowed with forester approval. When planting to create a screen, size, variety and spacing will be approved by the forester. 
(2)	Utilities. Only small trees (as defined under subsection (a)(3) of this section) shall be allowed to be planted on city-owned property under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire or within five lateral feet of any underground utility or water or sewer line. 
(3)	Disturbance of trees. 
a.	No person shall trim, cut, prune or otherwise eliminate growth from any tree on public property without a permit. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees located under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this policy at the determination of the forester. 
b.	No person shall plant, remove, cut above the ground, or disturb any tree on any street, park, or other city-owned property without first filing an application and producing a permit from the forester. Persons receiving such a permit shall abide by applicable requirements under the city Code. 
c.	No person shall violate the tree preservation policy promulgated by the forester under subsection (a)(5) of this section. 
(Ord. of 7-18-2000) 
Secs. 16-202-16-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SHADE TREE DISEASE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 38. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt an ordinance delineating a shade tree disease control program more stringent than that of the commissioner of agriculture, Minn. Stats. § 18.023, subd. 3. 

Sec. 16-221. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to establish a shade tree program, providing regulation for the control of certain diseases affecting trees, incorporating agency rules and regulations, and providing for penalty for violation of this division. 
(Code 1989, § 530.01) 
Sec. 16-222. - Regulations adopted by reference. 
    Minn. Rules §§ 1505.0010-1505.0380, relating to shade tree disease program, as amended, are adopted by reference and made a part of this division as if fully set out in this division, except as modified or amended in this section. One copy of the rules is on file and available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1989, § 530.02) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt by reference any statute, code or pertinent administrative rule of any department of the state, Minn. Stats. § 471.62. 
Sec. 16-223. - Stockpiling. 
    The stockpiling of bark bearing elm wood within the city is permitted during the period from September 15 through April 1 of any given year. Any such wood not utilized by April 1 of any year must then be removed and disposed of as provided by this division and the regulations incorporated by this division. 
(Code 1989, § 530.03) 
State Law reference- Stockpiling and storage of elm logs, Minn. Rules § 1505.0250. 
Sec. 16-224. - Dutch elm disease control policy declaration. 
    The council intends, through the following policy, to control and prevent the spread of the Dutch elm disease, which is threatening the health of the elm trees within the city: 
(1)	Tree inspector. The powers and duties of the tree inspector as set forth in this section are conferred upon the operations superintendent. It is the duty of the tree inspector to coordinate, under the direction and control of the council, all activities of the city relating to the control and prevention of Dutch elm disease. He shall recommend to the council the details of a program for the control of Dutch elm disease, and perform the duties incident to such a program adopted by the council. 
State Law reference- Qualifications of a tree inspector, Minn. Rules § 1505.0050. 
(2)	Dutch elm disease program. The council intends to conduct a program of plant pest control pursuant to all the powers of this city, including the authority granted by Minn. Stats. § 18.023. This program is directed specifically at the control and elimination of Dutch elm disease fungus and elm bark beetles and is undertaken at the recommendation of the state commissioner of agriculture. The city tree inspector shall act as coordinator between the commissioner of agriculture and the council in the conduct of this program. 
(3)	Nuisances declared. The following things are public nuisances whenever they may be found within the city: 
a.	Any living or standing elm tree infected to any degree with the Dutch elm disease fungus Ceratocystis ulmi (buisman) moreau or which harbors any of the elm bark beetle Scolytus multistriatus (eichh.) or Hylungopinus rufipes (marsh); 
b.	Any dead elm tree, including legs, branches, stumps, firewood or other elm material from which the bark has not been removed and burned or sprayed with an effective elm bark beetle insecticide. 
(4)	Abatement. It is unlawful for any person to permit any public nuisance to remain on any premises owned or controlled by him within the city. Such nuisances may be abated in the manner prescribed by this subsection. 
(5)	Inspection and investigation. 
a.	Annual inspection. The tree inspector shall inspect all premises and places within the city at least three times during the growing season, by June 15, July 15, and August 15 to determine whether any condition described in subsection (3) exists there. He shall investigate all reported incidents of infestation by Dutch elm fungus or elm bark beetles. 
b.	Entry on private premises. The tree inspector or his duly authorized agents may, upon prior reasonable notification, enter upon private premises at any reasonable time for the purpose of carrying out the duties assigned him under this subsection. 
State Law reference- Reasonable notice of inspection required, Minn. Stats. § 18.023, subd. 2. 
c.	Diagnosis. The tree inspector shall, upon finding conditions indicating Dutch elm infestation, immediately send appropriate specimens or samples to the state commissioner of agriculture tree disease laboratory for analysis, or take such other steps for diagnosis as may be recommended by the commissioner. Except as provided in subsection (7), no action to remove infected trees or wood shall be taken until positive diagnosis of the disease has been made. 
State Law reference- Methods of identifying diseased shade trees, Minn. Rules § 1505.0130. 
(6)	Abatement of Dutch elm disease nuisances. In abating the nuisances defined in subsection (3), the tree inspector shall cause the infected tree or wood to be sprayed, removed, burned or otherwise effectively treated so as to destroy and prevent as fully as possible the spread of Dutch elm disease fungus and elm bark beetles. Such abatement procedures shall be carried out in accordance with current technical and expert opinions and plans as may be designated by the commissioner of agriculture. 
State Law reference- Methods of disposal include burning, burying, chipping, and utilization, Minn. Rules § 1505.0230. 
(7)	Procedure for removal of infected trees and wood. 
a.	Whenever the tree inspector finds with reasonable certainty that the infestation defined in subsection (3) exists in any tree or wood in any public or private place in the city, he shall proceed as follows: 
1.	If the tree inspector finds that the danger of infestation of other elm trees is low risk because symptoms reflect early stages of infection not progressing beyond the 30 percent wilting point, he shall make a written report of his finding to the council, which shall proceed by abating the nuisance as a public improvement under Minn. Stats. ch. 429 or abating the nuisance as provided in subsection (6). 
State Law reference- Obligation of tree inspector to identify whether a tree infected with Dutch elm disease has extensive wilt or is showing only early symptoms of the disease, and categorize trees infected with Dutch elm disease as either high-risk trees or low-risk trees, Minn. Rules § 1505.0180. 
2.	If the tree inspector finds that danger of infestation of other elm trees is high-risk, that is, the trees are dead, barren or have extensive wilt (30 percent or more of the tree is wilted), he shall notify the abutting property owner by certified mail that the nuisance will be abated within a specified time, not less than five days from the date of mailing of such notice. The tree inspector shall immediately report such action to the council; and after the expiration of the time limited by the notice, he may abate the nuisance. 
b.	Upon receipt of the tree inspector's report required by subsection (7)a.1. of this section, the council may by resolution order the nuisance abated. Before action is taken on such resolution, the council shall publish notice of its intention to meet to consider taking action to abate the nuisance. This notice shall be mailed to affected property owners and published once no less than one week prior to such meeting. The notice shall state the time and place of the meeting, the streets affected, action proposed, the estimated cost of the abatement, and the proposed bases of assessment, if any, of costs. At such hearing or adjournment of such meeting, the council shall hear property owners with reference to the scope and desirability of the proposed project. The council shall thereafter adopt a resolution confirming the original resolution with such modifications as it considers desirable and provide for the doing of the work by day labor or contract. Every reasonable effort shall be made to remove all low-risk trees on private and public property within 20 days of notification, but in no case shall it be later than April 1 of the following year. 
c.	The tree inspector shall keep a record of the costs of abatements done under this subsection and shall report monthly to the city clerk all work done for which assessments are to be made, stating and certifying the description of the land, lots and parcels involved and the amount chargeable to each. 
d.	On or before September 1 of each year, the clerk shall list the total unpaid charges for each abatement against each separate lot or parcel to which they are attributable under this subsection. The council may then spread the charges or any portion of the charges against the property involved as a special assessment under Minn. Stats. § 429.101 and other pertinent statutes for certification to the county auditor and collection the following year along with current taxes. 
(8)	Spraying elm trees. 
a.	Whenever the tree inspector determines that any elm tree or elm wood within the city is infected with Dutch elm fungus, he may spray or treat all nearby high-value elm trees, with an effective elm bark beetle destroying concentrate or fungicide or both. Activities authorized by this subsection shall be conducted in accordance with technical and expert opinions and plans of the commissioner of agriculture and under the supervision of the commissioner and his agents whenever possible. 
b.	The notice provisions of subsection (7) apply to spraying and treatment operations conducted under this subsection. 
(9)	Transporting elm wood prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to transport within the city any bark-bearing elm wood without having obtained a permit from the tree inspector. The tree inspector shall grant such permits only when the purposes of this section will be served. 
(10)	Interference prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the tree inspector or his agents while they are engaged in the performance of duties imposed by this section. 
(Code 1989, § 530.04) 
Sec. 16-225. - Conflicts. 
    Where the provisions of this division conflict or are inconsistent with any other section of this Code, the provisions of this division shall supercede except in instances where one regulation is more restrictive than another, in which case the more restrictive shall apply and control. 
(Code 1989, § 530.05) 
Chapter 18 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; restrictions on no burning of junk, § 10-422; burning prohibited on public roads, § 20-2. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt by reference any ordinance or regulation specifying requirements equal to, in addition to, or more stringent than the requirements of the Uniform Fire Code, Minn. Stats. § 299F.011, subd. 4. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Purpose. 
    The city council is concerned with safeguarding of life and property to a reasonable degree from hazards of fire and explosion. Pursuant to the powers and jurisdictions vested through Minnesota Statutes and other applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations, the city council does hereby adopt this chapter and the Minnesota Uniform Fire Code (referred to in this chapter as the fire code) for the purpose of establishing reasonable regulations, administration and enforcement for the prevention, control and extinguishment of fires; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees where required by the fire code, and providing penalties for violation of fire code regulations. 
(Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.100), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-2. - Interference with fire department. 
    No person shall give or make, or cause to be given or made, a fire alarm without probable cause, or neglect or refuse to obey any reasonable order of the chief of the fire department at a fire, or interfere with the fire department in the discharge of its duties. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(12); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.112), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, the fire code or the fire marshal division alterations and amendments, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building official means the individual certified by the state and appointed by the city council to administer and enforce the building codes within the city. 
    Chief means the chief of the volunteer fire department, or authorized representative, except that for the purposes of enforcement of this chapter, the term "chief" shall also include those persons listed in section 18-111. 
    Corporation counsel means the attorney for the city. 
    Jurisdiction and municipality mean the City of Long Lake as a whole. 
(Code 1989, § 570.03(3b); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.203), 8-6-2002) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-4. - Interpretation and conflict. 
(a)	Minimum requirements. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the protection of the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(b)	Conflict with public provisions. This chapter is not intended to interfere with, abrogate, or annul any other ordinance, rule or regulation, statute, or other provision by law. Where any provision of this chapter imposes restrictions different from those imposed by any other provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance, rule or regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provisions are more restrictive or impose higher standards shall control. 
(Code 1989, § 570.25(1); Ord. No. 162, § 2, 8-6-2002) 
Secs. 18-5-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 18-31. - Fire department. 
    The fire department for the city shall be a volunteer fire department consisting of not fewer than 20 nor more than 35 firefighters, including up to eight officers. Officers shall be nominated by the fire chief and appointed after confirmation by the city council. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(1); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.101), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-32. - Appointment. 
    The chief of the fire department and the assistant chief shall be elected for two-year terms by the members of the department, subject to approval by the city administrator and confirmation by the city council. Each shall hold office until a successor has been duly elected, except that they may be removed by the council for cause after a public hearing. Firefighters and probationary firefighters shall be nominated by the members of the department, for approval by the city administrator and confirmation by the city council. All firefighters are required to complete a city employment application, background investigation, physical examination, and physical agility test, to be considered for employment as a probationary firefighter. Following one year as a probationary firefighter, the department may nominate the probationary member for confirmation by the city council as a firefighter. The department shall submit the necessary documentation that the probationary member has demonstrated satisfactory performance and met the minimum requirements of the position. At the first council meeting after nomination, the council shall vote to either confirm or refuse to confirm the nominee. Firefighters shall continue as members of the department during good behavior and may be removed by the council only for cause after a public hearing. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(2); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.102), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-33. - Duties of fire marshal. 
    The office of fire marshal may be held by the fire chief, or by the chief's designee, if approved by a resolution of the council. The fire marshal shall be charged with the enforcement of all ordinances aimed at fire prevention. The fire marshal shall have full authority to inspect all premises and to cause the removal or abatement of all fire hazards. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(3); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.103), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-34. - Duties of chief. 
    The chief of the fire department shall report directly to the city administrator and perform the duties as outlined in the position description. The chief shall have control of all the firefighting apparatus and shall be solely responsible for its care and condition. The chief shall make an annual report to the city council at its first regular meeting in January. The annual report shall include information on the condition of the equipment and needs of the fire department. The chief may submit additional reports and recommendations at any meeting of the council. The purchase of any vehicle or equipment to be used by the fire department, whether the acquisition is by purchase, lease, or donation, shall require prior approval of the city council. The chief shall also have control over the daily operations of the department and the conduct of its members. All disciplinary actions beyond a verbal reprimand and temporary suspension must be preauthorized by the city administrator. The fire chief shall report each temporary suspension of a member of the fire department at the first meeting of the council following such suspension. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(4); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.104), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-35. - Records. 
    The fire chief shall keep in convenient form a complete record of all emergency incidents, including fires. Such a record shall include the time of the incident, location of the incident, cause of incident (if known), persons involved, type of building including name of owner and tenant (if applicable), purpose for which occupied, value of building and contents (if known), members of the fire department responding to the alarm, and such other information the chief may deem advisable or as may be required from time to time by the council or state. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(5); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.105), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-36. - Practice/training drills. 
    The fire chief, or the chief's designee, shall hold a minimum of one monthly practice/training drill of at least one hour's duration for the fire department and shall give or arrange for instruction to the firefighters in approved methods of firefighting, fire prevention, and medical training. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(6); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.106), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-37. - Assistant chief. 
    In the absence or disability of the fire chief, the assistant chief shall perform all the functions and exercise all of the authority of the chief. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(7); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.107), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-38. - Firefighters. 
(a)	The firefighters shall be able-bodied and not less than 18 years of age at the time of application for membership. They shall become members of the fire department only after a one-year probationary period and upon satisfactory completion of firefighter I training or the equivalent fire department, state, and NFPA approved training. Each candidate, before he or she may become a probationary firefighter, must be in acceptable physical condition and meet any other physical and mental qualifications which may be specified by the fire chief or council; and each must pass satisfactorily a physical examination which must include a pre-employment drug test, and a physical exam administered by a licensed occupational health specialist to determine if the candidate's health and fitness is sufficient to meet the minimum requirements of the position as determined by the council. Firefighters shall be able to perform the job duties as outlined in the position description. 
(b)	Each candidate, before he or she may become a probationary firefighter, must undergo a thorough physical examination by a licensed occupational health specialist and submit such specialist's written report thereof with his or her city employment application for membership in the department. Such report shall contain a statement whether or not, in such specialist's opinion, there is any evidence of myocarditis, coronary sclerosis, or pneumonia or its sequel in the candidate at the time of the examination. Such a report shall be retained and permanently kept in the files of the fire department. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(8); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.108), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-39. - Compensation. 
    The members and officers of the fire department shall receive compensation as determined annually by the city council. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(9); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.109), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-40. - Present members. 
    No person who has passed the one-year probationary period and is a full member of the fire department at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be required to serve a probationary period before becoming a firefighter. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(10); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.110), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-41. - Relief association. 
    The members and officers of the fire department may organize themselves into a firefighters' relief association in accordance with the law. The mayor, city treasurer, and fire chief are ex officio members of the relief association. The mayor and the city treasurer, or their designees, shall attend all meetings of the relief association. The relief association shall hire an independent, professional, financial consultant to manage the pension assets of the association and to make an annual report to the city council. 
(Code 1989, § 570.02(11); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.111), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-42. - Active nonprobationary members. 
    The active nonprobationary members of the fire department may adopt bylaws regulating the volunteer members. The bylaws shall govern to the extent they are approved by the city council and conform to this article and other applicable law. The fire chief, along with any active nonprobationary member, has the right to recommend to the fire department membership a change in any bylaw. A bylaw change must be submitted in writing at a regular fire department business meeting and referred to the bylaws committee for review. The bylaw change request shall be presented to the membership no earlier than 30 days after the original request. A bylaw change requires at least 75 percent approval from a quorum of voting fire department members who are in good standing. A quorum shall constitute two-thirds of the voting members of the department. If a bylaw change is approved by the membership, the change will go into effect once it has been reviewed and approved by city council. Policies that are not bylaws must be approved by the city council before they become effective, and the chief shall request the input of the membership when appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.113), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-43. - Loss of membership. 
    To be in and remain in good standing in the fire department, each officer, member, or probationary member shall attend at least 70 percent of the meetings and trainings during a quarter and respond to no less than 20 percent of the emergency incidents, unless excused by the fire chief, during a quarter. The failure to so attend, without receiving prior approval from the fire chief, may be deemed sufficient cause for removal of the member from the fire department. The removal of a firefighter based on the failure to meet the attendance requirements, may be approved by 75 percent of the voting members at the next regular business meeting. Prior to voting, the member in question will be given the opportunity to explain his or her attendance record. Firefighters shall continue as members of the department during periods of good behavior, and may be removed by the city council only for cause after a public hearing; however, the fire chief shall have authority to suspend a member pending such public hearing and only after consultation and approval of the city administrator. A member shall receive no pay while suspended. 
(Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.114), 8-6-2002) 
Secs. 18-44-18-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE CODE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- The Uniform Fire Code shall be applicable throughout the state and in all political subdivisions and municipalities therein, Minn. Stats. § 299F.011, subd. 4. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-81. - Adoption. 
(a)	The Minnesota Uniform Fire Code (referred to in this chapter as fire code) has been adopted by Minnesota Laws as a uniform fire code applicable throughout the state. Such code is hereby confirmed as the fire code of the city. Every provision contained in the fire code, except as modified or amended in this article, is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as if fully set out in this article. One copy of this fire code shall be on file and available for public examination in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)	The Minnesota Uniform Fire Code adopted in this section shall mean the edition of the Uniform Fire Code, as promulgated by the International Conference of Building Officials and the Western Fire Chiefs Association, that is currently being used by the state fire marshal division rules and regulations, and all other nationally recognized fire safety standards such as referenced in the fire code. 
(Code 1989, §§ 570.01, 570.03(1), (2); Ord. No. 162, § 1((550.201), (550.202)), 8-6-2002) 
State Law reference- Authority to incorporate by reference any statute, any pertinent administrative rule, or code of Minnesota, Minn. Stats. § 471.62. 
Sec. 18-82. - Amendments. 
(a)	Purpose and authority. Pursuant to Minnesota Statutes, the city council hereby adopts the additions and amendments in this chapter to the standards contained in the state fire code for purposes of providing reasonable additional safeguards to life and property given the special conditions, topography, water supply, and general fire protection capabilities available in the city. 
(b)	Future amendments. As conditions described in this chapter change or otherwise warrant, the city council may from time to time add, amend, or delete provisions from this chapter. Public hearings on all proposed amendments shall be held by the city in the manner prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. 162, § 1((550.301), (550.302)), 8-6-2002) 
State Law reference- Amendments to appendixes of Uniform Fire Code as adopted by the Minnesota Uniform Fire Code, Minn. Rules § 7510.3710. 
Secs. 18-83-18-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 18-111. - Enforcement authority. 
    The provisions of this article and the fire code shall be enforced within the corporate limits of the city. Authority for enforcement is hereby granted to and may be exercised by any or all of the following persons, except where such authority is reserved by state statute as sole responsibility of the state fire marshal. 
(1)	The state fire marshal, or authorized representative. 
(2)	The chief of the volunteer fire department or authorized representative. 
(3)	The building official or authorized representative. 
(Code 1989, § 570.03(4); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.204), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-112. - Fire prevention inspection authorized. 
    The fire chief, or authorized representative, may conduct fire prevention inspections or educational programs within the city consistent with provisions of the fire code, standard practices of the volunteer fire department and applicable ordinances or resolutions of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.205), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-113. - Permits and fees. 
(a)	Wherever the fire code or this article requires a permit be issued for some activity or use of property, applications for the permit shall be made to the building official together with all information required by the building official or the fire chief and a permit application fee as required by the current city fee schedule. Payment of an application fee shall not in and of itself require issuance or approval of any permit. 
(b)	The building official shall refer all fire code permit applications to the fire chief of the volunteer fire department, or the chief's designee, who shall perform required prepermit inspections. The fire chief shall upon request by the building official supply a written report to the building official prior to permit issuance. 
(c)	The fire chief of the volunteer fire department shall issue fire code permits. One copy of each permit so issued shall be delivered to the building official for permanent record. 
(d)	No fire code permit shall be issued if the permit would authorize an activity or use of property or structures contrary to any provision of the fire code, the state statutes or this Code. 
(Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.206), 8-6-2002) 
State Law reference- Application for permits required under the Minnesota Uniform Fire Code, Minn. Rules § 7510.3520, subp. 3, secs. 105.3 and 105.8. 
Sec. 18-114. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the fire chief shall disapprove or refuse to grant a permit applied for under this article, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire code or this article do not apply, or that the true intent and meaning of the fire code has been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief to the city council within 30 days from the date of the decision. 
(Code 1989, § 570.20(1), (2); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.207), 8-6-2002) 
State Law reference- If a board of appeal is not appointed to hear appeals from orders under the fire code, appeal of orders must be made directly to the local governing body, Minn. Stats. § 299F.011, subd. 5a; appeals from decisions by the local governing body on issues arising from orders under the fire code must be made to the state fire marshal as a contested case in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act, Minn. Stats. § 299F.011, subd. 5, Minn. Rules § 7510.3520, subp. 2, sec. 103.1.4. 
Sec. 18-115. - New materials, processes or occupancies which may require permits. 
    The city clerk, building official and the fire chief shall together act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in the fire code. As they occur, such determinations shall be listed; such lists shall be posted in the offices of the city clerk, building official, and the fire chief, and distributed to all interested parties. 
(Code 1989, § 570.03(8); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.208), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-116. - Violations; penalties; remedies. 
(a)	Generally. Any person who fails to comply with or violates any of the provisions of the fire code or this article, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement or specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the city council or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment for a period not to exceed 90 days, or both, such fine and imprisonment pursuant to the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 335, § 5. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and, when not otherwise specified, each day that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)	Specific performance. The application of the penalty in subsection (a) of this section shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(c)	Civil enforcement. Appropriate actions and proceedings may be taken by law or in equity to prevent any violation of the provisions of these codes, to prevent unlawful construction, to recover damages, to restrain, correct or abate a violation, to prevent illegal occupancy of a building, or to prevent continued maintenance of prohibited conditions. These remedies shall be in addition to the penalties described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1989, § 570.20; Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.400), 8-6-2002) 
State Law reference- Violation of a provision of the Minnesota Uniform Fire Code shall constitute a misdemeanor, Minn. Stats. § 299F.011, subd. 6. 
Secs. 18-117-18-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISTRICT PROHIBITIONS 

Sec. 18-141. - Establishment of limits of districts in which storage of flammable or combustible liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited. 
    The limits referred to in sections 7902.2.2.1 and 7904.2.5.4.2 of the Minnesota Uniform Fire Code, in which the storage of flammable or combustible liquids is restricted, are established as follows: R-1, R-1A, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5, R-6, B-1, B-2, B-3 zoning districts. 
(Code 1989, § 570.03)

Sec. 18-142. - Establishments of limits in which storage of liquefied petroleum gases is prohibited.

(Code 1989, § 570.03) 
State Law reference- Liquefied petroleum gases, Minn. Rules § 7510.3670. 
Sec. 18-143. - Establishment of limits of districts in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is to be prohibited.

(Code 1989, § 570.03)

    The limits referred to in section 8001.1.1 of the Minnesota Uniform Fire Code, in which the storage of hazardous materials is prohibited or limited, is established as follows: all zoning districts. 
(Code 1989, § 570.03)
