DIVISION 4. - FIRE LANES 

Sec. 18-171. - Established. 
    The city council hereby determines that the health and safety of persons and property in the city is unduly jeopardized because motor vehicles and other objects tend to obstruct emergency access to buildings, exit doors, and fire hydrants, which obstruction often occurs on private property. In accordance with fire code articles, the city council hereby provides for the establishment of fire lanes for purposes of ensuring immediate unobstructed access for emergency vehicles and equipment. 
(Ord. No. 175, § 1(intro ¶), 5-7-1985; Code 1989, § 570.04(2) (intro ¶); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.303) (intro ¶)), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-172. - Parking in or obstructing fire lanes prohibited. 
    Whether located on public property or on private property, no person shall park or leave unattended any motor vehicle in any established fire lane, and no person shall otherwise obstruct any established fire lane at any time. Any vehicle found unattended in any fire lane may be impounded and towed by the police department in accordance with the provisions of section 34-231 et seq. for the disposal of illegally parked vehicles. 
(Code 1989, § 570.04; Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.307), 8-6-2002) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Fire department access, Uniform Fire Code, part III, art. 9, secs. 901 and 902, Minnesota Uniform Fire Code, Minn. Rules §§ 7510.3550, 904.1, 904.2. 
Sec. 18-173. - Appeals. 
    The owner of any property receiving an order to establish a fire lane may appeal all or part of the order to the city council by filing a written statement. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.303(e)), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-174. - Fire hydrants. 
    Whether marked or unmarked, fire lanes are hereby established at all public or private fire hydrants, which fire lanes shall extend ten feet on either side of the hydrant and 20 feet in front of the curb or pavement edge nearest the front of the hydrant. 
(Ord. No. 175, § 1(A), 5-7-1985; Code 1989, § 570.04(2)(A); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.303(a)), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-175. - Building exits. 
    Whether marked or unmarked, fire lanes are hereby established at all building exits required by the fire code or city building codes, which fire lanes shall extend ten feet in all directions from such exits. Where larger fire lanes are required, they shall be established and marked pursuant to sections 18-176 and 18-177. 
(Ord. No. 175, § 1(B), 5-7-1985; Code 1989, § 570.04(2)(B); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.303(b)), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-176. - Existing properties. 
    The chief of the fire department is hereby empowered to order the establishment, designation and maintenance of fire lanes on public or private property wherever and to whatever extent the chief determines is reasonably necessary to ensure open and unobstructed emergency access. In this determination the fire chief may confer with and accept the recommendations of the building official. Fire lane orders shall be in writing and shall be served in person or by registered letter upon the property owner of record or, in the case of commercial properties, may be served upon the tenant occupying the property. 
(Ord. No. 175, § 1(C), 5-7-1985; Code 1989, § 570.04(2)(C); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.303(c)), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-177. - New construction. 
    The building official, upon recommendation of the fire chief, may order the installation and designation of fire lanes and/or the installation or relocation of fire hydrants as a condition of issuance of any building permit, which conditions shall appear in writing on the face of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.303(d)), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-178. - Standards. 
    The actual size, location and extent of required fire lanes shall be determined by the fire chief in consideration of the particular access need and configuration on individual properties. As a minimum, all marked and designated fire lanes shall be at least 20 feet in unobstructed width, shall have at least 13 feet six inches of vertical clearance, shall where necessary provide for a turning radius of at least 50 feet, and shall be constructed of all-weather surfacing capable of carrying a vehicle axle loading of five tons (10,000 pounds). 
(Ord. No. 175, § 1(D), 5-7-1985; Code 1989, § 570.04(2)(D); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.304), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-179. - Signs and markings. 
    When a fire lane has been ordered to be established pursuant to sections 18-176 and 18-177, one or more permanent upright metal signs bearing the words "No Parking - Fire Lane," or similar words if approved by the fire chief, shall be placed designating the restricted area. The number, size and location of required signs shall be determined by the fire chief. 
(1)	When the fire lane is located on public property or within a public right-of-way, the required signs shall be erected by the city or by the public agency having jurisdiction over the property. 
(2)	When the fire lane is located on private property, the required signs shall be erected by the property owner at his own expense within 30 days of the date of the order establishing the fire lane. 
(Ord. No. 175, § 1(E), 5-7-1985; Code 1989, § 570.04(2)(E); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.305), 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 18-180. - Maintenance. 
    All established fire lanes shall be permanently and continuously maintained by the property owner to be free from obstructions, including motor vehicles, trailers, equipment, storage, rubbish, vegetation or accumulation of dirt or snow. All required fire lane signs shall be permanently and continuously maintained by the property owner to be securely fastened, not visually obstructed in any way, and free from paint or vandalism. Missing or vandalized signs shall be promptly replaced. 
(Ord. No. 175, § 1(F), 5-7-1985; Code 1989, § 570.04(2)(F); Ord. No. 162, § 1(550.306), 8-6-2002) 
Secs. 18-181-18-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIREWORKS 

Sec. 18-201. - Purpose; compliance. 
(a)	Due to the inherent risk of fire and injury to persons and property associated with the sale, possession and use of fireworks, the city council has determined that it is necessary and in the interest of public health, safety and welfare to establish reasonable regulations concerning fireworks. 
(b)	Fireworks are regulated by Minn. Stats. § 624.20. In addition to those regulations, all display sales, storage for commercial purposes, manufacturing, and use of consumer fireworks shall comply with the health and safety regulations in this article. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2003, § 1) 
Sec. 18-202. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fireworks has the same definition as contained in Minn. Stats. § 624.20, subd. 1(c), or any superseding statute as amended from time to time. Consumer fireworks governed by this article include but are not limited to wire or wood sparklers, other sparkling items such as cylindrical or cone fountains, ground spinners, wheels, snakes and glow worms, smoke devices, and trick noisemakers which include paper streamers, party poppers, string poppers, snappers, and drop pops. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2003, § 2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-203. - Penalty. 
(a)	Materials which violate and/or pose a threat to public safety may be confiscated and destroyed. Costs associated with disposal shall be assessed back to the property owner or holder of a permit under this article. 
(b)	Violations of this article, city ordinances, or state statutes may result in revocation of the permit under this article or civil penalties of up to $500.00 per occurrence. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2003, § 8) 
Sec. 18-204. - Authority having jurisdiction. 
    The city council shall appoint the authority having jurisdiction under this article during the annual appointments. It is recommended that this article be enforced by the fire chief or the building official. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2003, § 9) 
Sec. 18-205. - Permit. 
(a)	No person, without first securing a permit, shall manufacture, store, sell or make a public display of fireworks. The use of consumer fireworks is not permitted on public property (i.e., parks, roads, alleys, schools, government property, etc.). 
(b)	The authority having jurisdiction shall give final approval or denial of an application for the manufacture, storage for commercial purposes, or sale of fireworks within 14 days of such application being made to the city. 
(c)	Permits shall be issued by the city clerk for a period of one calendar year. A license shall expire December 31 of each year. The license fee will not be prorated. 
(d)	Prior to the city processing the application, a certified criminal record check from the state bureau of criminal apprehension (BCA) must be submitted to the city by the applicant and/or responsible party. Neither the applicant nor the responsible party for the permit shall have been convicted of a felony or a fire/fireworks-related misdemeanor within the last three years. 
(e)	The authority having jurisdiction shall determine if the proposed location is compliant with state building and fire codes. 
(f)	The application shall include a letter from the owner or other person legally responsible for the property on which the fireworks-related activity will occur. Such letter shall grant permission to the applicant for the use of the property. 
(g)	Any permit granted under this article shall be nontransferable. 
(h)	The applicant shall provide comprehensive general liability insurance in which the city is named an additional insured for $1,000,000.00 per occurrence per individual. 
(i)	The applicant shall provide a performance bond in the amount of $500.00 to guarantee full compliance and performance in accordance with the permit and conditions. 
(j)	The fee for the permit shall be as set forth in the city fee schedule adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2003, § 3-5) 
Sec. 18-206. - Sales and storage. 
(a)	No person shall sell or store fireworks within 100 feet of any fuel dispensing apparatus. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any seller of any fireworks to permit smoking at any site containing fireworks. No smoking signs must be conspicuously posted and approved fire extinguishers must be available for use. 
(c)	In buildings that do not have an automatic sprinkler system, retail sales display of fireworks shall be limited to a gross weight of 400 pounds of fireworks. In buildings that do contain an automatic sprinkler system, the amount of fireworks shall be determined by the authority having jurisdiction on a case-by-case basis after considering the building's construction, fire suppression apparatus and other relevant factors. 
(d)	The requirements of this article are in addition to any requirements imposed by any building and zoning regulations, fire codes or state law. 
(e)	Only persons 18 years of age or older may purchase fireworks and the age of the purchaser must be verified by photographic identification. Compliance checks may be conducted by the Orono Police Department to ensure that those authorized to sell firework products are following and complying with the requirements of this article. 
(f)	No exterior storage, display, or transient sales of fireworks are permitted. No manufacturing, sales or storage for commercial purposes shall occur on residentially zoned property or properties used for educational purposes or assemblies. 
(g)	A list of all consumer fireworks displayed and stored on the property shall be available at all times. The list shall document the name, weight, and quantity of the fireworks and be accompanied by the material safety data sheets. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2003, § 6) 
Sec. 18-207. - Rules and regulations regarding discharge. 
(a)	It is unlawful to use, fire or discharge any fireworks along the route of and during any parade or at any place of public assembly or on public property or in any commercial/industrial zoning district. 
(b)	It is unlawful at any time to throw, toss, or aim any fireworks at any person, animal, vehicle, or object or used in any manner that may threaten or cause possible harm to life or property. 
(c)	The discharge of fireworks shall be prohibited inside a building and within 15 feet of any building. 
(d)	The authority having jurisdiction may ban the use of fireworks if dry, windy or other unsafe conditions occur. 
(e)	Juveniles may not possess fireworks unless under the direct supervision of a responsible adult. 
(f)	Fireworks may not be discharged in such a manner that may create a nuisance nor between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Ord. of 6-3-2003, § 7) 
Chapter 20 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Dumping prohibited on public roads, grounds. 
    No person shall dump or deposit leaves or rubbish on or in any public road or grounds within the city or in the ditches of any such road. 
(Code 1989, § 540.02) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 28.

(Code 1989, § 540.01)

Sec. 20-31. - Use regulated.

ARTICLE III. - CURFEW[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of a county board to adopt an ordinance establishing a countywide curfew for unmarried persons under 18 years of age. Within the Metropolitan Area, such a curfew must contain an earlier curfew for children under 12, Minn. Stats. § 145A.05, subd. 7A. 

Sec. 20-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency means a circumstance or combination of circumstances requiring immediate action to prevent property damage, serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Establishment means any privately owned place of business to which the public is invited, including but not limited to any place of amusement, entertainment or refreshment. 
    Guardian means an adult appointed pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 525.6155 or 525.6165 who has the powers and responsibilities of a parent as defined by Minn. Stats. § 525.619. 
    Juvenile means a person under the age of 18 years. The term does not include persons under 18 years who are married or have been legally emancipated. 
    Parent means birth parents, adoptive parents, and stepparents. 
    Proprietor means an individual, firm, association, partnership or corporation operating, managing or conducting any establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
    Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access, and includes but is not limited to streets, highways and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities and shops. 
    Responsible adult means a person 18 years old or older specifically authorized by law or by a parent or guardian to have custody or control of a juvenile. 
    Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss of impairment of the function of any body part or organ. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 20-62. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)	It is unlawful for a juvenile under the age of 12 years to be present in any public place or establishment within the city: 
(1)	Any time between 9:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, and 5:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(2)	Any time between 10:00 p.m. on any Friday or Saturday and 5:00 a.m. on the following day. 
(b)	It is unlawful for a juvenile, age 12 to 14 years inclusive, to be present in any public place or establishment within the city: 
(1)	Any time between 10:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday and 5:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(2)	Any time between 11:00 p.m. on any Friday or Saturday and 5:00 a.m. on the following day. 
(c)	It is unlawful for a juvenile, age 15 to 17 years inclusive, to be present in any public place or establishment within the city: 
(1)	Any time between 11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, and 5:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(2)	Any time between 12:01 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. on any Saturday or Sunday. 
(d)	It is unlawful for a parent or guardian of a juvenile knowingly, or through negligent supervision, to permit the juvenile to be in any public place or establishment within the city during the hours prohibited in subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section. 
(e)	It is unlawful for a proprietor of an establishment within the city to knowingly permit a juvenile to remain in the establishment or on the establishment's property during hours prohibited in subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section. If a proprietor is not present at the time of the curfew violation, the responding officer shall leave written notice of the violation with an employee of the establishment. A copy of the written notice shall be served upon the establishment's proprietor personally or by certified mail. 
Sec. 20-63. - Defenses. 
(a)	It is an affirmative defense for a juvenile to prove that the juvenile was: 
(1)	Accompanied by his parent, guardian or other responsible adult. 
(2)	Engaged in a lawful employment activity or was going to or returning home from his place of employment. 
(3)	Involved in an emergency situation. 
(4)	Going to, attending or returning home from an official school, religious or other recreational activity sponsored and/or supervised by a public entity or civic organization. 
(5)	On an errand at the direction of a parent or guardian. 
(6)	Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution or article I of the state constitution. 
(7)	Engaged in interstate travel. 
(8)	On the public right-of-way boulevard or sidewalk abutting the property containing the juvenile's residence or abutting the neighboring property, structure or residence. 
(b)	It is affirmative defense for a proprietor of an establishment to prove that the proprietor or employee: 
(1)	Reasonably and in good faith relied upon a juvenile's representation of proof of age. Proof of age may be established pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 340A.503, subd. 6, or other verification means, including but not limited to school identification cards and birth certificates. 
(2)	Promptly notified the responsible police agency that a juvenile was present on the premises of that establishment during curfew hours. 
Sec. 20-64. - Earlier curfew. 
    The parent, guardian or legal custodian of any person under the age of 18 years may designate an earlier curfew which shall have the effect of law for such person. 
Sec. 20-65. - Presence not permitted. 
    This article shall not be construed as permitting the presence at any time of a person under the age of 18 years in a place where his presence is prohibited by any law or ordinance. 
Sec. 20-66. - Police authority. 
    Any member of the police force is authorized to arrest, with or without warrant, any person observed to be violating the provisions of this article and shall notify, as soon thereafter as reasonably possible, the parent, guardian or person having legal custody of any minor so arrested. 
Secs. 20-67-20-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC SAFETY ALARMS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Requisite reporting of malicious false fire alarms in educational facilities, Minn. Stats. § 299F.452; intentional false fire alarms or unlawful tampering or interference with fire alarm systems constitutes a misdemeanor, Minn. Stats. § 609.686, subd. 1. 

Sec. 20-101. - Purpose. 
    This article is intended to protect the public safety services of the city from misuse of public safety alarms and to provide for the maximum possible service to public safety alarm users. This article regulates the use of fire, burglary and safety alarms; establishes users' fees; and establishes a system of administration. 
(Code 1989, § 580.01) 
Sec. 20-102. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm system means any alarm installation designed to be used for the prevention or detection of burglary, robbery or fire on the premises which contain an alarm installation. Automobile alarm devices shall not be considered an alarm system under this article. 
    Alarm user means the person in control of any building, structure or facility wherein an alarm system is maintained. 
    False alarm means an alarm signal eliciting a response by public safety personnel when a situation requiring a response does not, in fact, exist, and which false alarm is caused by the activation of the alarm system through mechanical failure, alarm malfunction, improper installation, or the inadvertence of the alarm system's owner or lessees or of his employees or agents. False alarms do not include alarms caused by climatic conditions such as tornadoes, thunderstorms, utility line mishaps, violent conditions of nature, or any other conditions which are clearly beyond the control of the alarm manufacturer, installer or owner. 
    Public safety personnel means city employees or personnel duly authorized to maintain and enforce public safety. 
(Code 1989, § 580.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 20-103. - User fee. 
(a)	User fee schedule. Once a public safety alarm system reports more than three false alarms to the city in a single calendar year and the alarm user has received timely notice of each violation, the alarm user shall be charged a user fee as fixed and determined from time to time by the council. 
(b)	Appeal. Any alarm user required by the city to pay a user fee as the result of a false alarm may make a written appeal of the false alarm charge to the police chief within ten days' notice from the city of the false alarm charge. Following review and determination by the police chief, such decision may be appealed to the council, who will have the authority to make a final determination as to whether the appellant is to be charged with a fee for a false alarm. 
(Code 1989, § 580.03) 
Sec. 20-104. - Payment of fees. 
(a)	Fees paid to city treasurer. Payment of user fees must be paid to the city treasurer within 30 days from the date of notice by the city to the alarm user. Failure to pay the fee within 30 days' notice will cause the alarm user to be considered delinquent and subject to a penalty of ten percent of the fee. 
(b)	Delinquent charges. All delinquent charges for user fees shall be certified by the clerk to the county assessor, who shall prepare an assessment roll each year providing for assessment of the delinquent amounts against the respective properties served, which assessment roll shall be delivered to the council for adoption on or before October 10 of each year. 
(Code 1989, § 580.04) 
Sec. 20-105. - Alarm report. 
    When an alarm user has incurred five false alarms or more within one calendar year, the alarm user shall submit within ten days after being charged with the fifth false alarm written verification to the police chief that appropriate actions are being taken to discover and eliminate the cause of the false alarms. It is unlawful for any person to fail to submit such written verification required by this section. 
(Code 1989, § 580.05) 
Sec. 20-106. - Confidentiality. 
(a)	Deemed confidential record. All information submitted in compliance with this article shall be held in confidence and shall be deemed a confidential record exempt from discovery to the extent permitted by law. 
(b)	Statistics. Subject to requirements of confidentiality, the police chief may develop and maintain statistics for the purpose of ongoing alarm systems evaluation. 
(Code 1989, § 580.06) 
Chapter 22 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Leashing animals in parks, § 6-101 et seq.; environment, ch. 16; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 30; vegetation, ch. 38; waterways, ch. 40. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND PLAYGROUNDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of park commissioner to devise, plan and establish a system of public parks and to improve, govern and maintain them, Minn. Stats. § 448.56, subd. 1. 

Sec. 22-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public park or playground means and includes any lot, yard, area or place within the city which has been dedicated to or by the city for purposes of public recreation, leisure and/or sporting activities, and which has been designated, improved and/or maintained as such, including any open watercourse which is adjacent to, located upon or connected with any such lot, yard, area or place. 
(Code 1989, § 535.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-32. - Prohibited and restricted acts. 
    The following acts or conduct within or upon the public parks and/or playgrounds of the city are deemed contrary to public health, safety and welfare and are, therefore, unlawful: 
(1)	Keeping pets. To keep or allow to be kept for any period of time any pet which is owned by or within the custody of any person using or occupying the public parks or playgrounds for any purpose. As used in this subsection, and without limiting its generality, the term "pet" includes any dog, cat, horse, pony, sheep, goat, bird or any other animal commonly known or referred to as a pet. It shall not be unlawful, however, for a blind or deaf person or a person with a physical or sensory disability to be accompanied by a properly identified and harnessed service animal. Dogs shall be allowed in public parks in accordance with section 6-101. 
(2)	Camping. To camp upon or use public parks or playgrounds for purposes of overnight accommodation and/or sleeping. The term "overnight" means those hours between regular or special closing time and the next authorized opening of the park. 
(3)	Operating motorized vehicle. To operate any motorized vehicle upon any portion of a public park or playground which is not graded, paved and/or maintained as a public street, parking area or boat launch; except that authorized police, fire, emergency and maintenance personnel may operate such motorized vehicles upon any portion of a public park or playground as is reasonably necessary to perform their ordinary and necessary duties. 
(4)	Defacing, damaging or destroying. To willfully and intentionally deface, damage or destroy any structure, building, sign, fixture, table, tree, shrubbery, grass, fence, post, pole, light, slide, swing, plaything or any other article or thing connected with and located upon such public parks or playgrounds. 
(5)	Alcoholic beverages. To sell or consume or allow to be sold or consumed any alcoholic beverages within or upon public parks or playgrounds except by special license issued by the council. 
(6)	Unacceptable refuse. To drop, leave, strew or cause or allow to be dropped, left or strewn within or upon public parks or playgrounds which are not designated or commonly accepted receptacles, any refuse, garbage, paper, wrappings, bags, cans, bottles, peelings, rinds or other waste material. 
(7)	Unattended fires. To initiate or cause or allow to be initiated any fire and to leave or allow them to be left or any burning or smoldering coals or ashes unattended or unextinguished. 
(Code 1989, § 535.02) 
State Law reference- Unfair discriminatory practice for an owner, operator, or manager of a public conveyance or place to prohibit a blind or deaf person or a person with a physical or sensory disability from taking a service animal into the public place or conveyance if the service animal can be properly identified and is properly harnessed, Minn. Stats. §§ 256C.02, 363.03, subd. 10. 
Sec. 22-33. - Hours and reservations for special use. 
    Public parks and playgrounds open at 7:00 a.m. and close at 10:00 p.m. except in the case of organized sports events or by special permit obtained from the city clerk. Groups reserving these places for special uses may extend their use before or beyond such times. A permit will be issued by the city clerk for groups desiring to reserve any park facilities for permitted and lawful uses. 
(Code 1989, § 535.03) 
Sec. 22-34. - Large public gatherings on public lands. 
(a)	Purpose and intent. This section is intended as part of a program to promote the public welfare and safety; the sanitation and safety of large public gatherings organized on city parkland and beaches which adjoins Long Lake. 
(b)	Definitions. The term "Long Lake" means that certain body of water adjoining and partly lying within the city unless the context otherwise clearly requires. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate certain matters of health, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 22. 
(c)	Permit requirements. 
(1)	Persons organizing and running a public or private gathering or event estimated at more than 250 participants and spectators on any parkland of the city adjoining Long Lake or on any public beaches or other public facilities for access to Long Lake are required to obtain a permit from the council. 
State Law reference- Commissioner of health may regulate the general sanitation of mass gatherings, Minn. Stats. § 144.12, subd. 2. 
(2)	A verified application for each permit shall be made to the city clerk on forms provided by the city. The applications shall include: 
a.	The name, address and telephone number of the applicant and if an organization, the name, address, telephone number and date of birth of each officer, principal, partner, director or shareholder of the applicant. 
b.	Descriptive information, including: 
1.	The purpose of the gathering or event; 
2.	The nature of the activities to be conducted during the gathering or event; 
3.	The proposed date, hours of operation, number of people to be involved, vehicles or other equipment to be used; 
4.	Location and size of structures or equipment to be used during the gathering or event drawn to scale and appropriately labeled on a map; 
5.	The location of activities to be conducted also drawn to scale and appropriately labeled on a map; and 
6.	Any other information the council may request after consideration of the application. 
c.	Showing that all requisite permits, licenses and approvals have been obtained from all other governmental units, subdivisions or agencies having jurisdiction of Long Lake and its environs. 
d.	Detailed plans to ensure waste disposal, sanitary facilities, inspections of vehicles or equipment, post-event cleanup and other necessary precautions to prevent pollution to land or the lake. 
e.	The permit fee, provided that if the permit is not granted, the fee shall be refunded to the applicant minus costs for police background investigation of the applicant and/or its principals, city staff investigation or other expenses incurred by the city relative to the application. 
(3)	The application and information required to be given under subsection (c)(2) of this section shall be submitted at least 45 days in advance of the proposed event unless the city council shall waive this requirement for good cause shown. 
(4)	Upon receipt of the application required by subsection (c)(2) of this section the council shall refer it to the police chief and such other members of the city staff as it shall deem necessary for review, investigation and recommendation. The costs of police and staff review and investigation shall be reimbursed from the license fee submitted with the application. 
(5)	The council shall act upon the application within 30 days of its submission to the city clerk. In making its decision to grant or deny the permit, the council shall exercise its discretion and may consider, among other things, the following: 
a.	The recommendations of the police chief as to criminal history, or lack thereof, of the applicants and the recommendations of city staff charged with investigation and processing of the application. 
b.	Whether the proposed event will cause pollution of the waters or shoreline of Long Lake. 
c.	Whether the proposed event is compatible with activities of unorganized users of the lake and/or public facilities adjoining the lake. 
d.	Whether the proposed event will create a condition hazardous to persons or property. 
e.	Whether the proposed event, by reason of noise, fumes, light or other characteristics will tend to be a source of nuisance or annoyance to persons in the vicinity of the event. 
(6)	The council may, when deemed necessary, impose written conditions upon the granting of a license. A violation of any of the conditions shall be a violation of this section. 
(7)	The permit fee to be submitted with the application shall be determined from time to time by the city council. 
(8)	No person granted a permit pursuant to this section shall gain a vested right to obtain such permits in the future. 
(9)	By making application, the applicant consents to permitting officers and agents of the city to enter the event area at all times to investigate the activities and to determine whether the conditions of the permit and all other applicable laws are being complied with. 
(d)	Concessions. No applicant granted a permit pursuant to this section shall have the right to sell food, beverages, gifts, knickknacks, curios or other concessionaire goods on any public property in connection with the event or its activities. Concessions for the event shall be regulated by the city and granted only to nonprofit organizations which make application to the city for a concession permit. The applicant, however, may at its option prohibit the sale of concessions by so stating in its application. 
(e)	Violations. Violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable in accordance with section 1-13. 
(Code 1989, § 535.04) 
Chapter 24 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 10; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 30. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 24-1-24-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS AND CONTRIBUTION SOLICITATION PRACTICES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 10. 
State Law reference- Authority to restrain or license and regulate auctioneers, transient merchants and dealers, hawkers, peddlers, solicitors and canvassers, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 19; authority to regulate or license hawkers and peddlers, Minn. Stats. § 329.06; authority to regulate or license transient merchants, Minn. Stats. § 329.15. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-31. - Purpose. 
    This article is intended to regulate and/or prohibit certain business-related or contribution-related solicitation practices within the city so as to protect the residents from unwanted, annoying or illegal sales and contribution practices and to protect established business concerns within the city from unfair, annoying or illegal sales competition or contribution practices. 
(Code 1989, § 525.01; Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.01) 
Sec. 24-32. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business solicitation means an attempt by a solicitor to sell or distribute goods or services within the city by means of personal face-to-face contact with the solicitee at a place other than the solicitor's established place of business. It does not include solicitations in which the solicitee previously knows the solicitor, his/its business firm or organization and the identity of the goods or services offered or solicitations where the contact was initiated by the solicitee. 
    Contribution solicitation means an attempt by a solicitor to obtain money from a solicitee by means of personal face-to-face contact with the solicitee. It does not include solicitations where the solicitee previously knows the solicitor and his/its organization or solicitations where the contact was initiated by the solicitee. 
    Established place of business means real estate within a two-mile radius of the city which is owned or leased by the solicitor for at least 60 consecutive days prior to the date of application and upon which the solicitor intends to conduct business. 
    Goods means anything of value which is capable of physical delivery to the solicitee either at the time of the solicitation or later and in consideration for which the solicitor expects to receive payment. 
    Services means work or labor of any kind to be performed for the solicitee either at the time of the solicitation or later and in consideration for which the solicitor expects to receive payment. 
    Solicitee means the person, partnership, corporation or unincorporated association to whom or which a business or contribution solicitation is made. 
    Solicitor means a person who goes from house-to-house, door-to-door, business-to-business, street-to-street, or any other type of place-to-place, for the purpose of offering for sale, displaying or exposing for sale, selling or attempting to sell, and delivering immediately upon sale, the goods, wares, products, merchandise or other personal property that the person is carrying or otherwise transporting. 
    Unlawful purpose means any plan, goal or result the attainment of which or the attempted attainment of which is prohibited by local regulation or by state or federal statute or regulation. 
(Code 1989, § 525.02; Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 24-33-24-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 24-51. - Applications. 
(a)	Applications for licensing of business solicitations or registration of contribution solicitations shall contain: 
(1)	The name, address and date of birth and phone number of each solicitor; 
(2)	A certified record check from the state bureau of criminal apprehension (BCA) for each solicitor; 
(3)	The name and address of the business or organization for which solicitations are sought; 
(4)	The purpose of the solicitations; 
(5)	A description of goods or services to be sold through solicitations, if conducted; and 
(6)	The areas within the city where the solicitations are to be conducted. 
(b)	Application shall be made at the office of the city clerk on forms prescribed by the city clerk and shall be accompanied by an application fee set by the fee schedule of the city. 
(Code 1989, § 525.05; Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.05) 
Sec. 24-52. - Investigation. 
    All applications for a permit to conduct business solicitations or registration for contribution solicitation shall be immediately referred to the chief of police for investigation for the truth of the information contained therein or any other information bearing upon the character of the solicitors or the legality of business practices of the organization soliciting. 
(Code 1989, § 525.06; Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.06) 
Sec. 24-53. - Recommendation. 
    The investigation shall be completed within ten days of receipt of the application and a written recommendation provided to the city council for hearing at its next regular meeting. If the investigation uncovers information that requires further inquiry to adequately assess whether the solicitor poses a public safety or public deception risk, the police chief shall notify the applicant. Information indicating the solicitor or organization has participated in any of the following shall require further investigation: fraudulent dishonest solicitation; activity causing property damage or vandalism; violent crimes; or crimes involving sexual assault. If the applicant wishes to pursue the license or registration, the applicant shall pay the costs of additional investigation. If the investigation produces evidence that the solicitor poses a public safety or public deception risk, the police chief may recommend conditions to eliminate the risk or may recommend that the city council deny the permit or registration. 
(Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.065) 
Sec. 24-54. - Registration. 
    All applications to conduct contribution solicitations, once completed and submitted to the city clerk along with the required filing fee, shall be kept on file by the city clerk. Solicitations shall cease after expiration of the permit unless and until a new permit is completed and filed as provided in this article. 
(Code 1989, § 525.07; Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.07) 
Sec. 24-55. - Approval; disapproval; revocation. 
(a)	Approval. All applications for a business solicitation permit under this article, after hearing before the council, shall be approved by the council. If approved, the council may, in its discretion, attach reasonable conditions to the permit, which conditions shall become part and parcel of the permit. If approved, the city clerk shall keep the permit and any conditions attached to it in an active file for the duration of the permit. 
(b)	Disapproval. The council may disapprove a business solicitation permit application for any of the following reasons: 
(1)	Recommendation of disapproval by the chief of police; 
(2)	Evidence that the solicitation permit, if granted, would cause or tend to cause a hazard to public safety; 
(3)	Evidence that the solicitation permit, if granted would substantially and adversely affect established business located in the city by creating an unfair competitive advantage over such established businesses; 
(4)	Evidence that the solicitor has no established place of business; 
(5)	Evidence that the solicitor's activities have in the past resulted in harassment, nuisance or deception of members of the public. 
(c)	Revocation. Once granted, a business solicitation permit may be revoked after notice and hearing before the city council for any of the following reasons: 
(1)	Evidence that the solicitor has violated any of the provisions of this article; 
(2)	Evidence that the solicitor's activities have created a danger to public safety; 
(3)	Evidence that the solicitor has violated any conditions attached to permit by the council. 
(Code 1989, § 525.08; Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.08) 
Sec. 24-56. - Duration. 
    No business solicitation permit shall be granted which exceeds 120 consecutive days in duration. 
(Code 1989, § 525.09; Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.09) 
Secs. 24-57-24-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 24-81. - Prohibited practices. 
(a)	Unlawful purpose. It is unlawful for any solicitor to engage in solicitation for any unlawful purpose. 
(b)	Refusal to leave. It is unlawful for any solicitor to refuse to leave the premises of a solicitee when requested by the solicitee to do so. 
(c)	Permit unobtained. It is unlawful for any person to engage in business solicitation without first obtaining a permit therefor as provided in this article. 
(d)	Registration unobtained. It is unlawful for any person to engage in contribution solicitation without first completing the registration as provided in this article. 
(e)	Fraudulent or deceptive practices. It is unlawful for any solicitor to engage in any fraudulent or deceptive solicitation practices. 
(f)	Violations of council conditions. It is unlawful to violate any conditions placed upon a business solicitation permit by the council. 
(Code 1989, § 525.03; Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.03) 
Sec. 24-82. - Exempted practices. 
    The following solicitation practices are exempt from the requirements of this article: 
(1)	Nonprofit solicitations by children. Business or contribution solicitations by children under the age of 16 years provided such solicitations are for the benefit of a nonprofit athletic, religious, social or educational organization to which such children belong and provided, further, that the use of such children in conducting such solicitations is not for the sole purpose of obtaining this exemption. 
(2)	Nonprofit solicitations during public events. Business or contribution solicitations from a concession stand set up and operated during a community celebration or public event sponsored by any nonprofit athletic, religious, social or educational organization having its principal place of business within the city, provided such solicitations are conducted only during the celebration or public event. Such concession may only be operated upon the specific premises upon which the community celebration or public event is being conducted. 
(3)	City-authorized solicitations. Business or contribution solicitations from a permanent concession stand located upon any public park within the city when the solicitor's use of the stand has been authorized by the city for athletic events. 
(4)	Fire department solicitations. Business or contribution solicitations conducted by the volunteer fire department or any auxiliary organization thereof for the exclusive benefit of the fire department. 
(5)	Long Lake Park Subcommittee solicitations. Business or contribution solicitations conducted by and for the exclusive benefit of the Long Lake Park Subcommittee. 
(6)	Home-grown edible produce solicitations. Business or contribution solicitations which involve the sale of home-grown edible produce at the intersection of County Road 146 and U.S. Trunk Highway 12 or at any location within the area platted as the Long Lake Commercial-Industrial Park provided the solicitor shall have first obtained the written permission of the landowner or lessor of the property on which such solicitations shall be conducted and the solicitor shall have first registered with and obtained a permit to do so from the city clerk. 
(Code 1989, § 525.04; Ord. of 6-19-2001, § 525.04) 
State Law reference- Provisions for licensing and regulation of hawkers and peddlers do not apply to persons who may sell or peddle the products of the farm or garden occupied and cultivated by themselves, Minn. Stats. § 329.08. 
Chapter 26 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; environment, ch. 16; zoning administrator, § 16-171 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 30; utilities, ch. 36; vegetation, ch. 38; waterways, ch. 40. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt zoning ordinances, Minn. Stats. § 462.357. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSULTANT DEVELOPMENT FEES 

Sec. 26-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Costs means any time or expense incurred by the city for services performed by the city engineer and city attorney or any other regular staff consultants. 
    Development means any subdivision, planned unit development, rezoning special use permit, variance, vacation, building addition or site plan; or proposed rezoning, special use permit, variance, building addition or change in site plan; or any amendment to a previously approved subdivision, planned unit development, rezoning, special use permit, variance, vacation, building addition or site plan. 
    Owner means any property owner, applicant or duly authorized representative of a development. 
(Code 1989, § 430.02; Ord. No. 475.09, § 1, 1-5-1999) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-132. - Reimbursement may be required. 
    Any owner that causes the city to incur costs on behalf of or on account of that owner, associated with a proposed development, may be required to reimburse the city for the actual costs expended by the city on behalf of or on account of that owner. If the city administrator intends to seek reimbursement of city costs to be incurred, he shall notify the applicant and place the matter on the agenda of the city council meeting for approval. At any time prior to final approval of the project or as a condition of final approval, the city council may consider the matter and determine whether reimbursement of actual costs shall be sought by the city. If reimbursement of actual costs is approved by the city, the city administrator shall follow the provisions of this article. Any development which involves only one platted residential lot, for a noncommercial purpose, located in a residential zoning district shall not be responsible for costs incurred by the city beyond the initial application fee. 
(Code 1989, § 430.03; Ord. No. 475.09, § 2, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 26-133. - Deposit required. 
    Subject to the provisions of section 26-132, the owner shall deposit with the city in escrow an amount, as determined by the city administrator, necessary to cover the total costs associated with the proposed development prior to the performance of any such services by the city's regular staff or consultants. However, if a proposed development and the related consultant review is anticipated to span a period of time in excess of 90 days, the owner will only be expected to deposit a sum, as determined by the city administrator, necessary for the city to pay all costs for 90 days. The owner will then be expected to maintain the escrow fund at a balance equal to the original amount deposited. Any escrow shall be held in a special escrow account and shall be credited to the subdivider, owner or developer. Staff time and legal expenses incurred by the city in plat approval, office and field checking, setting grade and drainage requirements, general supervision, staking, inspection, installation and cost of traffic control and street signs, drafting as-built drawings and all other city staff and consultant services performed in the processing of such improvements and developments, administrative and legal expenses in examining title to the property being developed shall be charged to the escrow account and shall be credited to the city. 
(Code 1989, § 430.03; Ord. No. 475.09, § 3, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 26-134. - Monthly statements of expenditures required. 
    The city will provide itemized statements to the owner by the 15th day of each month, showing the city's expenditures for staff and consultant services for the prior month associated with a development, together with the current balance in the developer's escrow fund, and a statement, if additional funds are requested, to maintain the fund at the level established. No statement will be sent if there are no transactions during the preceding month in the escrow fund. The city shall itemize all time, services and materials billed to any developer's escrow account; and such time, services and materials shall be in accordance with the rules, regulations and fees as promulgated and adopted by the council. The subdivider, owner or developer making the deposits in the escrow account shall, upon request, be furnished a copy of such itemized charges. Any balance remaining in the account upon completion of all platting conditions shall be returned to the depositor by the finance department after all claims and charges have been paid. 
(Code 1989, § 430.03; Ord. No. 475.09, § 4, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 26-135. - Reimbursement of escrow fund. 
    The owner shall reimburse the escrow fund for any deficits caused if the amount actually expended by or billed to the city exceeds the escrow fund balance. 
(Code 1989, § 430.03; Ord. No. 475.09, § 5, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 26-136. - Refund of unexpended balance. 
    The city shall refund any moneys deposited in the escrow fund not expended for consultant fees within 30 days after completion of any city consultant services associated with the development. 
(Code 1989, § 430.03; Ord. No. 475.09, § 6, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 26-137. - Escrow fund not to draw interest. 
    The city shall not pay interest on the moneys deposited in the escrow fund. 
(Code 1989, § 430.03; Ord. No. 475.09, § 7, 1-5-1999) 
Sec. 26-138. - Rates established. 
    The city administrator shall establish the rates charged for the services performed by the city staff or consultants. 
(Code 1989, § 430.03; Ord. No. 475.09, § 8, 1-5-1999) 
State Law reference- Authority to conduct financial affairs of the city, including settlement of accounts, Minn. Stats. § 412.241. 
Chapter 28 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; environment, ch. 16; dumping prohibited on public roads, § 20-1; utilities, ch. 36. 
State Law reference- Authority to organize, provide, require, and enforce collection of solid waste, Minn. Stats. §§ 115A.94, subd. 2, 115A.941. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Apartment building means for the purpose of this chapter only, any building used for residential purposes consisting of three dwelling units or more with individual kitchen facilities for each. 
    Brush means sticks, twigs, branches, woody plants and tree trimmings up to six inches in diameter. 
    Commercial establishment means any premises where a commercial or industrial enterprise of any kind is carried on, and includes clubs, churches and establishments or nonprofit organizations where food is prepared or served or goods are sold. 
    Commercial, nonresidential garbage and refuse collectors means any person who shall offer to, or engage in the collection of garbage or refuse from any industry or business; dwelling with more than two dwelling units; and such places as churches, nursing homes, nonprofit associations, and schools within the city. 
    Garbage means animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
State Law reference- Definition of garbage, Minn. Rules § 7035.0300, subp. 40. 
    Mixed municipal solid waste means garbage, refuse and other solid waste from residential, commercial, industrial and community activities which is generated and collected in aggregate. This definition does not include auto hulks or large auto parts, street sweepings, ash, construction debris, mining waste, sludges, tree and agricultural wastes, tires and other materials collected, processed and disposed of as separate waste streams. 
State Law reference- Definition of mixed municipal solid waste, Minn. Stats. § 115A.03, subd. 21. 
    Multiple dwellings means, for the purposes of this chapter only, any building used for residential purposes consisting of more than two dwelling units with individual kitchen facilities for each. 
    Recyclable materials means paper, plastic, tin cans, aluminum, motor oil, glass, and other metal goods, each separated or otherwise prepared, which are intended for transportation, processing and manufacturing reuse. 
State Law reference- Definition of recyclable materials, Minn. Stats. § 115A.03, subd. 25a. 
    Recycling center means premises approved by the city council for receipt, storage, and processing of recyclable materials. 
State Law reference- Definitions of recycling facility, Minn. Stats. § 115A.03, subd. 25c; Minn. Rules § 7035.0300, subp. 88. 
    Refuse means discarded waste materials in a solid or semiliquid state consisting of garbage, rubbish or a combination thereof. 
State Law reference- Definitions of refuse, Minn. Rules § 7035.0300, subp. 89. 
    Residential garbage and refuse collectors means any person who shall offer to or engage in the collection of garbage or refuse from any house or residential building of two units or fewer within the city. 
    Rubbish means nongarbage solid waste such as tin cans, glass, paper, sweepings, ash, etc. 
State Law reference- Definition of rubbish, Minn. Stats. § 443.27, Minn. Rules § 7035.0300, subd. 94. 
    Solid waste has the meaning given it in Minn. Stats. § 116.06, subd. 10. 
State Law reference- Definition of solid waste, Minn. Stats. §§ 115A.03, subd. 31, 116.06, subd. 22. 
    Yard waste means grass clippings, leaves, garden waste, vegetable tops, skins, vines and weeds. 
State Law reference- Definitions of yard waste, Minn. Stats. § 115A.03, subd. 38, Minn. Rules § 7035.0300, subp. 121. 
(Code 1989, § 900.01; Ord. No. 210, § 900.00, 9-16-1992; Ord. No. 213, § 900, 5-2-2000) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 28-2. - Appeal board. 
    The city council may establish an appeal board to consider appeals from the strict application of this chapter. Determinations of the appeal board may be appealed to the city council. 
(Code 1989, § 900.60; Ord. No. 210, § 900.60, 9-16-1992; Ord. No. 213, § 900.60, 5-2-2000) 
Sec. 28-3. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1989, § 900.70; Ord. No. 210, § 900.70, 9-16-1992; Ord. No. 213, § 900.70, 5-2-2000) 
State Law reference- Enforcement of solid waste management may be conducted under Minn. Stats. §§ 115.071, 115A.034, 116.072. 
Secs. 28-4-28-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISPOSAL 

Sec. 28-31. - Generally. 
(a)	Nuisance. Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse on any premises is a nuisance and shall be prohibited. 
State Law reference- Authority to define nuisances and provide for their prevention or abatement, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 23. 
(b)	Residential precollection and collection. For all persons who are owners, lessees, or occupants of any residential building wherein there are four or fewer housing units, recyclable materials shall be separated from mixed municipal waste in accordance with rules, regulations and procedures as adopted by the city for the separation of recyclable materials from mixed municipal waste. 
State Law reference- Opportunity to recycle, Minn. Stats. § 115A.552. 
(c)	Refuse in streets, etc. No person shall place any refuse in any street, alley, or public place or upon private property except in proper containers for collection or other lawful disposal. No person shall throw or deposit refuse in any stream or other body of water. 
(d)	Scattering of refuse. No person shall deposit anywhere within the city any refuse in such manner that it may be carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or any other premises within the city. 
(e)	Burying of refuse. No person shall bury any refuse in the city. This subsection does not prevent anyone from composting yard waste and other easily biodegradable, nonpoisonous garbage on his own premises. Composting of garbage shall be allowed only when application has been made to and approval granted by the building and zoning administrator on a finding that such composting would be done in a rodentproof structure and in an otherwise sanitary manner. 
State Law reference- Civil penalties for unlawfully depositing any portion of solid waste in or on public or private lands or waters, Minn. Stats. § 115A.99; criminal penalties for disposal of solid waste upon an unauthorized site, Minn. Stats. § 609.671, subd. 13. 
(f)	Disposal required. Every person shall, in a sanitary manner, store and dispose of refuse that may accumulate upon property owned or occupied by him in accordance with the terms of this chapter. Garbage shall be collected or otherwise lawfully disposed of at least once each week. Every householder, occupant, and owner of any residence shall use the refuse collection service provided by the city. 
State Law reference- Authority to establish mandatory collection of solid waste, Minn. Stats. §§ 115A.94-115A.941. 
(g)	Multiple dwellings. Occupants of multiple dwelling properties shall have the same opportunity to recycle afforded to occupants of other residential dwelling units. It is unlawful after April 30, 2000, for any multiple dwelling owner, association or joint management entity to negotiate, execute, or maintain a contract for multiple dwelling garbage or other refuse collection unless it includes, as part of that contract or as part of a separate contract, a minimum of bimonthly collection of recyclables or as deemed adequate by the city. 
(Ord. No. 210, § 900.10, 9-16-1992; Ord. No. 213, § 900.10, 5-2-2000) 
State Law reference- Mandatory recycling opportunities, Minn. Stats. § 115A.552, subd. 2. 
Sec. 28-32. - Containers. 
(a)	General requirement. Every householder, occupant, or owner of any residence and any restaurant, industrial establishment, or commercial establishment shall be provided by his designated hauler on the premises one or more containers to receive and contain all refuse which may accumulate between collections or other disposal. All normal accumulation of refuse shall be deposited in such containers except that leaves, trimmings from shrubs, grass clippings, shavings, excelsior, and other rubbish of similar volume and weight may be stored in closed containers not meeting the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)	Container requirements. Each residential container shall be watertight, shall be impervious to insects and rodents, shall be fire resistant, and shall not exceed 90 gallons in capacity. Any commercial or business establishment having refuse volume exceeding two cubic yards per week shall provide bulk or box-type refuse storage containers. Containers shall be maintained in good and sanitary condition. Any container not conforming to the requirement of this chapter or having ragged or sharp edges or any other defect likely to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents shall be promptly replaced after notice by the city. 
(c)	Recycling containers. The city shall provide to each dwelling unit a container for the separation and collection of recyclable materials. The recycling containers will, at all times, remain the property of the city. The owner or occupant of each dwelling unit shall leave the recycling containers at the premises upon relocation and shall maintain the recycling containers in good condition. 
State Law reference- All containers for the storage of solid waste and refuse must be covered, leakproof, durable, of easily cleanable construction, and maintained in a manner to prevent a nuisance or menace to public health, Minn. Rules §§ 7035.0700, subps. 2 and 4, 7035.0800, subp. 2; authority to dictate the size, allowable weight and other specifications of containers, Minn. Rules § 7035.0700, subd. 2(B), (C). 
(d)	Placement. Where an alley open to traffic is available, each container for the premises abutting the alley shall be placed at the rear of the property next to the alley. Where no alley exists, the container shall be placed near the door of the building to which it relates. In that case, the container shall be placed at the front property line for collection, but it shall not be so placed before 7:00 p.m. the night before collection and shall be removed by 7:00 p.m. the day of collection. 
(e)	Use of containers. Refuse shall be drained of liquid and household garbage shall be wrapped before being deposited in a container. Highly inflammable or explosive material shall not be placed in containers. 
(Code 1989, § 900.20; Ord. No. 210, § 900.20, 9-16-1992; Ord. No. 213, § 900.20, 5-2-2000) 
State Law reference- Solid waste does not include hazardous waste, Minn. Stats. § 116.06, subd. 22, Minn. Rules § 7035.0300, subp. 100. 
Secs. 28-33-28-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LICENSING OF COLLECTORS AND HAULERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license persons to collect mixed municipal solid waste, Minn. Stats. § 115A.93, subd. 2. 

Sec. 28-61. - Required; insurance; fee. 
(a)	No person shall engage in the business of residential garbage or refuse collection or conveyance in the city unless such person shall first secure from the city clerk a license to do so and pay the license fee prescribed in this section. The city may issue up to three licenses for the collection of refuse or recyclable materials within the city. 
(b)	No person shall engage in the business of commercial, nonresidential garbage and refuse collection or conveyance in the city unless such person shall first secure from the city clerk a license to do so and pay the license fee prescribed in this section. 
(c)	An applicant for such license shall make such application to the city clerk on a form prepared by the city clerk. The application shall accurately state: 
(1)	The name of the owner or licensee. 
(2)	A description of the kind of services to be rendered. 
(3)	A description of each motor vehicle to be used for hauling, including the license number thereof. 
(4)	The manner and kind of service proposed to be given the customers and scheduled pickups. 
(5)	The route or area to be served. 
(d)	No such license shall be issued until the applicant files with the city clerk a certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state currently covering all vehicles to be used by the applicant in the business. The minimum limits of coverage for such insurance shall be: 
(1)	Each person injured, at least $300,000.00. 
(2)	Each accident, at least $600,000.00. 
(3)	Property damage, at least $100,000.00. 
Such insurance shall be kept in force during the term of the license and shall provide for notification of the city prior to termination or cancellation. Any license issued under this chapter shall automatically be revoked upon notice of termination or cancellation of such insurance and shall remain revoked until, and unless, other insurance is provided as requested in this section. 
(e)	The annual license fee shall be as duly set by the council by resolution from time to time. Such license shall expire December 31 of each year. This fee shall not be prorated during any calendar year. 
(f)	The hauler shall post a performance bond in the amount of $10,000.00 to guarantee full compliance and performance in accordance with the license and conditions. 
(g)	Any licensee wishing to renew its license shall do so within 90 days of the end of the existing license year. 
(h)	The city may revoke any license issued under this chapter upon reasonable notice and hearing and failure of the licensee to perform any condition of the license, this chapter, or any applicable law within 20 days after such notice. 
(Code 1989, § 900.30; Ord. No. 210, § 900.30, 9-16-1992; Ord. No. 213, § 900.30, 5-2-2000) 
Sec. 28-62. - Vehicles. 
    All licensed vehicles under this chapter shall be operated in accordance with the following regulations: 
(1)	Each refuse collection vehicle shall be marked on the outside so as to identify the licensee. Every vehicle used for hauling garbage shall be covered, leakproof, durable, and of easily cleanable construction. Every vehicle used for hauling refuse shall be sufficiently airtight so as to prevent dust, paper, or other collected materials from escaping. Every vehicle shall be kept clean to prevent nuisances, pollution, and insect breeding, and shall be maintained in good repair. Residential collector vehicles shall be restricted to a maximum weight on any single axle of 10,000 pounds on all residential streets unless otherwise approved by city council. 
(2)	Vehicles operating under this chapter for collection of materials from commercial customers shall be excused from the seasonal weight restrictions placed on city roads except that: 
a.	No such vehicle shall be operated during the seasonal weight restrictions when the gross weight on any single axle exceeds 14,000 pounds. 
b.	During seasonal weight restrictions commercial collectors may provide weekly service to accounts on the following roads: 
1.	Park Avenue. 
2.	Central Avenue. 
3.	Grand Avenue. 
4.	Lakeview Avenue. 
5.	Orchard Lane. 
6.	Inglewood Lane. 
7.	Dexter Drive. 
8.	Glenmoor Lane. 
9.	Watertown Road. 
10.	May Street. 
c.	No roll-off container service that exceeds the seasonal weight restrictions shall be operated on a posted road. 
d.	During any period of time when weight restrictions are imposed, each collector shall make provisions for operation and conformance with such restrictions so that service is not interrupted. 
(Code 1989, § 900.40; Ord. No. 210, § 900.40, 9-16-1992; Ord. No. 213, § 900.40, 5-2-2000) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 34. 
Sec. 28-63. - Rates and charges. 
(a)	The licensee shall negotiate service needs and rates with individual customers. 
(b)	All licensed residential haulers shall provide free yard waste disposal for a two-week period in both the spring and fall. Dates shall be prearranged between the licensee and the city. 
(c)	The licensee shall establish and maintain an office within local calling distance or with a toll-free telephone number, with telephone, and shall provide the telephone number to all dwelling units serviced by the licensee not less than four hours per day, Monday through Friday. All complaints shall be logged and provided to the city during each license renewal. 
(d)	The licensee shall be responsible for billing its customers. 
(Code 1989, § 900.50; Ord. No. 210, § 900.50, 9-16-1992; Ord. No. 213, § 900.50, 5-2-2000) 
Chapter 30 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS, AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Any ordinance or resolution dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-9(a)(5); buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; environment, ch. 16; parks and recreation, ch. 22; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 24; planning and development, ch. 26; traffic and vehicles, ch. 34; leaving wrecked, nonoperating vehicles on street, § 34-234; skateboards, roller skates, roller blades and roller skis, § 34-321 et seq.; utilities, ch. 36; vegetation, ch. 38; waterways, ch. 40.
