ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS, CURBS, AND GUTTERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to construct, modify, repair, maintain and control streets, sidewalks and public grounds, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 6. 

Sec. 30-31. - Permit required. 
    No sidewalk, curb or gutter shall be constructed on any street, avenue, right-of-way or other public property in the city without first having obtained a permit. Application for such permit shall be made on forms to be approved by the council. No permit, however, shall be required for any such improvement ordered or to be installed by the city. 
(Code 1989, § 420.01) 
Sec. 30-32. - Specifications and regulations for construction. 
    All sidewalks, curbs and gutters constructed upon any street, avenue or other public property in the city shall be constructed according to plans and specifications on file with and approved by the council. Before any construction is begun, the city shall establish grades and assist in determining their locations. If such grade or location has not been established before the filing of an application for a permit to construct the improvement, the council shall order the city engineer, or other person designated by the council, to establish the grade, unless the permit is denied for cause; and the expense of such work shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1989, § 420.02) 
Sec. 30-33. - Inspection and supervision. 
    The council shall require the inspection of all work done under this article as deemed necessary. Any work not done according to specifications shall be corrected or removed at the cost of the owner. 
(Code 1989, § 420.03) 
Secs. 30-34-30-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CULVERTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to establish and maintain drains, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 6. 

Sec. 30-61. - New culverts. 
    All new culverts in the city put in or placed under driveways shall be put in only upon authorization by the council and be of such size and material deemed necessary to take care of drainage. The council, upon recommendation by the city engineer, shall decide on the size and material to be used. 
(Code 1989, § 405.01) 
Sec. 30-62. - Culverts of insufficient size. 
    Where culverts now in use are found to be of insufficient size to take care of the drainage, the council shall order a culvert of sufficient size and proper material put in to take care of drainage. 
(Code 1989, § 405.02) 
State Law reference- Culvert widths, Minn. Stats. § 165.04 (roads and highways). 
Sec. 30-63. - City payment. 
    The city shall pay 20 percent of the cost of a required pipe or culvert and 20 percent of the cost of labor of placing it. 
(Code 1989, § 405.03) 
Chapter 34 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance establishing traffic or parking regulations on any street or public way, including traffic schedules saved from repeal, § 1-9(a)(10); parking or obstructing fire lanes prohibited, § 18-172; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 20; collector licensing for vehicles, § 28-62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 30. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate traffic, Minn. Stats. § 169.04. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Penalties. 
    When any provision of this chapter covers the same subject for which a penalty is provided for in Minn. Stats. ch. 169, the penalty for violations shall be identical with the penalty provided for in Minn. Stats. ch. 169 for the same offense. 
State Law reference- Local traffic ordinances addressing the same subject for which a penalty is provided in Minn. Stats. ch. 169 shall provide a penalty identical with the one provided for the same offense in chapter 169, Minn. Stats. § 169.022. 
Sec. 34-2. - State law incorporated by reference. 
    The regulatory provisions of the Minnesota Highway Traffic Regulation Act, Minn. Stats. ch. 169 shall regulate the use of highways, streets and alleys within the city, and are adopted and incorporated by this reference and made a part of this section as if completely set forth and set out in full. 
(Code 1989, § 800.01) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt and incorporate by reference any state statute, pertinent administrative rule or code, Minn. Stats. § 471.62. 
Sec. 34-3. - State driver's license law incorporated by reference. 
    The regulatory provisions of the state driver's license law, Minn. Stats. ch. 171, are adopted and incorporated in and made a part of this section as completely as if set out in full. 
(Code 1989, § 800.02) 
State Law reference- Minn. Stats. §§ 171.01-171.28 may be cited as the Driver's License Law, Minn. Stats. § 171.28; authority to adopt and incorporate by reference any state statute, pertinent administrative rule or code, Minn. Stats. § 471.62. 
Secs. 34-4-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 34-31-34-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRUCKS 

Sec. 34-51. - Purpose and intent. 
    This division is intended to limit and prohibit truck traffic over and upon certain residential streets and to provide penalties for enforcement. 
(Code 1989, § 820.01) 
Sec. 34-52. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency vehicles means any motor vehicle authorized by law to carry flashing lights and siren and which is used for public safety purposes to respond to medical, fire and police related emergencies. 
    Garbage truck means any motor vehicle designed and used for the purpose of collecting and hauling garbage and refuse for hire and which is used to perform such contract services for residents and businesses within the city. 
    Maintenance vehicle means any motor vehicle which is owned or operated for maintenance or construction purposes by the city, county or state or by a public utility or by a contractor having a bona fide maintenance or construction contract with the city. 
    School bus means any motor vehicle meeting the definition of school bus as found in Minn. Stats. § 169.01, subd. 6. 
    Truck means any motor vehicle meeting the definition of truck as found in Minn. Stats. § 169.01, subd. 49. 
    Trucks serving residential properties means delivery, maintenance and/or construction motor vehicles which are privately owned and which are used in making deliveries or performing services to specific residential households within the city. 
(Code 1989, § 820.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definition of emergency vehicle, Minn. Stats. § 169.01, subd. 5. 
Sec. 34-53. - Prohibited through truck traffic. 
    It is unlawful for any driver or operator of a truck to drive, operate or be in physical control of such motor vehicle upon or over the following streets: 
Apple Glen Road 
Bollum Lane 
Bollum Circle 
Central Avenue 
Charles Street 
Creekside Drive 
Dexter Drive 
Dupont Street 
Glendale Drive 
Glenmoor Lane 
Grand Avenue 
Greenhill Lane 
Harrington Drive 
Hartington Circle 
Heather Lane 
Highview Lane 
Inglewood Street 
Kennedy Lane 
Lakeview Avenue 
Lindawood Lane 
May Street 
Martha Lane 
Meadow Lane 
Neilson Avenue 
Orchard Lane 
Orchard Circle 
Orono Orchard Road 
Park Avenue 
Russell Lane 
Stoneridge Circle 
Symes Street 
Upper Lea Lane 
Valley View 
Virginia Avenue 
Watertown Road 
Westwood Drive 
(Code 1989, § 820.01) 
Sec. 34-54. - Exemptions. 
    The following motor vehicles are exempted from the provisions of section 34-53: 
(1)	School buses; 
(2)	Maintenance vehicles; 
(3)	Garbage trucks; 
(4)	Trucks serving residential properties; and 
(5)	Emergency vehicles. 
(Code 1989, § 820.02) 
Sec. 34-55. - Violations. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this division is guilty of a petty misdemeanor and upon the second or more conviction is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1989, § 820.04) 
Secs. 34-56-34-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXHIBITION DRIVING 

Sec. 34-81. - Purpose and intent. 
    The council enacts this division in order to promote the public safety and welfare with respect to certain hazardous driving conduct. 
(Code 1989, § 825.01) 
Sec. 34-82. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Exhibition driving means the operation of a motor vehicle in such a way as to cause it to stop, start, accelerate, decelerate or turn at such rate of speed so as to cause tires to squeal, gears to grind, soil or gravel to be thrown, engine backfire, fishtailing or skidding or, as to two-wheeled or three-wheeled motor vehicles, the front wheel to lose contact with the ground or roadway surface. 
    Motor vehicle means any vehicle which is self-propelled or propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires used for the purpose of transporting persons or property over the ground whether on or off public highways and whether or not such vehicle is required to carry a motor vehicle registration and whether or not its operation requires a license. A motor vehicle does not include a vehicle moved solely by human power. 
(Code 1989, § 825.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definition of motor vehicle, Minn. Stats. § 169.01, subd. 3. 
Sec. 34-83. - Exhibition driving prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to do any exhibition driving on any street, parking lot or any other public or private property, except when an emergency creates the need for such operation to prevent injury to persons or damage to property. 
(Code 1989, § 825.03) 
Secs. 34-84-34-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SEASONAL WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Except where express statutory authority may be granted, local governmental units have no authority to alter the size, weight, and load limits prescribed by Minn. Stats. §§ 169.80-169.88, Minn. Stats. § 169.80, subd. 1. 

Sec. 34-101. - Purpose. 
    This division shall delineate: 
(1)	The city engineer's authority to impose: 
a.	Emergency limits and restrictions; and 
b.	Limitations upon operation or weight of trucks or commercial vehicles; 
(2)	Seasonal restrictions and exemptions; 
(3)	Specific streets with: 
a.	Four-ton axle limits; and 
b.	Nine-ton axle limits; and 
(4)	Weight limitations on Willow Drive Bridge. 
(Code 1989, § 810.01) 
Sec. 34-102. - Scope. 
    The weight limitations set out in this division apply only to vehicles operated exclusively within the city. All other vehicles are subject to the weight limitations delineated at Minn. Stats. § 169.825. 
(Code 1989, § 810.01) 
Sec. 34-103. - Engineer to impose restrictions. 
    The city engineer may prohibit the operation of vehicles upon any street or road or impose restrictions as to the weight of vehicles to be operated on such streets or roads whenever any such street or road, by reason of deterioration, rain, snow or other climatic conditions, will be seriously damaged or destroyed unless such prohibitions or weight restrictions are imposed. The city engineer shall erect or cause to be erected and maintained signs plainly indicating the prohibition or restriction at each end of that portion of any affected street or road, and the prohibition or restriction shall only be effective upon erection of such signs. Once erected, no person shall remove, deface or cause the visibility of any such sign to be reduced except by order of the city engineer. 
(Code 1989, § 810.02) 
State Law reference- No ordinance regulating size, weight and load limits shall be effective until signs giving notice of the regulations are posted upon the highway affected, Minn. Stats. § 169.04. 
Sec. 34-104. - Engineer to limit vehicles. 
    The city engineer, with respect to streets or roads within the city, may also prohibit the operation of trucks or other commercial vehicles, or may impose limitations as to the weight on designated roads, which prohibitions or limitations shall be designated by appropriate signs placed upon such streets or roads. All such prohibitions or restrictions shall only be effective upon placement of signs plainly giving notice of such prohibitions or restrictions upon the affected streets or roads. Once erected, no person shall remove, deface or cause the visibility of any such sign to be reduced except by order of the city engineer. 
(Code 1989, § 810.03) 
Sec. 34-105. - Seasonal restrictions. 
    Except where other prohibitions or restrictions are imposed as provided in sections 34-106 and 34-107, no person shall operate any vehicle or combination of vehicles upon any street or road within the corporate limits of the city during the period of March 1 to May 15 of each year, where the gross weight on any single axle, as defined by Minn. Stats. § 169.825 exceeds the limits set forth in sections 34-106 and 34-107, provided that there shall be exempted from these provisions refuse collection vehicles where the gross weight on any single axle exceeds 14,000 pounds and emergency vehicles of the city, county, state or any public utility used in making repairs to its plant, equipment or improvement. 
(Code 1989, § 810.04) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit the operation or impose restrictions as to the weight of vehicles upon any highway under its jurisdiction which, by reason of deterioration, rain, snow or other climatic conditions, will be seriously damaged or destroyed otherwise, Minn. Stats. § 169.87, subd. 1. 
Sec. 34-106. - Streets with four-ton axle limits. 
    The following streets are designated as four-ton axle limit streets: 
Apple Glen Road

(Code 1989, § 810.05)

    The following streets are designated as nine-ton axle limit streets:

Premier Drive 
Shaughnessy Avenue 
Symes Street 
Tamarack Avenue 
West Industrial Boulevard 
Willow Drive 
(Code 1989, § 810.06) 
Sec. 34-108. - Willow Drive Bridge. 
    The bridge on Willow Drive going over the Burlington Northern Railroad shall have a yearround weight restriction of 19 tons per vehicle or 32 tons per truck and full trailer or semitrailer combination. No person shall operate a vehicle excess in weight to these limits over and across this bridge. 
(Code 1989, § 810.07) 
Secs. 34-109-34-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, parking provisions, Minn. Stats. §§ 169.32-169.36. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 34-141-34-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 34-161. - Generally. 
    The following additional traffic and parking regulations govern the use of highways, streets and alleys within the city: 
(1)	Commercial vehicle. No person shall park a commercial vehicle of more than one-ton capacity upon U.S. Highway 12 within the city limits and Mill Street to Lake Street; however, this shall not prohibit the parking of such vehicles for more than a period of 30 minutes on any such street for the purpose of having access to any abutting property when such access cannot conveniently be secured from any alley or other side street. 
(2)	Vehicles for sale. No vehicle shall be parked on any street or boulevard for the purpose of displaying it for sale. 
(3)	Vehicles obstructing plowing. No vehicle shall be parked on any street, alley, boulevard, sidewalk or public ground so as to obstruct or hinder the plowing or removal of snow; and any police officer may cause such vehicle to be removed to a garage and the cost of such removal and storage shall be paid by the owner. 
(4)	Congested district parking. No person shall park a vehicle within the congested district of the city for a period longer than two hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. The congested area is defined as all of U.S. Highway 12 from the east limits to the west limits of the city, and the south 200 feet of Mill Street. 
(5)	Wrecked or damaged vehicles. Any wrecked or damaged vehicle shall be removed from any street in the city without unreasonable delay and, pending removal, if conditions warrant the care, such vehicle shall be guarded by proper lights or by flares. 
(6)	All-night parking prohibited. No person, except an operator of an emergency vehicle on emergency call, shall park a vehicle on any street between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of any day. 
(Code 1989, § 805.01) 
Sec. 34-162. - No parking provisions. 
(a)	North side of U.S. Highway 12. No vehicle shall be parked at any time on the north side of U.S. Highway 12 that borders the following tracts of land: 
(1)	That part of lot 7 lying easterly of a line running from a point in the southerly line of lot 7 a distance of 200 feet westerly from southeasterly corner to the most northerly corner of lot 7 (plat 59060, parcel 7001). 
(2)	That part of lot 7 lying westerly of a line running from a point in the southerly line of lot 7 a distance of 200 feet westerly from the southeasterly corner to the most northerly corner of lot 7 (plat 59060, parcel 7010). 
(3)	Lot 8, block 1, Nelson's Long Lake Addition (plat 59060, parcel 8000). 
(4)	Commencing at the most northerly corner of lot 19, then southeasterly along the northeasterly line and its extension to the north line of the state highway, then northwesterly along the northerly line of the highway to the southwesterly line of lot 19, then northwesterly to the most westerly corner, then northeasterly to the beginning except the state highway (plat 58990, parcel 3801). 
(5)	Southwesterly 80 feet of lots 9 and 10, block 4 (plat 59010, parcel 2400). 
The tracts of land described in this subsection are more commonly known as State Bank of Long Lake, Rettinger Brothers Oil, Rettinger Brothers Oil Station, and Red Rooster, Inc. 
(b)	Watertown Road and west side of Willow Drive. No person shall park a vehicle at any time on any portion of Watertown Road lying within the city limits, or on the west side of Willow Drive from U.S. Highway No. 12 to the railroad trestle of the Great Northern Railway lying south of the highway, except an operator of an emergency vehicle on emergency call. 
(c)	Lakeview Avenue. No parking of motor vehicles is allowed on Lakeview Avenue from Park Avenue to Central Avenue at any time. 
(Code 1989, § 805.02) 
Sec. 34-163. - Truck parking. 
(a)	Detached semitrailer. It is unlawful to park a detached semitrailer upon any street, city-owned parking lot, or other public property except streets as specifically designated by the council by resolution and signposted. 
(b)	Trucks in residential districts. It is unlawful to park a truck (other than a truck of 9,000 pounds gross vehicle weight or less), truck-trailer, tractor-trailer or truck-tractor within an area zoned as a residential district except for the purpose of loading or unloading. 
(c)	Trucks in business district. It is unlawful to park a commercial vehicle of more than 9,000 pounds gross vehicle weight upon any street in the business district except streets as specifically designated by the council by resolution and signposted, but parking of such vehicle for a period of not more than 20 minutes shall be permitted in such space for the purpose of necessary access to abutting property while actively loading or unloading when such access cannot reasonably be secured from an alley or from an adjacent street where truck parking is not so restricted. 
(d)	Diagonal parking. It is unlawful to park a truck or other vehicle using or equipped with a trailer or extended body or other extension or projection beyond the original length of such vehicle or any passenger bus diagonally along any street except for a time sufficient to load or unload, and in such case only parallel parking shall be permitted; however, a truck may stand backed up to the curb if the weight or bulk of the load makes parallel parking impracticable but then only for a period of time sufficient to load or unload. 
(e)	Twenty-minute time limit. Parking of commercial vehicles is permitted in duly designated and signposted loading zones and in alleys for a period of up to 20 minutes provided that such alley parking does not prevent the flow of traffic in the alley, all of which shall be for the purpose of access to abutting or adjacent property while actively loading or unloading. 
(Code 1989, § 815.01) 
Secs. 34-164-34-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PHYSICALLY DISABLED[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Parking privilege for physically disabled, Minn. Stats. § 169.345. 

Sec. 34-181. - Regulated. 
(a)	Statutory parking privileges. Statutory parking privileges for physically handicapped shall be strictly observed and enforced. Police officers are authorized to tag vehicles on either private or public property in violation of such statutory privileges. 
(b)	Parking restrictions. It is unlawful for any person, whether or not physically handicapped, to stop, park or leave standing, a motor vehicle in a signposted fire lane at any time or in lanes where, and during such hours as, parking is prohibited to accommodate heavy traffic during morning and afternoon rush hours. 
(Code 1989, § 815.02) 
Sec. 34-182. - Violation a misdemeanor or petty misdemeanor. 
    Every person violates a section, subdivision, paragraph or provision of this division when he performs an act prohibited or declared unlawful by this division, or fails to act when such failure is prohibited or declared unlawful, and upon conviction, shall be punished as follows: 
(1)	Where the specific section, subdivision, paragraph or provision specifically makes violation a misdemeanor, he shall be punished as for a misdemeanor; where a violation is committed in a manner or under circumstances so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property, he shall be punished as for a misdemeanor; where he stands convicted of violation of any provision of this division, exclusive of violations relating to the standing or parking of an unattended vehicle, within the immediate preceding 12-month period for the third or subsequent time, he shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. 
(2)	As to any violation not constituting a misdemeanor under the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, he shall be punished as for a petty misdemeanor. 
(3)	As to violations of parking privilege or parking criteria for the disabled, the penalties shall coincide with those required by Minn. Stats. §§ 169.345 and 169.346. 
(Ord. No. 175, § 4, 5-7-1985) 
State Law reference- Enhancement of penalty, Minn. Stats. § 169.89; penalties for violation of disabled parking criteria, Minn. Stats. § 169.346, subd. 3. 
Secs. 34-183-34-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - WATERCRAFT TRANSPORTS 

Sec. 34-201. - Purpose and intent. 
    The city council finds that a substantial public nuisance has developed with respect to the use of public and private property and city streets for temporary parking of trailers or any other type of conveyance used to transport motorboats, personal watercraft, and other watercraft as defined by Minn. Stats. § 86B.005, et seq., by persons using or intending to use Long Lake for recreational purposes. The purpose of this division is to abate the public nuisance, and to promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city through the regulation of parking of such vehicles in such areas other than those designated for such use within the city. 
(Ord. No. 215, § 1, 7-18-1994) 
State Law reference- Elements of a public nuisance, Minn. Stats. § 609.74; authority to define nuisances and provide for their prevention or abatement, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 23. 
Sec. 34-202. - Prohibition. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park and/or leave unattended for more than 15 minutes on any public property, street or private property located on or contiguous to Symes Street, Lake Street or Mill Street within the city any trailer or any other type of conveyance used to transport motorboats, personal watercraft or other watercraft as defined by Minn. Stats. § 86B.005 et seq., whether or not hitched to a motor vehicle, except in the area located in Nelson's Lakeside Park specifically designed "Boat Trailer Parking" by sign or otherwise. However, this prohibition shall not apply to the following: 
(1)	Persons who own or lease real property on or contiguous to Symes Street, Lake Street or Mills Street in the city and who use their owned or leased property for storage and/or parking purposes; 
(2)	Persons who obtained the written permission of an owner or tenant of real property within the past 30 days located at or contiguous to Symes Street, Lake Street or Mill Street in the city to park or leave their trailer on the owner/tenant's real property while they use their boat or watercraft on Long Lake; and 
(3)	Any police, fire or public safety officer while in the performance of his official duties. 
(Ord. No. 215, § 2, 7-18-1994) 
Sec. 34-203. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this division is guilty of a petty misdemeanor. The registered owner shall be deemed prima facie to be the operator of the motor vehicle, trailer or other conveyance for purposes of enforcement of this division. 
(Ord. No. 215, § 3, 7-18-1994) 
State Law reference- When a local ordinance regulating traffic covers the same subject for which a penalty is provided under the Highway Traffic Regulations Act, the penalty prescribed by the local ordinance shall be identical with the penalty provided by the act for the same offense, Minn. Stats. § 169.022. 
Secs. 34-204-34-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate abandoned motor vehicles as long as the regulations are not less stringent than the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 168B, Minn. Stats. § 168B.09, subd. 2. 

Sec. 34-231. - Reason for division. 
(a)	The council finds, determines and declares vehicles are or may in the future be abandoned in the streets and partially dismantled, wrecked, junked, not operating or discarded vehicles left about the city other than in junkyards or other appropriate places; and such conditions tend to impede traffic in the streets or interfere with the enjoyment of and reduce the value of private property, invite plundering, create fire hazards and other safety and health hazards to children as well as adults, interfere with the comfort and well-being of the public, and create, extend and aggravate area plight; and adequate protection of the public health, safety and welfare requires that such conditions be regulated, abated or prohibited. 
(b)	Under the provisions of Minn. Stats. § 168B.09, subd. 2, the city exercises its authority to enact ordinances and regulations equal to or more stringent than those set out in Minn. Stats. §§ 168B.01-168B.101 and Minn. Rules §§ 7035.3000-7035.3600, pertaining to abandoned motor vehicles. 
(Code 1989, § 830.01) 
Sec. 34-232. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned motor vehicle means a motor vehicle, as defined in Minn. Stats. § 169.01, that has: 
(1)	Remained for a period of more than 48 hours on public property illegally, or more than four hours on property owned or controlled by a unit of government when it is properly posted. 
(2)	Remained for a period of more than 48 hours on public property and is lacking vital component parts such that it is in an inoperable condition. 
(3)	Remained for a period of more than 48 hours on private property without the consent of the person in control of such property. 
(4)	Remained for a period of more than 48 hours on private property, with or without the consent of the person in control of such property, which is in an inoperable condition such that it has no substantial potential further use consistent with its usual functions, unless it is kept in an enclosed garage or storage building. 
(5)	Been voluntarily surrendered by its owner to a unit of government or a person duly licensed pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 168B.10 and this article. 
A classic car or pioneer car, as defined in Minn. Stats. § 168.10 shall not be considered an abandoned motor vehicle within the meaning of this article. 
    Private property means any real property which is not a duly dedicated street, highway, public ground or public building. 
    Street and highway mean the dedicated traveled portion of any public way between the boundaries of private property, whenever it is open to the use of the public for the purposes of travel. 
    Vehicle means any device or machine designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides and transport persons or property, and shall include without limitation automobiles, trucks, trailers, wagons, tractors and motorcycles. 
(Code 1989, § 830.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definition of abandoned motor vehicle, Minn. Stats. § 168B.011, subd. 2, Minn. Rules § 7035.3100, subp. 1; definition of vehicle, Minn. Stats. § 169.01, subd. 2. 
Sec. 34-233. - Prohibited. 
    No person shall abandon any vehicle within the city, and no person shall leave any vehicle at any place within the city for such time or under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. 
(Code 1989, § 830.03) 
State Law reference- Any person who abandons a motor vehicle on any public or private property, without the consent of the person in control of such property, is guilty of a misdemeanor, Minn. Stats. § 168B.03. 
Sec. 34-234. - Leaving wrecked, nonoperating vehicles on street. 
    No person shall leave any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked or junked vehicle or any vehicle not properly licensed for operation within the state on any street or highway within the city. 
(Code 1989, § 830.04) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 30. 
State Law reference- Authority to impound vehicles left unattended on public property, Minn. Stats. § 168B.04, subd. 2(b)(1). 
Sec. 34-235. - Disposition of wrecked or discarded vehicles. 
    No person in charge or control of any property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, shall permit or allow any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked, junked or discarded vehicle or any vehicle not properly licensed for operation within the state to remain on such property longer than 24 hours; except that this section shall not apply to vehicles within a closed building or a vehicle on the premises of a business or enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner when necessary to the operation of such business or enterprise. 
(Code 1989, § 830.05) 
State Law reference- Authority to impound a vehicle left unattended on private property, Minn. Stats. § 168B.04, subd. 2(b)(2). 
Sec. 34-236. - Removal. 
    Any police officer is authorized to remove or have removed any vehicle left at any place within the city which reasonably appears to be in violation of this article or lost, stolen or unclaimed. Such vehicle may be removed, impounded or disposed of according to section 34-237. 
(Code 1989, § 830.06) 
State Law reference- Authority to take into custody and impound any unauthorized vehicle under Minn. Stats. §§ 169.041, 168B.04, subd. 2(a). 
Sec. 34-237. - Authority to remove. 
(a)	Abatement of nuisance. Any vehicle parked or stored in violation of any section of this article or of the law of the state is declared to be a nuisance and may be summarily abated by removing such vehicle by or under the direction of any police officer of the city by means of towing or otherwise. Within 24 hours thereafter, written notice that the vehicle has been impounded shall be sent by the police officer to the owner and all readily identifiable lienholders. The notice shall: 
(1)	Set forth the date and place of the taking, the year, make, model and serial number of the impounded motor vehicle if such information can be reasonably obtained, and the place where the vehicle is being held; 
(2)	Inform the owner and any lienholders of their right to reclaim the vehicle under Minn. Stats. § 168B.07; and 
(3)	State that failure of the owner or lienholders to exercise their right to reclaim the vehicle and contents within the appropriate time allowed under Minn. Stats. § 168B.051, subd. 1, 1a or 2, shall be deemed a waiver by them of all right, title and interest in the vehicle and contents and a consent to the transfer of title to and disposal or sale of the vehicle and contents pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 168B.08. 
(b)	Notice by mail or publication. The notice shall be sent by mail to the registered owner, if any, of an impounded vehicle and to all readily identifiable lienholders of record. The department of motor vehicles shall make this information available to impound lot operators for notification purposes. If it is impossible to determine with reasonable certainty the identity and address of the registered owner and all lienholders, the notice shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the area where the motor vehicle was towed from or abandoned. Published notices may be grouped together for convenience and economy. 
(c)	Unauthorized vehicle; notice. If an unauthorized vehicle remains unclaimed after 30 days from the date the notice was sent under subsection (b) of this section, a second notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the registered owner, if any, of the unauthorized vehicle and to all readily identifiable lienholders of record. 
(Code 1989, § 830.07) 
State Law reference- Authority to define nuisances and provide for their prevention or abatement, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 23. 
Sec. 34-238. - Prosecution. 
    The impounding of any vehicle shall not prevent or preclude the institution of prosecution of any criminal proceedings against the owner or operator of such impounded vehicle. 
(Code 1989, § 830.08) 
Sec. 34-239. - Claiming vehicle. 
    Before the owner or his agent shall be permitted to remove a vehicle from the possession of the police officer he shall: 
(1)	Furnish satisfactory evidence to the police officer of his identity and ownership of the vehicle; 
(2)	Pay all towing and storage charges resulting from taking the vehicle into custody; and 
(3)	Sign a written receipt for the vehicle. 
(Code 1989, § 830.09) 
State Law reference- Right of owner or lienholder to reclaim impounded vehicle, Minn. Stats. § 168B.07. 
Sec. 34-240. - Sale of the vehicle. 
    If at the expiration of 60 days after mailing or publication of the notice as provided in section 34-237 such vehicle is not redeemed by the owner or his agent, the police chief shall proceed to sell the vehicle in accordance with the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 168B. 
(Code 1989, § 830.10) 
State Law reference- Authority to sell impounded vehicles, Minn. Stats. §§ 168B.051 and 168B.08. 
Secs. 34-241-34-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SNOWMOBILES AND ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate the operation of snowmobiles on public lands, streets, highways, waters and property provided such regulations are not inconsistent with the provisions of Minn. Stats. §§ 84.81-84.88, Minn. Stats. § 84.87, subd. 3. 

Sec. 34-271. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. A term used in Minn. Stats. § 84.81 has the meaning given it by that section. 
    All-terrain vehicle and vehicle mean a motorized flotation-tired vehicle of not less than three low-pressure tires, but not more than six tires, that is limited in engine displacement of less than 800 cubic centimeters and total dry weight less than 800 pounds. 
State Law reference- Definition of all-terrain vehicle, Minn. Stats. § 84.92, subd. 8. 
    Deadman throttle and safety throttle mean a device which when pressure is removed from the engine accelerator or throttle, causes the motor to be disengaged from the driving mechanism. 
    Natural terrain means areas other than roadways or driveways (private or public), parking lots and other areas the surface of which has been intentionally modified for motor vehicle operation. 
    Operate means to ride in or on and control the operation of a snowmobile or ATV. 
State Law reference- Definition of operate, Minn. Stats. § 84.81, subd. 5. 
    Operator means every person who operates or is in actual physical control of a snowmobile or ATV. 
State Law reference- Definition of operator, Minn. Stats. § 84.81, subd. 6. 
    Owner means a person, other than a lienholder having the property in or title to a snowmobile or ATV entitled to its use or possession. 
State Law reference- Definition of owner, Minn. Stats. §§ 84.81, subd. 4, 84.92, subd. 5. 
    Public waters means all waters lying wholly within the state and all portions of boundary waters within the jurisdiction of the state contained within any wilderness areas and which the public has a right to use for navigation, fishing, hunting or any other beneficial public use. 
State Law reference- Definition of public waters, Minn. Stats. § 84.43, subd. 3. 
    Snowmobile means a self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on snow or ice steered by skis or runners. 
State Law reference- Definition of snowmobile, Minn. Stats. § 84.81, subd. 3. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.01, 6-18-1996) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-272. - Adoption of state code. 
    The provisions of Minn. Stats. §§ 84.81-84.90 and 84.92-84.929 are adopted by reference. These sections shall apply to all public streets and all snowmobiles and ATVs used in the city. However, this article shall not apply to any public waters, frozen or open, located within the city. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.02, 6-18-1996) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt and incorporate by reference any state statute, pertinent administrative rule or code, Minn. Stats. § 471.62. 
Sec. 34-273. - Operation. 
    Except as otherwise permitted in this article, it is unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile or ATV not licensed as a motor vehicle as follows: 
(1)	On the portion of any right-of-way of any public highway, street, road, travel or alley used for motor vehicle travel. A snowmobile may be operated upon the ditch bottom or the outside bank of a trunk, county state-aid and county highways where such highways are so configured within the corporate limits. 
(2)	On a public sidewalk or bicycle trail provided for pedestrian or bicycle travel. 
(3)	On boulevards within any public right-of-way. 
(4)	On private property of another without specific permission of the owner or person in control of the property. 
(5)	At a rate of speed greater than reasonable or proper under all surrounding circumstances. 
(6)	At any place in a careless, reckless or negligent manner, or heedlessly in disregard of the rights or safety of others, or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger or cause injury or damage to any person or property. 
State Law reference- It shall be unlawful to operate a snowmobile or all-terrain vehicle at a rate of speed greater than reasonable or proper under all the surrounding circumstances, Minn. Stats. §§ 84.87, subd. 2(1), 84.928, subd. 2(1). 
(7)	So as to tow any person or thing except through use of a rigid towbar attached to the rear of the snowmobile or ATV. 
(8)	At any place while under the influence of alcohol or drugs as prohibited by Minn. Stats. §§ 84.91-84.911, 169.121-169.1218, and 169.123-169.129, which are incorporated by reference. 
(9)	Within 100 feet of any pedestrian, fisherman, skating rink or sliding area where the operation would conflict with the use or endanger other persons or property. 
(10)	On any publicly owned land and all public waters, frozen or open, located in the city. The public land to which this prohibition applies includes but is not limited to school grounds, park property, playgrounds, recreation areas and golf courses, except areas designated for use by the city council by council resolution. Any area so designated shall be posted with signs indicating authorized use. 
(11)	During the hours of 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m., of any day. 
(12)	At a speed greater than ten miles per hour when within 100 feet of any lakeshore, or of fishermen and icehouse or skating rink. 
(13)	In a manner so as to create a loud, unnecessary or unusual noise which disturbs, annoys or interferes with the peace and quiet of other persons. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.03, 6-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-274. - Special orders. 
    In addition to the regulations provided in section 34-273, it is unlawful to operate a snowmobile or ATV on any public place where prohibited by order of the city. The city shall have the power, by written order, to prohibit such operation whenever in its discretion it would be likely to produce damage to property or endanger the safety or repose of other persons. Such areas shall be appropriately signposted before such order shall become effective. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.04, 6-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-275. - Direct crossings. 
    A snowmobile or ATV may make a direct crossing of a street or highway, except an interstate highway or freeway, provided: 
(1)	The crossing is made at an angle of approximately 90 degrees to the direction of the street or highway and at a place where no obstruction prevents a quick and safe crossing. 
(2)	The snowmobile or ATV is brought to a complete stop before crossing the shoulder or main-traveled way. 
(3)	The driver yields the right-of-way to all oncoming traffic which constitutes an immediate hazard. 
(4)	In crossing a divided street or highway, the crossing is made only at an intersection of such street or highway with another public street or highway. 
(5)	If the crossing is made between the hours of one-half hour after sunset, but before 10:00 p.m., to one-half hour before sunrise, but after 7:00 a.m., or in conditions of reduced visibility, only if both front and rear lights are on. An ATV not licensed as a motor vehicle is forbidden to cross highways or streets except when pushed across by human power. An ATV when pushed across highways or streets shall be subject to all the regulations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.05, 6-18-1996) 
State Law reference- Criteria for permissible direct crossing of a street or highway by a snowmobile or all-terrain vehicle, respectively, Minn. Stats. §§ 84.87, subd. 1(b), 84.928, subd. 1a(a). 
Sec. 34-276. - Yielding the right-of-way. 
    It is unlawful for any person operating a snowmobile to enter any intersection without yielding the right-of-way to any vehicles or pedestrians at the intersection, or so close to the intersection as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.06, 6-18-1996) 
State Law reference- A snowmobile or all-terrain vehicle may make a direct crossing of a street or highway at any hour of the day, provided the driver yields the right-of-way to all oncoming traffic which constitutes an immediate hazard, Minn. Stats. §§ 84.87, subd. 1(b), 84.928, subd. 1a(3). 
Sec. 34-277. - Persons under 18. 
(a)	Snowmobiles. 
(1)	It is unlawful for any person under the age of 14 years to operate a snowmobile for any purpose as the operator of a snowmobile. A person 14 years of age or older but less than 18 years of age may operate a snowmobile as permitted under this article only if that person has in his possession a safety certificate issued by the commissioner of natural resources or a valid motor vehicle operator's license issued by the commissioner of public safety or the driver's license authority of another state as provided by Minn. Stats. § 84.872. 
(2)	It is unlawful for the owner of a snowmobile to permit the snowmobile to be operated contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(3)	It is unlawful for a person under the age of 18 years to operate or ride a snowmobile without wearing protective headgear that complies with standards established by the commissioner of public safety. 
(b)	All-terrain vehicles. 
(1)	Except for operation on public road rights-of-way that is permitted under Minn. Stats. § 84.928, a driver's license issued by the state or another state is required to operate an all-terrain vehicle along or on a public road right-of-way. 
(2)	A person under 12 years of age shall not: 
a.	Make a direct crossing of a public road right-of-way; 
b.	Operate an all-terrain vehicle on a public road right-of-way in the state; or 
c.	Operate an all-terrain vehicle on public lands or waters. 
(3)	Except for public road rights-of-way of interstate highways, a person 12 years of age but less than 16 years may make a direct crossing of a public road right-of-way of a trunk, county state-aid or county highway or operate on public lands and waters only if that person possesses a valid all-terrain vehicle safety certificate issued by the commissioner and is accompanied on another all-terrain vehicle by a person 18 years of age or older who holds a valid driver's license. 
(4)	All-terrain vehicle safety certificates issued by the commissioner to persons 12 years old but less than 16 years old are not valid for machines in excess of 90cc engine capacity. 
(5)	A person less than 18 years of age shall not operate an all-terrain vehicle on public land, public waters or on a public road right-of-way unless wearing a safety helmet approved by the commissioner of public safety. 
(6)	It is unlawful for any person who is in lawful control of an all-terrain vehicle to permit it to be operated contrary to this section. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.07, 6-18-1996) 
State Law reference- It is unlawful for any person who is the owner or in lawful control of a snowmobile to permit it to be operated contrary to statutory provisions, Minn. Stats. § 84.872, subd. 1a. 
Sec. 34-278. - Equipment. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile or ATV any place within the city unless it is equipped with the following: 
(1)	Standard mufflers which are properly attached and which reduce the noise of operation of the motor to the minimum necessary for operation. No person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass, straight pipe or similar device on a snowmobile or ATV motor. 
State Law reference- Muffler requirements on snowmobiles, Minn. Stats. § 84.871, subd. 1. 
(2)	Brakes adequate to control the movement of and to stop and hold the snowmobile or ATV under any condition of operation. 
(3)	A safety or so-called deadman throttle in operating condition. 
(4)	When operated between the hours of one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise or at a time to reduced visibility, at least one clear lamp attached to the front, with sufficient intensity to reveal persons and vehicles at a distance of at least 100 feet ahead during the hours of darkness and under normal atmospheric conditions. Such headlamp shall be so aimed that glaring rays are not projected into the eyes of an oncoming snowmobile or ATV operator. It shall also be equipped with at least one red taillamp having a minimum candlepower of sufficient intensity to exhibit a red light plainly visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear during the hours of darkness under normal atmospheric conditions. 
(5)	Reflective material at least 16 square inches mounted on each side, forward of the handlebars, or steering device of a snowmobile or ATV and at the highest practical point on any towed object, as to reflect light at a 90-degree angle. Reflector material shall have at least the minimum intensity values as prescribed in table II of federal specifications L-S-300A, dated January 1, 1970. Registration numbers, the manufacturer's trade name, or other decorative material, if meeting minimum reflectorization standards, may be included in computing the required 16-square-inch area. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.08, 6-18-1996) 
State Law reference- Headlight and taillight requirements for snowmobiles, Minn. Stats. § 84.87, subd. 2(3), Minn. Rules § 6100.5700, subp. 1(A), (B). 
Sec. 34-279. - Locking vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any person to leave a snowmobile or ATV unless that person locks the ignition, removes the key and takes the key with him. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.09, 6-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-280. - Further regulated activities. 
    No person shall post, alter, mutilate or remove any notice or sign relating to snowmobiles on property in which he has no legal interest, including any public land. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.010, 6-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-281. - Emergencies. 
    Notwithstanding the prohibition of operating a snowmobile upon a roadway to the contrary, a snowmobile may be operated on a public thoroughfare in an emergency during the period of time when and at locations where snow upon the roadway renders travel by automobile impractical. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.011, 6-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-282. - Animals. 
    It is unlawful to intentionally drive, chase, run over or kill any animal with a snowmobile or ATV. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.012, 6-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-283. - Signal from officer to stop. 
    It is unlawful for a snowmobile or ATV operator, after having received a visible or audible signal from any law enforcement officer to come to a stop, to operate a snowmobile or ATV in willful or wanton disregard of such signal, or interfere with or endanger the law enforcement officer or any other person or vehicle, or increase speed or attempt to flee or elude the officer. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.013, 6-18-1996) 
State Law reference- Willfully failing or refusing to comply with any lawful order or direction of any peace officer invested with authority to direct, control or regulate traffic constitutes a misdemeanor, Minn. Stats. § 169.02, subd. 2. 
Sec. 34-284. - Violation. 
    Every person violates a section, subdivision, paragraph or provision of this article when the person performs an act prohibited or declared unlawful, or fails to act when such failure is prohibited or declared unlawful upon conviction shall be punished as follows: 
(1)	Misdemeanor. When the specific section, subdivision, paragraph or provision of this article specifically makes violation a misdemeanor, the person shall be punished as for a misdemeanor; where a violation is committed in a manner or under circumstances so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property the person shall be punished as for a misdemeanor; where the person stands convicted of violation of any provision of this article exclusive of violations relating to the standing or parking of an unattended vehicle, within the immediate preceding 12-month period for the third or subsequent time, the person shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. 
(2)	Petty misdemeanor. As to any violation not constituting a misdemeanor under the provisions of subsection (1) of this section, the person shall be punished as for a petty misdemeanor. 
(3)	Adoption by reference. As to any violation of a provision adopted by reference, the person shall be punished as specified in such provision so adopted. 
(4)	Impoundment. Any vehicle used in or during the violation of any provision of this article may be impounded for up to 60 days in addition to any other penalty provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 835.00, § 835.014, 6-18-1996) 
State Law reference- Penalties for violation of Minn. Stats. §§ 84.81-84.89; snowmobiles, Minn. Stats. § 84.88. 
Secs. 34-285-34-320. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SKATEBOARDS, ROLLER SKATES, ROLLER BLADES AND ROLLER SKIS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 30. 

Sec. 34-321. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect the public health and safety arising out of the use of skateboards, roller skates, roller blades and roller skis within the city. The city council finds that there is a substantial lack of statutory regulation on the use of such devices and that there have been numerous complaints of residents of the city relating to their use on public streets and in certain commercial or industrial areas such as parking lots where automobile and motorized vehicular traffic are frequent. It is also found that use of these devices on the more heavily trafficked streets and highways within the city and on commercial/industrial parking areas has created a danger to persons and property. 
(Code 1989, § 840.01) 
Sec. 34-322. - Prohibited acts. 
    It is unlawful for any person to participate or engage in any of the following acts: 
(1)	To ride or propel a skateboard, roller skates, roller blades or roller skis while on the paved and/or traveled portion of any of the following streets, roadways or highways within the jurisdictional limits of the city: 
a.	Any street or roadway in any area of the city zoned for industrial use; 
b.	U.S. Trunk Highway 12, Watertown Road, Grand Avenue, Willow Drive and North Brown Road, except designated bike routes; 
c.	Any area designated or used for ingress and egress or off-street parking within any area zoned for commercial or industrial uses within the city. 
(2)	To ride upon a skateboard, roller skates, roller blades or roller skis in any area within the jurisdictional limits of the city while being pushed, pulled or in any way propelled by any motorized vehicle or by any person on a bicycle. 
(3)	To ride or propel himself upon a skateboard, roller skates, roller blades or roller skis on any public street, roadway or highway which is not specified as prohibited in a direction which is perpendicular to the normal direction of roadway or highway traffic except for the purpose of traversing the street, roadway or highway at an intersection or designated crosswalk. 
(Code 1989, § 840.02) 
State Law reference- Persons riding upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates, toboggan, sled, skateboard or toy vehicle shall not attach the vehicle or themselves to any streetcar or vehicle upon a roadway, Minn. Stats. § 169.222, subd. 3. 
Sec. 34-323. - Observation of rules of the road. 
    Any person who participates or engages in the use of skateboards, roller skates, roller blades or roller skis on streets, roadways or highways within the city which are not specified as prohibited must observe the same rules of the road as required of bicycles pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 169.222. 
(Code 1989, § 840.03) 
Sec. 34-324. - Violations. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article is guilty of a petty misdemeanor unless the provisions of Minn. Stats. § 169.89, subd. 1, are applicable. In addition, any peace officer who observes any person violating any of the provisions of this article is authorized to seize the offender's skateboard, roller skates, roller blades or roller skis and to hold it at the Orono Police Station. In the event of such seizure, the offender, if an adult, may secure the return of the article seized after 24 hours have elapsed since the seizure. In the case of a minor, the article seized shall be returned only to the parent or guardian of such minor offender after 24 hours have elapsed since the seizure. 
(Code 1989, § 840.04) 
State Law reference- Penalties, Minn. Stats. § 169.89.
