ARTICLE II. - WATER SERVICE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to establish, own, operate, transfer or abolish public utilities, Minn. Stats. §§ 412.221, subd. 11, 412.321, subd. 1, 444.075, subd. 1a(i). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-31. - Clarification of provisions. 
    To clarify specific sections of this article, please refer to the City of Long Lake Street and Utility Standards and detail plats. Reference also the City of Long Lake Water and Sewer Service Installation, Repair and Disconnect Standards. 
Secs. 36-32-36-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to establish, own, operate, transfer or abolish public utilities, Minn. Stats. §§ 412.221, subd. 11, 412.321, subd. 1, 444.075, subd. 1a(i). 

Sec. 36-51. - Administration. 
    The council shall constitute the waterworks committee, and the city administrator shall be its executive officer serving under this article and the direction of the council. The water department shall be administered by the city administrator. 
(Code 1989, § 210.01) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 36-52. - Duties and powers of the waterworks committee (city council). 
    It shall be the duty of the waterworks committee to: 
(1)	Fix compensation of all employees of the waterworks system. 
(2)	Establish rules and regulations for the design, purchase, installation, testing, maintenance and removal of meters which shall be required to monitor all water furnished by the municipal water plant. 
(3)	Determine the amount to be charged for branch connections. 
(4)	Establish regulations for installation, maintenance and repair of service pipe between the meter and the water main or any pipes connected with the municipal water system. 
(5)	Regulate all excavations. 
(6)	Determine the location of a curb box placed in an alley. 
(7)	Set quarterly rates for all city users. 
(8)	Set charges for users of the municipal water system residing outside the corporate limits of the city. 
(9)	Establish a connection deposit to be paid by consumers. 
(10)	Authorize disconnection of service for repairs or nonpayment of fees. 
(Code 1989, §§ 210.06-210.11, 210.15, 210.17, 210.18, 210.20, 210.23) 
Sec. 36-53. - Duties and powers of the city administrator. 
    It shall be the duty of the city administrator to: 
(1)	Assess and levy, in the same manner as other taxes, any unpaid water accounts against the property upon which the account has accrued in the form of a lien against the property. 
(2)	Keep books of account of all waterworks transactions, including accounts with customers. 
(3)	Make reports of books of accounts to the waterworks committee. 
(4)	Manage and control employees of the waterworks system. 
(Code 1989, § 210.06) 
State Law reference- Authority to impose a lien against real property for unpaid charges, with penalties, for the connection to and use and availability of water service, Minn. Stats. § 116A.22. 
Sec. 36-54. - Water department functions. 
    The water department, under the direction of the city administrator, shall execute the rules and regulations established by the waterworks committee. The duties of authorized officers and employees of the water department shall include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)	To inspect, at all reasonable times, all service pipes and devices. 
(2)	To enter premises at any reasonable hour to read meters. 
(3)	To keep accounts of water used in the name of the property owner or his duly authorized agent. 
(4)	To install water meters, which are mandatory upon all premises connected to the municipal water system. 
(5)	To turn curb cocks on or off. 
(6)	To disconnect service for repairs or nonpayment of fees. 
(Code 1989, §§ 210.18-210.23) 
Sec. 36-55. - Additional rules and regulations. 
    The waterworks committee has the power to make additional rules and regulations for the administration of the municipal waterworks system not inconsistent with this article. 
(Code 1989, § 210.24) 
Sec. 36-56. - Major repair and replacement. 
(a)	Major repair and replacement fund. The council has the authority to direct the city administrator to create a major repair and replacement fund, to accumulate and invest the surplus proceeds or receipts from water revenues in excess of those sums necessary to meet the payment of the municipal water system bonds in that certain council resolution dated December 8, 1965, and to cover the necessary and budgeted expenses of maintaining the municipal water system and the city water department. Deposits shall be made only on a quarterly basis unless the council directs otherwise under an emergency situation. The fund shall continue to collect surpluses until such time as the goal set by the council from time to time shall have been met. 
(b)	Reasonable and necessary expenses. The waterworks committee shall from time to time apply moneys held in the fund to reasonable and necessary expenses amounting to a sum set from time to time by the council with respect to the water system for major repairs, replacements or maintenance items of a type not recurring annually, or at shorter intervals, or for reconstruction of parts of the water system. Such expenditure must not have been provided for in the operating budget for the water system. The expenditure must be recommended by the city engineer and directed by the council. 
(c)	Expansion of water system. The waterworks committee shall at the time of expansion of the water system apply moneys held in the major repair and replacement fund to the cost of such expansion to the extent that the remaining balance in the fund is not reduced lower than a level set from time to time by the council. 
(d)	Principal and interest of the bonds. The waterworks committee will withdraw from the major repair and replacement fund an amount to apply to the principal and interest of the bonds due for such year whenever water revenues and ad valorem taxes are insufficient to do so. 
(e)	Investment of moneys. Any moneys in the major repair and replacement fund may be invested by the waterworks committee as provided by law. Interest earned by investments may be transferred to the water operating revenues whenever such interest causes the fund balance to exceed the maximum established in subsection (a) of this section. 
(f)	Other withdrawals. No amount shall be withdrawn from or paid out of the major repair and replacement fund except as provided in this section 36-56. 
(Code 1989, § 210.25) 
Secs. 36-57-36-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 36-81. - Application for service. 
    Any person desiring a connection with the municipal water system of the city shall apply in writing to the city clerk on a form furnished by him for that purpose, for a permit to make such connection. The application is to contain an exact description of the property to be served, the estimated maximum amount of water to be used per month, the uses to which the water is to be put, and such other information as the rules and regulations shall require. 
(Code 1989, § 210.02) 
Sec. 36-82. - Permits issued by building official. 
    The building official shall, upon receiving an application as provided in section 36-81, if it is in proper form, issue to the person applying for the permit, a permit to connect with the municipal water system. 
(Code 1989, § 210.03) 
Secs. 36-83-36-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CHARGES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate and charge for connections, Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 5. 

Sec. 36-101. - Rules and regulations. 
    The rules, regulations and water rates enacted by the waterworks committee shall be considered a part of the contract with every person who is supplied with water through this municipal water system; and any person by taking water shall be considered to express his consent to be bound by such contract; and whenever any of the rules or regulations are violated, the water may be ordered shut off by the committee at the place of such violation, even though two or more parties are receiving water through the same pipe; and the meter shall not again be turned on except by a duly authorized person after payment of all accrued charges. 
(Code 1989, § 210.04) 
Sec. 36-102. - Rates. 
(a)	The cost of connections and installation of all plumbing between the water main and the curb box and between the curb box and the premises, and any service device maintained by the consumer, and all extensions made to the service pipes as well as all repairs shall be borne entirely by the consumer. The foregoing shall include, among other things, the cost of the tap-in at water main, corporation cock, curb stop and pipe from main to curb box and from curb box to meter, and the meter. If the consumer is on the opposite side of the street from the water main, a reasonable allowance may be made to him because of extra expense involved in reaching the main. All such service pipes and devices shall at all reasonable times be subject to inspection by duly authorized officers and employees of the water department. Any repairs found to be necessary by such inspection shall be made promptly or the water department will discontinue the service. 
(b)	From time to time the waterworks committee shall publish a schedule of quarterly rates for all city users. 
(c)	Persons residing outside of the corporate limits of the city and receiving water from the city municipal water system shall be charged for such water at such rate as the waterworks committee shall publish from time to time. Bills shall be paid quarterly within 30 days of the date of invoice and, if unpaid on the date due, a penalty as determined from time to time by the city council shall be added. 
(Code 1989, § 210.17) 
Sec. 36-103. - Accounts. 
    All accounts carried upon the books of the municipal water department shall be in the name of the property owner or his duly authorized agent; but the owner shall at all times be liable for the water used, whether he is occupying the premises or not. 
(Code 1989, § 210.19) 
Sec. 36-104. - Deposits. 
    The waterworks committee reserves the right to demand of each consumer a deposit, at the time the water is turned on at any property equal to the estimated cost of three months' service as the waterworks committee shall from time to time compute and publish. Upon the discontinuance of the service either for nonpayment of bills or at the request of the consumer of the service the deposit shall apply first to the accrued charges and the balance, if any, shall be refunded to the depositor upon surrender of the receipt for the deposit. 
(Code 1989, § 210.20) 
Sec. 36-105. - Unpaid water accounts. 
    The city administrator has the power to assess and levy in the same manner as other taxes, any unpaid water accounts against the property upon which such account has accrued; and the assessment and levy shall become a lien against the property. 
(Code 1989, § 210.05) 
State Law reference- Authority to impose a lien against real property for unpaid charges, with penalties, for the connection to, use and availability of water service, Minn. Stats. § 116A.22. 
Sec. 36-106. - Discontinuing service. 
    The waterworks committee reserves the right to discontinue service to any or all customers of the municipal waterworks system without notice when necessary in the repair of the system, or for the nonpayment of water rents; and when water has been shut off for nonpayment, it shall not again be turned on except upon the payment of the water rent past due and reconnect fee and such deposit as the committee shall require, all of which shall be paid to the clerk before the water service shall be turned on. 
(Code 1989, § 210.23) 
Secs. 36-107-36-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 36-131. - Service connections. 
    Tapping the mains will be done only by properly authorized persons. Mains must be tapped on the top side midway between the horizontal and perpendicular lines drawn through the center of the main and not, in any case at or within 12 inches back or 30 inches ahead of a hub or another tap. All tap-ins, installations or curb stops and boxes, and connections from curb stop to main must be made by waterworks employees or other duly authorized persons, and in no case until proper application has been made and permit issued. If the premises do not abut upon a street or alley in which there is a water main, the consumer shall pay the sum necessary to lay a pipe from the main to a point in the street abutting upon the property in question. 
(Code 1989, § 210.08) 
Sec. 36-132. - Every premises shall have a separate connection. 
    Unless special permission is granted by the waterworks committee, each premises shall have a separate and distinct service connection. Where such permission is granted for branch service pipes, each branch must have its separate curb cock and separate meter. The committee shall determine in each case the amount to be charged for such branch connections. 
(Code 1989, § 210.09) 
Sec. 36-133. - Installation of service pipe. 
    No one except regular employees of the water department, plumbers duly licensed, or other authorized person holding a duly issued permit from the water department shall do any plumbing work between the meter and the water mains or any pipes connected or to be connected with the municipal water system; and such work on the pipes between the meter and the water main must be done in accordance with the regulations of the waterworks committee. 
(Code 1989, § 210.10) 
Sec. 36-134. - Trenching and backfilling. 
    All excavations made by authorized persons in public ground shall be closed without any unnecessary delay, and while open shall be protected by suitable barriers, guards and lights as provided by law. Backfilling shall be thoroughly compacted and left in a condition satisfactory to the waterworks committee. Where excavations are not filled to the satisfaction of the committee, the committee shall cause them to be placed in a satisfactory condition; and the cost shall be charged against the owner of the property involved. 
(Code 1989, § 210.11) 
Sec. 36-135. - Character of pipe and service connections. 
    All pipe from main to curb box and from curb box to the premises shall be of brass or copper and shall be laid at least seven feet below the street grade, or as low as the street mains, and shall be laid waiving enough so as not to rupture through possible settling. 
(Code 1989, § 210.12) 
Sec. 36-136. - Bond. 
    Where work is contemplated on the public streets or alleys of this city, such person or the property owner shall be required to execute and deposit with the city clerk a bond in the penal sum of $5,000.00, to be approved by the council as to form and execution, conditioning that he will save the city harmless from any and all lawsuits or damages by reason of any negligence by such person or his employees or agents, in protecting by proper methods any work or excavations on any street or alley and that he will restore such streets or alleys to their former good condition. 
(Code 1989, § 210.13) 
Sec. 36-137. - Authorized persons and permit holders only. 
    No person except one duly authorized and holding a permit will be permitted to tap any distributing pipe or insert a corporation cock in such pipe. 
(Code 1989, § 210.14) 
Sec. 36-138. - Curb stop and water cocks. 
    There shall be a curb stop and box in every service line attached to the mains and placed as near as possible to the property line, if on a street; and if in an alley, the box shall be located wherever the committee shall determine. There shall be one or more stop and waste cocks attached to every supply pipe, at some point between the curb cock and the water meter, so that water may be shut off and the house plumbing entirely drained. 
(Code 1989, § 210.15) 
Sec. 36-139. - Checkvalves required. 
    Checkvalves are required on all connections to steam boilers or on any other connections deemed by the waterworks committee to require one. Safety and relief valves shall be required on all boilers or other apparatus for heating water where the steam pressure might be raised above 40 pounds per square inch. 
(Code 1989, § 210.16) 
Sec. 36-140. - Meters. 
    Every consumer shall provide a suitable place where a meter can be installed, under the rules and regulations of the water department. The meter shall be kept free from debris and set so that they may be easily read and examined. Any meter found to have been frozen or otherwise damaged or out of repair must be repaired or replaced at the expense of the consumer, and no meter shall be repaired or removed except at the orders of the waterworks committee. If the consumer desires to have the meter tested for accuracy, it shall be ordered by the committee. Should the meter register less than 98 percent accurate, it shall be repaired before being installed again. For the purpose of reading meters, duly authorized employees of the water department may legally enter any premises at any reasonable hour. 
(Code 1989, § 210.18) 
Sec. 36-141. - Turning curb cock on or off. 
    It is unlawful for any person except duly authorized persons or employees of the water department to turn any curb cock on or off. 
(Code 1989, § 210.22) 
Sec. 36-142. - Meters required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to take water from the municipal plant except through a meter installed by the water department. 
(Code 1989, § 210.21) 
Sec. 36-143. - All water to be metered. 
    All water furnished by the municipal water plant shall be measured by meters. The meters shall be of such design as the waterworks committee shall specify and shall be installed, purchased and maintained under such rules, regulations and terms as the committee shall determine. 
(Code 1989, § 210.07) 
Secs. 36-144-36-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - DISCONNECTION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Notice requirements for disconnection of utility services, Minn. Rules § 7820.2400. 

Sec. 36-161. - Purpose and intent. 
    The council finds that there are certain users of the city's water who consistently fail or refuse to pay their water bills. While it is the city's practice to certify unpaid water bills onto the taxes for the properties involved this results in a delay in payment and at times causes parties who have recently acquired such a property to pay for the previous owner or occupant's water usage. The purpose of this division is to inhibit the consistent practice of allowing water bills to go unpaid so as to be certified to the real estate taxes and to encourage prompt payment. 
(Code 1989, § 575.01) 
Sec. 36-162. - Disconnection authorized. 
    Any user of the city's water who received from the city invoices for such usage and who fails to currently pay the invoice shall be subject to the following sanctions: 
(1)	Disconnection procedure. If the customer has failed to pay a bill for water service and the amount of the customer's outstanding bill equals or exceeds the amount of the customer's deposit, the city shall be entitled to disconnect the water service, unless the disconnection would affect in any way the primary heat source of a residential unit, to the location at which the customer is then an occupant or owner (whether or not the same) once 30 days have elapsed since written notice of an uncertified but past-due water bill has been delivered to such customer. It shall be sufficient delivery of such notice if sent by first class mail to the address of the user from or upon which he is using city water. 
(2)	Reconnection procedure. Once a user has had water service disconnected as provided in subsection (1) of this section, the water service at the location disconnected shall not be reconnected unless and until all past-due water bills have been paid in full together with such disconnection and reconnection charges as the city council shall from time to time adopt; except that the service of certain qualified customers shall be reconnected in accordance with Minn. Rules § 7820.2300. In addition, if it is determined that the curb box is broken or in need of maintenance or replacement at the time of disconnection, the cost of repair or replacement must also be paid before reconnection shall be authorized. 
(Code 1989, § 575.02) 
Sec. 36-163. - Appeal. 
    Any person aggrieved by any of the provisions of this division shall have the right to appeal to the council in writing setting forth the grounds or reasons as to why this division should not be enforced. The notice of appeal must be delivered to the city clerk within the 30-day period following written notice of default and intent to disconnect referenced in section 36-162. If such written notice of appeal is received by the city clerk, the disconnection shall be stayed until the next regular council meeting, at which time the appealing party may appear and present evidence to support his position. The council shall then rule upon the appeal and mail written notice of its findings of fact and decision to the customer. If the council rules adverse to the appealing party, the disconnection shall proceed forthwith unless the council shall in its discretion specify a later date. A customer who disagrees with the council's decision must submit the entire disputed payment in escrow to the utility and a copy of the utility's escrow payment form to the public utilities commission which shall constitute an informal complaint against the utility to be resolved in accordance with Minn. Rules ch. 7829. 
(Code 1989, § 575.03) 
State Law reference- Disputes, Minn. Rules § 7820.2700. 
Secs. 36-164-36-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWER SERVICE[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to construct, reconstruct, repair, enlarge, improve or obtain sewer systems, sewage treatment works, disposal systems, and other facilities for disposing of sewage, industrial waste, or other wastes, Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 1a(ii). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-191. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Industrial wastes means those particular liquid or other wastes resulting from any process of industry, manufacture, trade or business or the development of any natural resources. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of waste treatment duly appointed by the council. 
(Code 1989, § 415.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 36-192. - Clarification of provisions. 
    To clarify specific sections of this article, please refer to the City of Long Lake Street and Utility Standards and detail plats. Reference also the City of Long Lake Water and Sewer Service Installation, Repair and Disconnect Standards. 
Secs. 36-193-36-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITIONS 

Sec. 36-211. - Connection with public sewer. 
(a)	Unsanitary deposits. It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in an unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the city or in any area under jurisdiction of the city any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(b)	Polluting discharges. It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any sewage, industrial waste or other polluted waters except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. 
(c)	Sewage disposal facilities. Except as otherwise provided, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)	Toilet facilities. Except for accessory buildings, the owner of any structure used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes within the city shall at his expense install and maintain suitable toilet facilities in such structure. If any portion of the lot, tract or parcel on which the structure is located lies within 100 feet of the municipal sanitary sewer system, such facilities shall be connected with the municipal system. The city clerk shall forthwith mail to the owner of every such structure in the city a notice of this requirement. Whenever any portion of the premises on which any such structure is situated shall hereafter be located within 100 feet of any extension of the system, the toilet facilities shall be connected with the municipal system within six months after such extension has been put into operating condition. 
(e)	Waiver. The council is empowered to waive the provisions of this section in those cases where the provisions would work undue hardship against the property owners or would temporarily be impractical because of construction of buildings, planned destruction of buildings and the like. 
(Code 1989, § 415.02) 
Secs. 36-212-36-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 36-231. - Permit required. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb the municipal sewer system or appurtenance without first obtaining a written permit from the clerk. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(1)) 
Sec. 36-232. - Application required. 
    The owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The application shall be supplemented by plans, specifications or other information necessary to show clearly the location and type of materials used. The applicant shall at the time of application pay an inspection fee as shall from time to time be set by the city council. If more than one inspection is required, an additional inspection fee shall be paid for each inspection. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(2)) 
Sec. 36-233. - Costs or expenses. 
    The cost of connections and installation of all plumbing between the sewer main and the premises and any service device maintained by the consumer, as well as all repairs, shall be borne entirely by the consumer. The contracting firm performing the installation shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned to it. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(3)) 
Sec. 36-234. - Connections separate and independent for every building. 
    A separate and independent service connection shall be provided for every building; except that if one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no public sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the sewer connection from the front building may be extended to the rear building, if permitted by the council, and subject to such conditions as the council may see fit to impose. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(4)) 
Sec. 36-235. - Old sewer service connection. 
    Old sewer service connections may be used for new buildings only when they are found on examination and test by the superintendent to meet all the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(5)) 
Sec. 36-236. - Connection specifications. 
    The sewer service connection shall be constructed of cast iron pipe A.S.T.M. specification C200-A2 or equal or other suitable material approved by the superintendent. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(6)) 
Sec. 36-237. - Connection location. 
    The connection of the sewer service connection into the municipal sewer shall be made at the place where the municipal sewer adjoins the property line. Whenever possible, the service connection shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. Any portions of the sewer service connection situated within five feet of the foundation wall must be constructed of cast iron or other approved material, and if laid parallel to the foundation wall must not be closer than five feet. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost. The service connection shall be laid at a uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and fittings, and a suitable manhole shall be installed at any bend of more than 221/2 degrees. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(7)) 
Sec. 36-238. - Gravity flow problems. 
    In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the municipal sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the service connection. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(8)) 
Sec. 36-239. - Excavations for installation. 
    All excavations required for the installation of sewer service connections shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the superintendent. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with A.S.T.M. specifications (C12-19), except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(9)) 
Sec. 36-240. - Joints and connections. 
    All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Joints in cast iron pipes shall be either lead joints or mechanical joints equal to A.S.A. specification A21.11. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(10)) 
Sec. 36-241. - Invert of connection. 
    The invert of the sewer service connection at the point of connection shall be at the same or at a higher elevation than the invert of the public sewer. A smooth neat joint shall be made and the connection made secure and watertight. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the superintendent. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(11)) 
Sec. 36-242. - Inspection by superintendent. 
    The applicant for sewer connection permit shall notify the superintendent when the service connection is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent or his representative. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(12)) 
Sec. 36-243. - Protecting public from hazards. 
    All excavations for sewer service connection installations shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of work shall be restored by the contractor in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(13)) 
Sec. 36-244. - License required. 
    No person shall make any connection whatever with the sewer system or make any repairs, additions or alterations of any fixture connected with or designed to be connected with the sewer system without first having obtained a license to do so under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(14)) 
Sec. 36-245. - Field tapping installation. 
    All field tapping installation must be made with tapping saddle; and all field tapping joints must be sealed with oakum and asphaltic sealer 707 or equivalent, or nonshrinking cement. No Portland cement shall be allowed. 
(Code 1989, § 415.04(15)) 
Secs. 36-246-36-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 36-271. - Quarterly charge. 
    The owner or occupant of each residential premises connected with the municipal sanitary sewer system shall pay a quarterly sewer service charge set from time to time by the council, which shall be measured by the water service to the same premises but will not be higher than the last preceding quarterly period ending on March 31. The owner or occupant of each commercial premises or multiple dwelling premises connected with the municipal sanitary sewer system shall pay a quarterly sewer service charge set from time to time by the council, which shall be measured by the water service to the same premises during the same quarterly period. The minimum charge for any quarterly period to any premises shall be set from time to time by the council, whether the premises are connected to the municipal water system or not. 
(Code 1989, § 415.06(1)) 
Sec. 36-272. - Multiple dwellings, commercial or industrial buildings. 
    For purposes of section 36-271, each separate unit in a multiple-family dwelling or apartment house designed for occupancy by a single person or a group of related persons shall count as single premises. In commercial or industrial buildings, each store, office, factory or other like unit that is equipped with one or more water fixtures draining into the municipal sewer system, separate and distinct from other users, shall count as separate premises. 
(Code 1989, § 415.06(2)) 
Sec. 36-273. - Industrial user strength charge. 
(a)	Authorized. This section establishes an industrial user strength charge in addition to the charge based upon the volume of discharge by an industrial user and establishes an industrial user strength charge formula for the computation of the charge to recover operation and maintenance costs of waste treatment services attributable to the strength of the discharge of industrial waste into the sewer system and establishes tax lien against property served in connection with such strength charge. 
(b)	Recitals. The metropolitan waste control commission, a metropolitan commission organized and existing under the laws of the state, in order to receive and retain grants in compliance with the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972 and regulations under such act, has determined to impose an industrial user sewer strength charge upon users of the metropolitan disposal system (as defined in Minn. Stats. § 473.121, subd. 24) to recover operation and maintenance costs of treatment works attributable to the strength of the discharge of industrial waste, such sewer strength charge being in addition to the charge based upon the volume of discharge. In order for the city to pay such costs based upon strength of industrial discharge and allocated to it each year by the commission, it is found, determined and declared to be necessary to establish sewer strength charges and a formula for its computation for all industrial users receiving waste treatment services within or served by the city. Furthermore, Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 3 empowers the city to make such sewer charge a charge against the owner, lessee, occupant or all of them and certify unpaid charges to the county auditor as a tax lien against the property served. 
(c)	Establishment of strength charges. For the purpose of paying the costs allocated to the city each year by the commission that are based upon the strength of discharge of all industrial users receiving waste treatment services within or served by the city, there is approved, adopted and established, in addition to the sewer charge based upon the volume of discharge, a sewer charge upon each person, company or corporation receiving waste treatment services within or served by the city, based upon strength of industrial waste discharged into the sewer system of the city. 
(d)	Establishment of strength charge formula. For the purpose of computation of the strength charge established by subsection (c) of this section, there is established, approved and adopted in compliance with the act the same strength charge formula designated in Resolution No. 76-172 adopted by the governing body of the commission on June 15, 1976, such formula being based upon pollution qualities and difficulty of disposal of the sewage produced through an evaluation of pollution qualities and quantities in excess of an annual average base and the proportionate costs of operation and maintenance of waste treatment services provided by the commission. 
(e)	Strength charge payment. It is approved, adopted and established that the strength charge established by subsection (c) shall be paid by each industrial user receiving waste treatment services and subject to such charge before the 20th day next succeeding the date of billing to such user by or on behalf of the city, and such payment shall be deemed to be delinquent if not so paid to the billing entity before such date. Furthermore, it is established, approved and adopted that if such payment is not paid before such date an industrial user shall pay interest compounded monthly at a rate to be fixed from time to time by the superintendent on the unpaid balance due. 
(f)	Establishment of tax lien. As provided by Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 3, it is approved, adopted and established that if payment of the strength charge established by subsection (c) is not paid before the 60th day next succeeding the date of billing to the industrial user by or on behalf of the city, the delinquent sewer strength charge, plus accrued interest established pursuant to subsection (e), shall be deemed to be a charge against the owner, lessee and occupant of the property served; and the city or its agent shall certify such unpaid delinquent balance to the county auditor with taxes against the property served for collection as other taxes are collected; however, such certification shall not preclude the city or its agent from recovery of such delinquent sewer strength charge and interest on such charge under any other available remedy. 
(Code 1989, § 415.06(3)) 
Sec. 36-274. - Additional rates and charges. 
    Additional rates and charges may be established for industries which produce wastes in large volume and with high organic material content, based on a report made by the city engineer or superintendent to the council. If such wastes require for proper treatment that the sewage disposal plant or other portions of the municipal sewer system be expanded or replaced, the cost shall be borne by such industry. 
(Code 1989, § 415.06(4)) 
Sec. 36-275. - Sewer service charges. 
    Charges for sewer service shall be billed quarterly simultaneously with charges for water service. Bills shall be due within 30 days of the date of invoice, and, if unpaid on the date due, a penalty determined from time to time by the city council shall be added. Any unpaid charges for sewer service may be certified to the county auditor for collection with taxes levied against the premises served, in accordance with Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 2. In addition, the city reserves the right to shut off water service to any premises for which charges for sewer service have not been paid, wherever so ordered by the council. 
(Code 1989, § 415.06(5)) 
Secs. 36-276-36-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TREATMENT 

Sec. 36-301. - Individual and alternative discharging sewage treatment systems. 
    The improper location, design, installation, use and maintenance of individual sewage treatment systems adversely affects the public health, safety and general welfare by discharge of inadequately treated sewage to the ground surface, surface waters, and groundwaters; therefore, to protect surface water and groundwater and promote public health, safety and general welfare, the city shall regulate all individual and alternative discharging sewage treatment systems in compliance with Minn. Stats. §§ 115.55-115.58 and Minn. Rules ch. 7080, which the city adopts and incorporates by reference. 
Secs. 36-302-36-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 36-321. - Protection from damage. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the municipal sewer works. Any person violating this section shall be subject to immediate arrest for disorderly conduct. 
(Code 1989, § 415.07) 
Sec. 36-322. - Violations. 
(a)	Failure to conform with article. Any person failing to connect with the municipal system as provided in section 36-211(d) and any person violating any other provisions of this article except those contained in section 36-271 shall be served by the city a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a period of 60 days from such notice for its satisfactory correction. The offender shall upon expiration of such notice permanently cease all violations. 
(b)	Continued violation. Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit as provided in subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished in accordance with section 1-13. 
(c)	Liability of violators. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article is liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by the city, by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1989, § 415.09) 
Secs. 36-323-36-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STORMWATER DRAINAGE AND WASTEWATER[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to build, construct, reconstruct, repair, enlarge, improve, obtain and operate sewer systems and storm sewer systems, Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 1a(ii), (iii); powers of metropolitan council in providing wastewater services, Minn. Stats. § 423.504. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 36-351-36-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DISCHARGES 

Sec. 36-371. - Discharge of stormwaters and other unpolluted drainage. 
    Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sanitary and storm sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the council. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged upon approval of the council to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(2)) 
Secs. 36-372-36-390. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PROHIBITIONS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Prohibited waste discharges into the Metropolitan Disposal System, Minn. Rules § 5900.4500. 

Sec. 36-391. - Discharge of waters. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(1)) 
Sec. 36-392. - Discharge of other waters or wastes. 
    Except as otherwise provided, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following waters or wastes to any public sewers: 
(1)	Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(2)	Any water or waste which contains more than 100 parts per million by weight of fat, oil or grease. 
(3)	Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(4)	Any garbage that has not been ground in a garbage disposal unit. 
(5)	Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, shavings, metal, glass, rags, leathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure, or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works. 
(6)	Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 6.0 or higher than 9.0 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewer works. 
(7)	Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, to constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or to create any hazard to the receiving waters or the sewage treatment plant. 
(8)	Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage treatment plant. 
(9)	Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(3)) 
Sec. 36-393. - Admission of waters or wastes into public sewers. 
    The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes: 
(1)	Having five-day carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand greater than 25 milligrams per liter; 
(2)	Containing more than 30 milligrams per liter of suspended solids; 
(3)	Containing any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in section 36-392; or 
(4)	Having an average daily flow greater than two percent of the average daily flow of the city; 
shall be subject to review and approval of the superintendent. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(6)) 
Secs. 36-394-36-410. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TREATMENT 

Sec. 36-411. - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
(a)	Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided in service stations, garages, restaurants, hospitals, rest homes, or any place which serves food daily to 20 or more persons. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent and shall be so located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(b)	Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable covers which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(4)) 
State Law reference- Definition of interceptor, Minn. Rules § 4715.0100, subp. 66; interceptors and separators required, Minn. Rules § 4715.1100; grease interceptors for commercial buildings, Minn. Rules § 4715.1110; interceptors and separators for specific installations, Minn. Rules § 4715.1130 (sand interceptors, subp. 1). 
Sec. 36-412. - Maintenance of interceptors. 
    All grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained at the owner's expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times, and shall be subject to inspection by the superintendent at intervals of 30 days. The owner shall regularly dispose of accumulated materials. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(5)) 
Sec. 36-413. - Preliminary treatment. 
    Where necessary in the opinion of the superintendent, the owner shall provide at the owner's expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to: 
(1)	Reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 300 parts per million and suspended solids to 350 parts per million by weight; 
(2)	Reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits provided for in section 36-392; or 
(3)	Control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes. 
Plans, specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the superintendent and of the state water pollution control commission; and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until such approvals have been received. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(6)) 
State Law reference- Maintenance of interceptors and separators, Minn. Rules § 4715.1150. 
Sec. 36-414. - Maintenance of preliminary treatment facilities. 
    When preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(7)) 
Sec. 36-415. - Manholes. 
    When required by the council on recommendation of the superintendent, the owner of any property connected with the municipal sewer shall install a suitable control manhole in the service connection to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole when required shall be accessible and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the council. The manhole shall be installed at the owner's expense and shall be maintained so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(8)) 
Sec. 36-416. - Wastes and waters measurements, tests and analyses. 
    All measurements, tests and analysis of the characteristics of wastes and waters to which reference is made in sections 36-392 and 36-393 shall be determined in accordance with "Standard Methods for Examination of Water Sewages," published by the American Public Health Association, Inc., 1790 Broadway, New York, NY 10019, and shall be made at the control manhole provided for in section 36-415, or upon suitable samples taken at the control manhole. If no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the municipal sewer to the point at which the waters or wastes to be tested are injected into the sewer. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(9)) 
State Law reference- Analytical procedures for determining constituents in sewage sludge samples, Minn. Rules § 7041.3200. 
Sec. 36-417. - Special agreements or arrangements. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed as preventing a special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1989, § 415.05(10)) 
Secs. 36-418-36-450. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SERVICE AVAILABILITY CHARGES[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to establish service availability charges, Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-451. - Purpose and intent. 
    The council finds that inequities exist pertaining to the connection to city sewer and water services for properties allowed to connect and hook up to them which have not been previously assessed by the city for the cost of construction and/or improvement. It is the purpose and intent of this article to establish connection and hookup charges for such properties in order to help pay for the cost of these public improvements, their availability, maintenance and improvement, as provided by Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subds. 3 and 5. 
(Code 1989, § 410.01) 
Sec. 36-452. - Sewer connection charges; certification. 
    No permit shall be issued to tap or connect with any sewer main of the city either directly or indirectly from any lot or tract of land unless the city administrator first certifies that the sewer connection fee, established and published from time to time as the council deems it necessary to maintain, repair and expand the system, has been paid. 
(Code 1989, § 410.02(1)) 
Sec. 36-453. - Sewer hookup charges. 
    In addition to the connection charges set forth in section 36-452, a hookup charge shall be imposed against each lot or tract of land served by the sewer system for usage of sewer treatment facilities, lift stations, force mains and trunk sewers. The amount of this charge shall be periodically established by motion or resolution of the council. Such periodic revision shall reflect construction cost changes evidenced by the Engineering News - Record Construction Cost Index. Initial charges shall be set by the council from time to time per sewer unit, defined as each 274 gallons of sewage flow per day. Single-family houses, townhouses, condominiums, duplex units, apartment units and mobile homes shall each comprise one sewer unit. Other buildings and structures shall be assigned one sewer unit for each 274 gallons of sewage flow per day which it is estimated they will discharge, and commercial and industrial buildings or uses shall be assigned a minimum of one sewer unit. The number of sewer unit hookup charges to be levied against each premises may thereafter be revised by resolution of the council to more accurately establish the benefit conferred upon the premises, and the council in making the redetermination may take into account the actual quantity of water consumed on the premises. 
(Code 1989, § 410.03) 
Sec. 36-454. - Water connection charges. 
(a)	Certification. No permit shall be issued to tap or connect with any water main of the city either directly or indirectly from any lot or tract of land unless the city administrator shall have certified that the water connection fee, established and published from time to time as the council deems it necessary to maintain, repair and expand the system, has been paid. 
(b)	Fees. The water connection fees for residential units of all types, inside and outside the jurisdictional limits of the city, shall be set from time to time as the council deems it necessary. 
(Code 1989, § 410.04) 
Sec. 36-455. - Water hookup charges. 
    In addition to the connection charges set forth in section 36-454, a hookup charge shall be imposed against each lot or tract of land served by the water system for usage of the wells, pumping stations, water storage facilities and equipment of the city water system. The amount of this charge shall be periodically established by motion or resolution of the council. Such periodic revision shall reflect construction cost changes evidenced by the Engineering News - Record Construction Cost Index. The initial charge shall be set from time to time as the council deems it necessary. A water unit is defined as each 274 gallons of water flow per day. Single-family houses, townhouses, condominiums, duplex units, apartment units and mobile homes shall each comprise one water unit. Other buildings and structures shall be assigned one water unit for each 274 gallons of water flow which it is estimated they will use each day and commercial and industrial buildings or uses shall be assigned a minimum of one water unit. The number of water unit hookup charges to be levied against each premises may thereafter be revised by resolution of the council to more accurately establish the benefit conferred upon the premises; and the council in making the redetermination may take into account the actual quantity of water consumed on the premises. 
(Code 1989, § 410.05) 
Sec. 36-456. - Hookup charges to be added to MWCC SAC/WAC fees. 
    Any sewer or water hookup fee charged pursuant to this article shall be in addition to any similar charges imposed by the metropolitan waste control commission to the city and shall be for the sole and exclusive benefit of the city's respective sewer and water funds. 
(Code 1989, § 410.06) 
Sec. 36-457. - Sewer and water connection charge exemptions. 
(a)	Sewer exemptions. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no property, lot or tract of land located within the jurisdictional limits of the city which has been assessed, reassessed or supplementally assessed for the cost of a sewer public improvement project shall be charged a connection fee as provided in section 36-452. A lot newly created from a previously assessed larger lot shall not qualify for this exemption unless the council imposes upon it a supplemental assessment at or about the time of its creation. 
(b)	Water exemptions. No property, lot or tract of land located within the jurisdictional limits of the city which has been assessed, reassessed or supplementally assessed for the cost of a water public improvement project shall be charged a water connection fee as provided in section 36-454. A lot newly created from a previously assessed larger lot shall not qualify for this exemption unless the council imposes a supplemental assessment upon it at or about the time of its creation. 
(Code 1989, § 410.07) 
Secs. 36-458-36-480. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE AVAILABILITY CHARGES 

Sec. 36-481. - Purpose. 
(a)	It is the purpose of this division to recover from users of city wastewater disposal system facilities, on an equitable basis, the share of the city's facilities' costs attributable to such users, and to provide funds for replacements, debt service and improvements for the city. 
(b)	The city finds it has a limited number of service availability charge (SAC) units. Inequities exist among various commercial users within the city, especially relating to wastewater that is discharged into wastewater disposable system facilities. The city finds that commercial automobile washes use considerable amounts of water which is discharged into the wastewater disposal system facilities. Also, they use significantly more amounts of water than previously estimated. Eliminating wastewater discharge is consistent with protecting the environment and promoting the health, welfare and public safety of the city. 
(Ord. No. 415.041, § 1, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 36-482. - Generally. 
    The debt service for the wastewater treatment facilities shall be recovered from new connections by a service availability charge (SAC) assessed against new building units. The following regulations shall apply to service availability charges (SAC): 
(1)	The service availability charge (SAC) shall be paid at the time at which a building permit or a sewer connection permit is issued for all buildings to be constructed or connected to the sewer system on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division derives. No charge shall be due upon the issuance of a connection permit if a charge was paid upon issuance of a building permit. The debt service connection charge for each building or structure shall be equal to the number of SAC units times the service availability charge in effect at the time of the application. 
(2)	The SAC units for various residential, commercial, public and institutional facilities shall be calculated according to current estimates of the metropolitan council. 
(Ord. No. 415.041, § 2(a), 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 36-483. - Meters. 
(a)	Secured meters measuring water usage shall be installed at the expense of the commercial automobile wash operator. 
(b)	Meters shall be located in a manner and place reasonably accessible to the city for inspection, maintenance and repair, observation, measurement, and sampling and testing at any time without prior notice. 
(Ord. No. 415.041, § 2(c), 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 36-484. - Rates and billing procedures. 
(a)	Rates. Wastewater service charges and service availability charges for the use of and for service supplied by the wastewater facilities of the city shall be established by ordinance and audited annually. 
(b)	Bills. Rates or charges for service shall be payable quarterly. 
(1)	The owner of the premises, the occupant, and the user of the service shall be jointly liable to pay for the service to such premises; and the service is furnished to the premises by the city only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant, and user of the service are jointly liable to the city. 
(2)	Bills for sewer service shall be sent out by the city on the last day of each quarter for which the service is billed. 
(3)	All sewer bills are due and payable 30 days after being sent out. A penalty of ten percent shall be added to all bills not paid by the 30th day after they have been rendered. 
(c)	Delinquent bills. If the charges for such services are not paid within 60 days after the rendition of the bill for such services, such services may be discontinued without further notice and shall not be reinstated until all claims are settled. 
(Ord. No. 415.041, § 2(d), 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 36-485. - Charges as lien. 
    Each charge levied pursuant to this division shall be a lien against the property, and all such charges due on September 30 of each year which are more than 30 days past due, notice having been properly mailed to the occupant or owner of the premises, shall be certified by the council to the county auditor, which shall specify the amount, the description of the premises, and the name of the owner. The amount so certified shall be collected and remitted to the city in the same manner as assessments for local improvements. 
(Ord. No. 415.041, § 2(e), 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 36-486. - Funds from service charges. 
    The funds received from the collection of charges authorized by this division shall be deposited as collected in the city capital revolving fund and shall be used for the operation, maintenance, debt service, replacement and improvement of the city wastewater disposal system. 
(Ord. No. 415.041, § 2(f), 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 36-487. - Powers and authority of city. 
(a)	The city has the right to enforce this division, including but not limited to the recovery of delinquent charges, and may seek all available remedies in any court of competent jurisdiction. Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished in accordance with section 1-13. Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage, including but not limited to attorney's fees, expert fees or engineering fees, occasioned by the city by reason of such violation. 
(b)	Any person found to be violating any provisions of this division shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for its satisfactory correction. Any person who continues any violation beyond the time limit shall be in breach of the service contract and shall be temporarily disconnected from the wastewater disposal system facilities. Such disconnection and reconnection shall be at the total expense of the customer. 
(c)	If any person fails to come into compliance with this division, the city reserves the right to close such use and may disconnect water or waste connections until the operation complies with this division. Any closing or disconnection by the city shall be preceded by written notice and a hearing before the city council. The notice shall give at least ten days' notice of the time and place of the hearing and shall state the nature of the charges against the user. The notice shall be mailed by regular and certified mail to the owner of the property. 
(d)	If any person exceeds his sewer availability charge (SAC) unit allocation, the city reserves the right to close the business operation responsible for the excess SAC unit use and may disconnect water or wastewater connections until compliance with this division. For purposes of determining compliance with this division, the city shall average the SAC unit consumption by the operation over the past 12 months. Any closing or disconnection by the city shall be preceded by written notice and a hearing before the city council. The notice shall give at least ten days' notice of the time and place of the hearing and shall state the nature of the charges against the user. The notice shall be mailed by regular and certified mail to the owner of the property. 
(e)	The city shall be permitted to gain access to such properties as may be necessary for the purpose of inspection, maintenance and repair, observation, measurement, sampling and testing, in accordance with provisions of this division. 
(f)	Where acids and chemicals damaging to sewer lines or treatment processes are released to the sewer causing rapid deterioration of these structures or interfering with proper treatment of sewage, the city is authorized to immediately terminate service by such measures as are necessary to protect the facilities. 
(g)	Any additional costs caused by discharges to the treatment works of toxins or other incompatible wastes, including the costs of restoring wastewater treatment services, cleanup and restoration of the receiving waters, and environmental and sludge disposal, shall be borne by the discharger of such wastes, at no expense to the city. 
(h)	As a condition of use, the city shall be granted access by industrial users to information regarding industrial processes which have a direct bearing on the type and source of discharges to the wastewater collection system. 
(i)	All work performed on private property by the city in the course of operating and maintaining the city's sewer utility shall be performed in full accordance with a duly negotiated and executed easement. 
(j)	The city and its authorized employees shall observe all applicable safety rules while performing work on private property, and the city shall hold the owner blameless for injury or death except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the owner to maintain safe conditions. 
(Ord. No. 415.041, § 2(h), 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 36-488. - Commercial automobile wastes. 
(a)	Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial automobile wash means a building or portion of a building containing facilities for washing automobiles, using production line methods with a chain, conveyor, blowers, steam-cleaning devices or other mechanical devices. 
(b)	SAC unit limitation. The metropolitan council estimates that commercial automobile washes use or consume 25 local service availability charge (SAC) units and 25 metropolitan council service availability charge (SAC) units. Commercial automobile washer operators have represented that reasonable technologies exist to limit the consumption of SAC units to 15 units. Accordingly, the city limits the allocation of SAC units to commercial automobile washes to 15 units unless otherwise agreed to in writing by a majority vote of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 415.041, § 2(b), 7-15-1997) 
Secs. 36-489-36-520. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - STORMWATER UTILITY SYSTEM 

Sec. 36-521. - General operation. 
    The city stormwater system shall be operated as public utility pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 444.075, from which revenues will be derived subject to the provisions of this article and state law. 
(Ord. No. 415.10, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 36-522. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Monthly stormwater utility revenue means the estimated monthly expenditures for planning and inventories, capital expenditures, personnel and equipment, and operation of the stormwater utility, in accordance with established city policy. 
    Stormwater utility fee means the annual charge developed for each parcel of land. 
    Utility factor means the ratio of runoff volume, in inches, for a particular land use, to the runoff volume, in inches for an average single-family residential, assuming a two-inch rainfall and Natural Resources Conservation Services (NRCS) "type B" soil conditions. 
(Ord. No. 415.10, 11-2-1999) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 36-523. - Stormwater utility factors. 
(a)	The stormwater management fee shall be determined by first determining the percentage of total runoff in the city which is attributed to single-family residential property. The fee per acre for single-family residential is computed by computing the product of the runoff percentage and the monthly stormwater utility revenue, divided by the estimated total acres of single-family residential land use in the city. The per-acre fee for all other individual parcels shall be defined as the product of the single-family residential per-acre fee, the appropriate utility factor, and the total acreage of the parcel. Single-family residential parcels shall be assessed on a per-household basis. 
(b)	The utility factors for various land uses are shown in the following table: 
Classification Land Use 1 Utility 
Factor 1. Residential 1.00 2. Commercial 4.23 3. Industrial 3.30 4. Public/Quasi-Public 2.22 5. Parks/Open Space/Cemeteries Exempt 6. Road Right-of-Way Exempt 7. Lakes/Streams/Wetlands Exempt 8. Vacant Exempt 9. Churches/Schools/Institutions 3.74 10. Multifamily Residential; Apartments/Condos/Townhomes 1.30  
1   Land use categories match those found in the city's comprehensive plan, which form the basis of the study "Stormwater Utility: a Special Report to the Long Lake City Council," by Short Elliot Hendrickson, Inc. (SEH). The study provides the basis for the utility factor rates. Generally, these land use categories will correspond to the residential, business, and industrial categories found in the city's zoning ordinance. According to the study, SEH will identify each parcel's land uses after passage of the policy, based on the tax parcel map (p. 43). 
(Ord. No. 415.10, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 36-524. - Credits. 
    The council may adopt fee schedules, by resolution, for adjustment of the stormwater management fees. Information to justify a fee adjustment must be supplied by the property owner. Such adjustments of fees shall not be retroactive. Credits will be reviewed regularly by a staff committee. 
(Ord. No. 415.10, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 36-525. - Exemptions. 
    The following land uses are exempt from the stormwater management fee: 
(1)	Public road right-of-way. 
(2)	Lakes. 
(3)	Wetlands. 
(4)	City property. 
(Ord. No. 415.10, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 36-526. - Payment of fee. 
    Stormwater utility fees shall be billed every quarter with water and sanitary sewer bills. The fee shall be due and payable on the same terms as water and sanitary sewer utility bills. Any prepayment or overpayment of charges shall be retained by the city and applied against subsequent fees. 
(Ord. No. 415.10, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 36-527. - Appeal of fee. 
    If a property owner or person responsible for paying the stormwater management fee believes that a particular assigned fee is incorrect, such a person may request that the fee be recomputed. 
(Ord. No. 415.10, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 36-528. - Penalty for late payment. 
    Each billing for stormwater utility fees not paid when due shall incur a penalty charge as determined by the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 415.10, 11-2-1999) 
Sec. 36-529. - Certifications of past-due fees on taxes. 
    If any two consecutive stormwater utility fees have not been paid when due, a penalty as set forth on section 36-528, shall be added to the amount due. Any such past-due fees may then be certified to the county auditor for collection with real estate taxes on the following year pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 444.075, subd. 3. In addition, the city shall also have the right to bring a civil action or to take other legal remedies to collect unpaid fees. 
(Ord. No. 415.10, 11-2-1999) 
Chapter 38 - VEGETATION[1] 
Footnotes:
